name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I start with an apology that we are starting five minutes late. We took the liberty of waiting a while for Commissioner Moscovici, who is on his way from the railway station. We will start now, because I believe that he will be with us in a few minutes. The next item is the report by Petr Ježek and Jeppe Kofod, on behalf of the Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged contraventions and maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion, on the inquiry into money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion (PANA Committee) (2017/2013(INI)(A8-0357/2017).

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I will inform the Commissioner later. First of all, I would like to thank the journalists involved in the leaks and revelations. They did a splendid job and this was investigative journalism at its best. It seems that the British media magnate, Lord Northcliffe, was thinking about Panama and other leaks when he famously said that ‘news is something someone wants suppressed’. Indeed, those who carried out the barbaric murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia aimed to suppress a similar kind of revelation. In my view, the work of journalists was not only key to the issues related to taxes and money laundering, but it was part of global proof of the paramount importance of traditional journalism in times of disinformation campaigns and distorted or entirely fake news. I am proud that the European Parliament took the baton and established its Committee of Inquiry into Money Laundering, Tax Avoidance and Tax Evasion (PANA Committee) and has been delivering. In particular, those citizens who feel left behind and abandoned by globalisation and other developments may see the behaviour of some rich individuals and companies implicated in leaks as further evidence of the injustice of the world they live in. The European Parliament, after thorough investigations, puts forward clear recommendations on how to improve the situation. Furthermore, it has already presented some of these recommendations, the Commission has made some proposals and the Member States have taken some steps in the directions indicated. Last week, for the first time, the EU published a list of tax havens. It took time and it has certainly not expanded, as some expected, but it is a first and important step. Stricter rules will apply when doing business with the listed countries as two important proposals made by the Commission refer to this list, namely the public country—by—country reporting proposal and a proposal on transparency requirements for intermediaries. Stricter reporting requirements will apply for multinationals with activities in listed jurisdictions or for intermediaries designing tax schemes routed through a listed country. To be credible, we should not only look outside the EU. Speaking about Member States, nothing is all shiny there. I would not perhaps go as far as Oxfam and consider Ireland, Luxembourg, Malta and the Netherlands to be tax havens per se, but some Member States are not very helpful in the fight against tax evasion and tax avoidance and for fairer taxation in general. Tomorrow there will be another – hopefully final – trilogue meeting on the revisions of the Anti—Money Laundering Directive. This is an essential piece of legislation and, in my view, the one that directly answers the Panama Papers revelations. One of the remaining key issues is the level of public access to the register of beneficial owners of companies and trusts. The PANA Committee is in favour of the widest possible access without limitations. One of the significant PANA recommendations relates to the financial intelligence units in Member States. They must be strengthened and have appropriate resources and personnel at their disposal.  Before I conclude, I would like to thank Jeppe Kofod, my co—rapporteur, and the shadows and other colleagues for their work and cooperation. It has been a lot of work and we must get the best out of it in tomorrow’s vote.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the co—rapporteurs, my co—rapporteur and the shadows for the work that we have done in the PANA Committee over the last one-and-a-half years. I would also like to be able to thank the Council, but I have to say that it has been very difficult for us in the PANA inquiry committee to have sincere cooperation with the Council. One of the things we should do is reform the way in which we deal with corporate tax policies in our European Union. The Panama papers, as you all know, were at the time the largest leak – 11.5 million documents. It revealed that a corrupt global elite of politicians, celebrities and corporate leaders had been corrupted and that they do not only put themselves above tax laws, but also above the law as such. We looked into that world in the PANA Committee. We have seen that many heads of states and governments have used opaque structures to hide their assets, to avoid taxes, to do money laundering, and even to carry out criminal activities. This is really detrimental to the trust in our societies and to democracy. Therefore, we need to act on behalf of the citizens to clean up the mess that we have seen in the Panama Papers. Our conclusions are clear. We have seen that EU legislation has not been properly implemented by Member States or enforced by the Commission, for example the Anti-Money Laundering Directive or the Directive on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation. We have seen that the Commission lacks resources and enforcement in this area; we have seen that some Member States grant golden visas to ultra-rich people and do not carry out the due diligence that they should. We have seen that sweetheart deals for big corporations multinationals like Apple, Nike, Starbucks and Ikea have been done by Member States. We have become caught in a sick race to the bottom on taxation and on regulation, and also sometimes on lack of implementation of our own EU legislation. Some of our EU Member States work to dilute and to avoid taking real steps in this field. We have had a secret working group in the Council – the Code of Conduct Group (Business Taxation) – for more than 20 years and they have not proven that they can end these harmful cross-border corporate tax regimes. In our recommendations, we are clear that we need to see open doors and transparency, not only in the way we make corporate tax policies and anti-money laundering policies within the European Union, but also when it comes to intermediaries, banks, lawyers, wealth managers, accountants, the whole industry that lives to put these schemes in place. We need a public EU register for beneficial ownership. We need a tax Europol to have true law enforcement for the people who commit these crimes. We need also to see that tax advisers face real sanctions if they engage in illegal behaviour. We need to end secrecy, tax secrecy and tax havens, and we also need to see that whistle-blowers are protected much better in European Union and also that we support investigative journalism that is doing the job that politicians should have done instead. What we see tomorrow is very important. We have in our recommendations 211 concrete recommendations to fight international tax evasion, tax avoidance and money laundering. Tomorrow, we will see which political groups and which Members of this Parliament are ready not only to talk, but also to vote and to ensure that we have a progressive stand in this Parliament. Now it is time to act, and we want a minimum corporate tax rate in Europe in order to end the endless race to the bottom on corporate taxes and regulation. We need a good and sound list of tax havens, not only in third countries outside Europe, but also in our own family. We need to clean up our own mess within EU Member States and ensure that they also fulfil the highest standards. We have four countries in the EU, and we need to take action to ensure that they also fulfil the highest standards in order to fight tax evasion and avoidance.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I thank both rapporteurs for their work on what is, in my opinion, one of the key items on the agenda of this plenary. Like you, Mr Kofod, I regret that the Council did not take the opportunity to be with us.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: member of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I address you today with a certain solemnity, because we are in the process of concluding a cycle together. This cycle - this political sequence - began very early in your mandate and also in mine, which has been marked by an almost uninterrupted succession of shattering financial scandals. Each time this European Parliament met with the TAX 1, TAX 2 and, today, PANA committees. I would of course like to extend my sincere congratulations to the two rapporteurs, MM. Kofod and Ježek, to the commission of inquiry, to its chairman, Mr. Langen, and to all of those who contributed to the report we are discussing this morning. If the work of the PANA commission is now successful, I sincerely hope that the dynamics it has generated continue. I know that your Parliament wishes to continue its work in this regard. He will do so with the full support of the Commission and with mine in particular. When it comes to tax fraud and tax evasion, the job is not finished, and I would go even further: it is never finished and will never be finished. The imagination of fraudsters and their ability to invent new mechanics are endless, so the fight must also be endless and relentless. More scandals may come, and I would even say, alas, no doubt, because human nature is so made, and so is the greed of some. This will call for a new determined response from our institutions, from the Commission and Parliament in particular. The implementation of the real advances that we have made in recent years must be effective, and we still greatly need the political impetus given by this Assembly to bring the many proposals that are on the table to fruition. In short, if this cycle ends this morning, the political momentum, that of priority to the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion, tax optimization and aggressive tax planning is not complete and must not run out of steam. It would be all the more regrettable if the European Commission and Parliament worked - as you know - in close collaboration, not to say hand in hand, with the PANA committee as with its predecessors. Two weeks ago, I myself was before the PANA committee to take stock of our progress after having discussed at length with the ECON committee on our fiscal agenda. What I can say, three years after the entry into force of this new commission, is that this collaboration has borne fruit: we have already imposed a complete paradigm shift. During these years - this is an international movement - from a culture of secrecy to that of transparency, from compartmentalization to cooperation between administrations. It had never been done before. There is nothing to be complacent about, the fight is not over, but we have come a long way and it would be absurd not to say so. We were able to do all of this thanks to your support and our common work. I therefore wish: that tomorrow we can continue on this path and even deepen it. It is Parliament - like any Parliament - that must decide on the organization of its work and the form it will take. To make further progress, we are of course inspired by your proposals, which echo the driving role that we want, that I want to continue to play by your side against tax fraud and tax evasion. I will therefore start by coming back to some of your proposals to show how the agendas and priorities of our institutions are already converging, and then also show how we can go further. I will classify them briefly into two sets: the actions which aim to make the exchange of information between tax administrations the norm and those aimed at pushing transparency down to the smallest detail and into the smallest corners. As we all know, the automatic exchange of information is crucial in preventing multinationals and some, usually wealthy, taxpayers from trading between national tax codes. Your report rightly points out that our system needs to be further strengthened on this point. Major progress is already visible on the ground, with the generalization of the automatic exchange of information. This began to apply for certain categories of income in 2015. The first automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts took place at the end of September 2017 and, in June 2018, the first automatic exchanges of financial account will take place. information of a fiscal nature on the activity of multinationals. When implementation fails, the Commission does not hesitate and will not hesitate to intervene. For example, we have already opened 18 infringement proceedings for failure to transpose the directive on administrative cooperation: one for what is called DAC 1, 13 for DAC 2 and nine for DAC 3. Idem for the Fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive: we have already initiated infringement proceedings against 16 Member States for failure to transpose. Everyone must of course do their work so that the results can be achieved at all stages: proposal, adoption and effective transposition in the field. Obviously, this task is not finished. Several projects are open and launched to further advance the automatic exchange of information. I therefore presented, less than 15 days ago, a proposal to develop cooperation and trust between European administrations in order to more effectively investigate cases of VAT fraud. You know that this VAT fraud, in particular cross-border, is passive and represents 50 billion euros of losses for our national budgets for the benefit of organized crime and probably also the financing of terrorism. The Paradise Papers further shed light on the extent of this fraud in some jurisdictions involving luxury goods, such as yachts or private jets. I say in passing - I will come to this a little later - to those who tell us "but you do not put European countries on your list of tax havens" - I will explain - that these are indeed European practices of which I speak and that we must banish and fight. We must propose to strengthen the powers of what is called "Eurofisc", which is also the cooperation between the tax and customs administration, their European partners, such as Europol, OLAF and the brand new European Public Prosecutor's Office. I know that by doing this we are stepping a little on the beds of the sovereignty of tax administrations and that there will be resistance. However, if we do not move from the culture of everyone for themselves to a culture of cooperation and transparency, also between administrations, then we are not doing our job. I am therefore sending our Member States and their tax administrations a strong message that this cooperation must take place. Your report also mentions the cooperation between financial intelligence units (FIUs) which play an essential role. In June, the Commission published a report and recommendations which identify all the obstacles to this cooperation. We will actively support the work of the Financial Intelligence Unit Platform. We also plan to come up with an initiative to improve cross-border sharing of financial data. Next to the automatic exchange of information, which - I repeat - is the mother of all reforms and the essence of all progress, we must now even more transparency. The "Panama Papers" and even more the "Paradise Papers" have highlighted the role of intermediaries in tax avoidance and optimization schemes. Your report notes a lack of transparency - and I was going to say almost by definition - about these aggressive optimization schemes. We share it fully. We must shed light on these arrangements between friends which bind, in the greatest opacity, multinationals - not all multinationals -, consulting firms - not all consulting firms -, law firms - not all law firms - and banks - not all banks. I say this because I think we should avoid stigmatizing professions. I totally understand why they take offense, but at the same time we have to separate the wheat from the chaff. Those who do their jobs with absolute respect for the law and ethics and those who fail to do so. This is why the Commission proposed in June that intermediaries systematically report to the tax authorities in their clients' countries optimization schemes that meet certain characteristics - not all schemes, some characteristics. These data will be accessible to all Member States to further strengthen cooperation between administrations. I said it before the PANA committee, I will say it again here in the plenary: I call for the adoption of this fundamental proposal by the Member States within six months. Let's not waste time, it must be done entirely during this term. Finally, the mandatory country-by-country public declaration, which we proposed last year, will also be a major step forward. I insist on the term "public": I think that today, to refuse transparency, to plead opacity is something totally archaic, which belongs to the past. These are old protective reflexes that don't correspond to anything today. Opposing transparency and competitiveness is a poor alibi. Yes, we have to go to the public declaration and we have to go quickly. Forcing large companies to disclose the details of their activity in each country where they operate, or rather asking them to do so, will allow everyone (citizens, journalists, parliamentarians, NGOs) to exercise their right, which is a power of control. The latest scandals remind us to what extent the role of this transparency and of these actors of public control is fundamental in bringing fraudulent practices to light. I take this opportunity to really salute the work of the media, of the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, without whom we would not have made so much progress. While European cooperation in tax matters is absolutely necessary, it is certainly not sufficient. We know that multinational corporations or wealthy individuals use global tax schemes to evade taxes. In this regard, I want to stress, of course, the list of third countries at high risk of money laundering or terrorist financing - this is a fundamental tool. Another fundamental list is the first list of tax havens, adopted by member states last week. I want to say it very frankly here. This is progress: 17 countries have been identified for breach of good governance standards, but above all - because it is at least as important - 47 countries have committed themselves at a very high political level to reforming their tax system and meet the criteria of good tax governance. It is therefore a dynamic that must be welcomed. However, it must also be said that there are shortcomings or incompleteness. I ask the finance ministers to avoid any naivety about the commitments of the 47 countries of what can be called "the gray list", which must change their tax laws as quickly as possible. This needs to be watched very closely and, if not, darken the situation. I therefore wish to appeal here formally and solemnly to the Member States on the monitoring of these lists. I call on them first to define dissuasive national sanctions. We must do everything to keep the pressure on the member countries, the principle of "name and shame" (denounce and blame) is a first step forward, but we must go further. This is why it is necessary to examine the immediate effects of the adoption of the list and its impact on the triggering of the European Fund for Sustainable Development, on that of the European Fund for Strategic Investments or more generally on the financial regulation of the Union. . These issues must be resolved quickly. This applies to European funds; this also applies to international financial institutions, such as the EIB or the EBRD. I also call on the Member States - I am finishing this, Mr President - to keep the follow-up of these first stages in a tight and precise timetable. In three months, we should be looking at the hurricane-affected countries - we've given them a deadline, then you have to look at it on a case-by-case basis. Six months from now, we need to review all of the commitments and make sure they are kept. In a year, we will have to review the list by removing those who have kept their promises - that is the goal - and add those who have not kept their word. I know that on some benches - I understand them all the better as I share this - and beyond this chamber, some were hoping for more from this list. I share those expectations, but I believe in taking this list for what it is - a positive first step - and going further. I know in passing the question of our own Member States arises. I say it again here in Parliament - I know it does not generate much media attention, but it’s the truth: you cannot compare the situation of any country in the European Union with such and such a tax haven, ie systemic and systematic which is on our list. But there are practices in our Member States that must be combated, and saying that they are not tax havens does not mean that we must let these practices continue to continue quietly. No, when there is VAT fraud or when there is suspicion of fraud in Malta, the Isle of Man, when there is legislation in the Netherlands which appears to have already been condemned, I say " speed up ”. We must therefore be absolutely rigorous with this and not confuse practices to be combated or banned with belonging to a list. Ladies and gentlemen, it was not my ambition to cover all the recommendations in your report, it would have taken even longer. It is very comprehensive, but I wanted to recall the main lines of the work we are doing to guarantee more efficient and fairer taxation in the European Union, in accordance with the expectations of our fellow citizens and your recommendations. I also know that you and I know that going further will also require changing the rules of the game from unanimity to qualified majority voting. All this your report says or suggests, and I thank you. I repeat my availability to you to continue to cooperate fully with your assembly in the fight against tax fraud, avoidance and optimization. I know that, in this fight, the Commission and Parliament are moving forward, once again, together. I know that, for you, this is a sine qua non and, for me, an absolutely indispensable support, for which I would like to thank you by welcoming, once again, the work of the rapporteurs and the committee.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, tax policy should be one of our key economic priorities, and it is, unlike in the past. We have actually achieved a lot. We have introduced new measures such as the Anti-Tax Avoidance Package (ATAP), we improved cooperation through the Directive on Administrative Cooperation and we are improving our efforts to fight money laundering through amendments to the Anti-Money Laundering Directive. We have also improved transparency, which is a very important part of this fight, and a lot of initiatives such as the Common Corporate Tax Base (CCTB) and tackling VAT fraud are on the table.  So progress has been made, but, as was revealed in the work of the PANA Committee, the mission is far from being completed. We need to improve enforcement, as was suggested, for example, in the Azerbaijan Laundromat hearing. We must make beneficial ownership information more available in order to fight money laundering, and the EU should use its soft and hard power more effectively to influence other countries.  Last, but not least, the Finance Ministers must agree to dismantle tax practices that are not in line with the mutual interests of the EU. At the same time, over-politicising the issue, proposing not functional, or even bad, measures that make good headlines and no progress, is not the way forward. That is why I believe that in the plenary vote we will substantially improve the report of the committee and the report will get broad support. As a consequence, we will strengthen our push for the Commission to fight in this area.

name: Peter SIMON
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Now, at the conclusion of the work of the Panama Committee of Inquiry, it is necessary to draw a conclusion. I think what we can establish is - as it was after the work in the special investigation committee TAXE - how important it is that we, alongside the member states, as the European Chamber of Citizens - as the European Parliament - against money laundering and state-organized tax avoidance, Drag field. Why? The Member States' Code of Conduct Group and other forms of cooperation between the Member States are inadequate. No Member State picks out another's eye like the crow. That is the experience that we have had in recent years, and only if we as the European Parliament move forward resolutely here, regardless of which government is in power in a member state, will we also succeed, against tax havens and places where the fight against money laundering is not carried out in the way we imagine it to actually proceed. As the Chamber of Citizens, we have the opportunity not only to show the member states their limits, but also to get them to act. As the European Chamber of Citizens, we are in a position to develop public pressure, which behind closed doors certainly does not arise when the Member States discuss these things. Then hopefully in the future we will also come up with better lists of tax havens outside the European Union. Hopefully also to lists of tax havens within the European Union and the corresponding lists of countries that we see as money laundering paradises and that we want to take action against. (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs and thank all the colleagues we have worked with for their work. Since the establishment of this special commission, seven fact-finding missions on money laundering and tax fraud have taken place, from February 2017 to September 2017. In addition, twenty-nine ordinary meetings, sixteen coordinator meetings and a series of public hearings. All this was in an extremely tense and strict time frame. The reports in the PANA Committee have shown how important it is to have appropriate vigilance and oversight systems. Although there are still many problems, some more serious than others, I would like to welcome the efforts of the Member States, which are actively working to combat illegal taxation and money laundering schemes. It is especially important to talk about tax havens and tax havens. It is important to remember that great efforts are being made and significant progress must be made. This is especially important in times like ours - with countless new forms of threats to national security, citizens, etc. Money laundering schemes are not only used for personal gain, but as we all know - to finance terrorist activities very close to our doorstep. Achieving a balance between not hindering economic development and maintaining our security is not an easy task. But every effort must be made to protect the citizens of the Member States of the European Union. I believe that the wide-ranging discussions we have here on this stage will contribute to finding good solutions and maintaining an open dialogue.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr. President, in this committee we have not known who the leaker of the Panama papers was, and fortunately, because we would not have been able to protect him. And at this moment we have to remember the brave. Journalists have told us that they fear multi-million dollar lawsuits. But Daphne Caruana isn't even; Besides being with the multimillion dollar lawsuit problem she was murdered. And her family has contacted us to say that they still need an independent commission of inquiry and are not being informed. So we named a room after her to recognize her memory, but we have to do something else. In this committee we have had to review the existing European legislation and its actual compliance, both in fiscal and financial matters. We have had to assess what is wrong in the fight against money laundering; how capital disappears in public finances; how it is possible to finance terrorism, drug trafficking or sexual slavery. They are the most serious crimes, those that most attack freedom, those that most attack the rule of law. And the dens of financial secrecy collaborate with intermediaries in rich countries, where these great assets are located. Some of the smartest tax advisers, lawyers, financial institutions, auditors and managers of large capitals and wealth have in fact acted as facilitators of evasion or avoidance. And circumvention - it has already been said - is only possible if the Member States actively or passively allow it. And national and European financial supervisors are not working enough - this we have been able to learn. So if the key to serious crime is hiding the real beneficiary of the money, we have to bring it up. The Council is not here today, and I am not surprised, because they have been cowards with the list and we cannot wait any longer, Commissioner. Within six months We will speak again and you will surely tell us something to cheer us up, but things are like this.We need transparency.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. president. We could not begin this intervention without expressing our gratitude to leakers and journalists. Without your work, this commission would not have been possible, it would not have occurred. Because it is the scandals that motivate that later the institutions have, precisely, to make commissions to demonstrate that something is done against tax evasion. If this commission has shown anything, it is that this is not a temporary problem, but rather a structural problem. Tax evasion and avoidance are structural problems. And that is precisely why we propose a permanent commission, not more special commissions. A permanent commission in the European Parliament. For many, the inquiry commission has simply been a facelift. But I think that from this committee we have managed, based on our work, to produce a good report: recommendations that are not binding but that are important to be able to work against tax evasion, a useful tool. But many of the accomplishments of this commission are at risk. They are at risk from the amendments of the ALDE and PPE Groups, who want to mutilate this text tomorrow, eliminating key elements for the vote. If this occurs, we will be giving an image as shameful as the white list of tax havens of the Commission and the Council. Tocqueville said that the French Revolution really began with a previous revolt of the privileged. Today, two hundred years later, we have a revolt of the privileged: those who do not want to pay taxes. (The President calls off the speaker.)

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, it was the Greens/EFA Group that began the process of establishing the inquiry committee into the Panama Papers whose report we are debating today.  We have a report to be proud of, with strong recommendations to clamp down on tax avoidance, tax evasion and money laundering. Our recommendations include requiring an economic justification before offshore structures can be established and ensuring that EU funds can never find their way to tax havens. We hope that our friends in other Groups will support this strong action against tax cheating to respond to the public outcry against continuing scandals. Any weakening of this report’s proposals represents contempt for their views.  After months of evidence-gathering and inquiry and the further revelations of the recent Paradise Papers, there can be no excuse for inaction. The Commission must take immediate steps to turn these recommendations into legislative proposals. We also look to the Council to adopt the legislative proposals made in the aftermath of the Panama Papers, especially greater transparency for the activities of large companies and the revision of the anti-money laundering rules.  A failure by Member States to cooperate to fight tax evasion and tax avoidance means that too many proposals are blocked in Council, which demonstrates its contempt for our work by not even sending anybody to be present at this debate. To break this blockage, we call on Commissioner Moscovici to present a legislative tax proposal under codecision during 2018.

name: Marco VALLI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have reached the conclusion of this third committee which dealt with the problem of tax havens. I remember that there are tax havens within the European Union and these tax havens are listed in the recent Oxfam report, and they are Luxembourg, Ireland, Malta and the Netherlands. These are countries that are also founders of the European Union and that continue to perpetrate a fiscal policy that attacks what is the possibility of countries to recover taxes from multinationals, and we must do everything possible to make this scandal stop. Unfortunately, the report is not binding, in fact there is a broad consensus in this Parliament. The problem then lies in the legislative proposals: we want the Council to be able to work well on this and find solutions and take what will be written in the report to heart. I hope, I repeat, that a text will not be depleted in the vote which, however, although not legislative, will be important in giving a move to this system.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, Commissioner Moscovici! A specific demand of the Panama Committee of Inquiry has already been met, namely the black list of states not willing to cooperate, which has been available since December 5th. Many were disappointed that there were only 17 states on it, not a single EU country, not even relevant tax havens such as Guernsey or Andorra and not even the USA, which do not want to cooperate with the European tax authorities. On the contrary: just recently five EU finance ministers sent a letter to the US finance minister warning that some of the regulations proposed under the new tax reform would violate the WTO rules and the agreements of the OECD in the fight against Tax avoidance violation. The black list is still having an effect; Of the 92 countries asked, 47 have promised to cooperate with the EU tax authorities and to adapt their tax legislation and have ended up on a gray list. In the future there will even be sanctions against these states, from freezing EU funds to measures at the state level. The black list is only one requirement of the report of the PANA committee of inquiry; many other points are still open. There is a great need for action here, because aggressive tax planning means that European households lose 70 billion euros in revenue every year. From a financial point of view, VAT fraud is a major issue, accounting for 150 billion euros. And the digital economy, where the Council adopted new rules on December 5th to make it easier for online businesses to comply with VAT regulations. The fight against money laundering will be countered with the revision of the fourth money laundering directive. Likewise, there should soon be proposals against mediators. Much remains to be done in the fight against tax avoidance. But we're on that right way.The PANA Committee of Inquiry and TAXE 1 and TAXE 2 have contributed to the fact that a large number of concrete measures were proposed that would lead to more transparency and fair ... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: - Mr President, the debate over tax havens, by stigmatizing some "immoral" capitalists, acquits the system that secures the funds stored there, which do not exceed 5% of total deposits. Eventually it becomes a joke! In other words, you admit that after the revelations, which of course do not serve transparency but merely competing interests, the tax havens multiplied within the European Union. The European Bargaining Council has excluded cases such as the Cayman Islands from tax havens. The resolution in question insists and urges to distinguish between illegal and legal tax evasion and tax exemption tactics, perpetuating the tax privileges of capital paid by the people with a savage tax raid, such as the increase in VAT on the Greek islands, which are being tested. Nomination of all shares, removal of all secrecy, ban on offshore companies, control of capital movements; can you do that? Of course not, because they go against the DNA of the system and the European Union, that is, the freedom of capital to move and hoard where it can best. This, no matter what you do, does not improve. It just overturns.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: - The 2016 disclosure of Panama papers caused a big scandal because it showed how large-scale tax avoidance, tax evasion and money laundering are taking place in the world. According to the estimates of the European Commission, the total losses of the budgets of the European Union Member States on this account alone amount to EUR 1,000 billion a year, and globally, such practices may cost the budgets of individual countries over USD 3,000 billion. The favorite places of these scams are of course the so-called tax havens, but in general these are jurisdictions that offer secrecy, anonymity and very low tax rates. The committee of inquiry has done a very good job. The report that we are receiving and discussing is a good report. Its main points have already been reported. I would like to say that we could make this report even better if there was better cooperation between the political groups in Parliament. In this context, I am asking the Socialists and Democrats group to show some flexibility before tomorrow's vote and to meet the expectations of other political groups, because we in Parliament need a very strong signal to the public. We must have the support of the entire House on this. He therefore calls for some compromises to be reached before tomorrow's vote, allowing the whole House to vote in favor of this report.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - On the Panama Papers, in the same week that we met with the Council and the Commission, in the 9th round of negotiations on the 5th directive on the prevention of money laundering and terrorist financing, which have been going on for eight months due to sheer obstruction by some Member States, the Council persists in denying public access to the registrations of beneficial owners of companies and trusts and insists on maintaining loopholes and escape routes for the financial crime industry to continue to operate with impunity. Even the creation of a European Financial Information Unit was ominously rejected by the Council. Now, advancing to the 5th directive resulted from the imperative to combat the financing of terrorism after the attacks on the Bataclan in Paris. But despite the reformist rhetoric, scandal after scandal and attack after attack, certain Member States do not really want to change. The capture of European governments for the interests of industry, tax evasion and money laundering is exposed in the absence of coherent and decisive action for tax justice against financial crime, corruption and the financing of terrorism. Malta, where Daphne Caruana Galizia was murdered, is a sinister example of this capture. We know that our work in the European Parliament, together with the investigative press, which I welcome, can make a difference. Thanks to our pressure on the Luxleaks scandal, Commissioner Vestager demanded that the Irish Government recover the taxes it had saved Apple and Commissioner Moscovici made new and positive proposals. We will continue the investigations of the Panama Papers and the Paradise Papers and we will expose the captured, the corrupt, the cover-ups and the criminals, wherever they are, and many are here in Europe, where there are many tax havens that are not on the list recently cynically approved by the Council. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the “blue card” procedure, pursuant to Article 162, paragraph 8 of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Nuno MELO
text: Question according to the "blue card" procedure.- I just wanted to ask you if, when you arrived here, you are finally convinced that Panama is Panama, Madeira is Madeira, Madeira has nothing to do with Panama, that when you treat Madeira as if it were not Panamait helps Europe but it certainly hurts Portugal.And finally, on the occasion, taking into account its final part, you may want to take the opportunity to say something about the current scandal of the Raríssimas, in Portugal, and those it involves, because, in short, it is very much your area and your word perhapshad some weight.

name: Ana GOMES
text: Answer according to the "blue card" procedure.- Madeira is Madeira and the Honorable Member brought it here, and I think Madeira is a tax haven.In fact, the justification for tax havens like Madeira is the same in Luxembourg or Malta: we are small, we have no resources, so we can get into organized crime.It could be the drug, it's white-collar crime.In my view, this is not acceptable, either in Portugal or in the European Union as a whole, and the Commission has responsibilities here and cannot continue to endorse situations like Madeira.And in relation to any corruption scandals in Portugal, from José Sócrates to Raríssimas, or whatever, I will be the first to do everything to expose them ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Colleagues, I am about to close the list for catch-the-eye in a couple of minutes. While we have a lot of requests for the floor from a number of the Groups, we still do not have any from two or three Groups, so I will give a few final minutes to attract the attention of the Chair for catch-the-eye and then I will close the list.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, you are not here today. Where are they actually? Why is this plenary hall yawning empty again? The most important committee of inquiry of this legislative period has now met - for a year and a half. It was about tax evasion, criminal activity, money laundering, terrorist financing, issues that are central to the future of us all and to our society, and Parliament does not seem to care. Why is the Chamber not packed today? Why aren't colleagues excited to see what this committee of inquiry has found out? I ask myself: Mr Simon spoke about the fact that we are a citizens' parliament. What are we How do our citizens want to understand what we have done if they do not at least take note of what work has been done here and where the grievances are. The most serious allegations are made against member states that have not implemented the third money laundering directive, as well as against the EU Commission, which has not insisted that it be implemented. Also to Parliament, which for years failed to take any action, even though everyone knew that this type of tax evasion and money laundering ... (The President cut off the speaker) (The speaker agreed to a Question about the "blue card" procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Peter SIMON
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr. Lucke!You pull over all the colleagues here who are not there.You know very well that the colleagues work in around 70 meeting rooms here.Don't you think populism is cheap?

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr. Simon!Sometimes there are important things to negotiate in a Parliament, and I think we have an hour like this today when we are discussing something important.It is reasonable to expect colleagues to come to the plenary chamber and take part in such a debate or at least listen to it.What we have seen here is a great violation of justice.There are rich and super-rich and super-influential people here who just don't pay the taxes they ought to pay, who move their income to some tax haven.And your party leader, the former President of this Parliament Martin Schulz, has made justice his central election issue.I ask myself: Why aren't there more Social Democrats in the plenary than is the case now?

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Colleagues, we have had an exchange of views on participation in this important report, but I would appreciate it if we could now focus on the substance and on the report itself.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, of course I congratulate all the members of the PANA Commission for the work they have done, as it undoubtedly provides a series of very positive elements for the fight.In such a short time, I can only go to the essentials: the Commissioner said that he appreciated Parliament's support.Look at you, it is not support, it is a requirement.That is to say, this is of greater political importance than one might imagine.When Panama and all that comes out - thanking the journalists who bring it out - some react by the morbidity of a soccer player, a super-rich and such, but the people know that democracy and especially the European welfare statethey are being unfairly attacked.It is not European who programs it but who works.The adversary is the Council and it must be convinced that it must be much more ambitious because European democracy is at stake.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Mr President, it is ironic but hardly surprising that, just as the Panama Papers inquiry is finished, we are now faced with an even bigger offshore leak: the Paradise Papers. We urgently need a new committee to examine those Appleby revelations. Let us remember that there is a human cost to this system that allows the ultra-rich to avoid contributing to society in any meaningful way and which deprives communities of the public services they need. In Ireland, we have seen eight people die in the freezing cold on the streets in a period of 14 weeks as a result of a homelessness crisis largely caused by a lack of investment in social housing.  Our governments are not innocent bystanders in the corporate tax avoidance system. In many cases, they actively promote it. There is a political choice to be made by those in power. Either shield the financial secrecy of the super rich, or promote the rights and wellbeing of communities. You cannot do both. This Parliament has a role to play in setting the political agenda. We need to make the strongest possible statement calling for this rotten offshore system to be wiped out when we vote on this report.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I will now close the catch-the-eye list and I will not re—open it. We have a long list and we also still have a long list of scheduled speakers.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! We have done a good job here over the past year and for a long time, across political groups. I would like to express my thanks to the Commission, which has incorporated much of what we have worked on here into proposals. What is now before us here in plenary is annoying: we have a total of 38 amendments and split votes plus 12 more, that is 50 proposals from the Christian Democrats and 34 from the Liberals, which aim to weaken this report by a majority. It is not about a few details, but rather some of these amendments or attempts to delete them go straight to the heart of this report. I really ask you to look at this again in detail. It is not right for us to maintain self-supervision over money laundering with lawyers or accountants. Dear Liberals: Infringement proceedings against member states are necessary if they fail to comply with the rules. We need minimum taxation on the worst shifts in interest and royalties. It is also wrong if Mr Juncker advocates majority proceedings, but you delete precisely these legislative proposals under Article 116. Please think again! (The President cut off the speaker)

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, Merry Christmas to friends and foe alike. Over the last few years, this Parliament has come up with a plethora of tax reports. Time after time, the conclusions are the same. We need more taxes, we need higher taxes, and we need a harmonisation of tax policies. In the meantime, the European Commission is advocating a common consolidated corporate tax base (CCCTB) and last week the European Code of Conduct Group proudly announced a blacklist of tax havens. It seems the EU federalists want to punish the UK for taking a democratic decision to leave. This is why some EU politicians are telling journalists that the UK will be blacklisted as a tax haven after Brexit. By threatening us, you are proving once again that the only aim of these EU tax proposals is banning freedom and free competition. According to this Panama report, tax avoidance is the improper utilisation of tax regimes. What you do not seem to understand is that people have the right to keep the fruits of their labour. Tax ...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Thank you colleague, and thank you for your Christmas wishes, which I can reciprocate.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the subtle distinction that Commissioner Moscovici, to justify the absence of Member States on the list, proposed to us between States that have some irregular practices and those that are instead a general system of protection of hidden finances. I think that Commissioner Moscovici's somewhat Jesuit distinction is used in reverse, it can be used in reverse: you have blacklisted poor Mongolia and you exclude Luxembourg, which is a state in the form of a tax haven. It is a tax haven, rather, in the form of a state, as we all know. And yet it's not there, you haven't put it on. The report should be criticized a little because it does not elaborate, as it should have been, two aspects: first, the strong link of the issue of tax havens with the dirty, mafia, irregular capital of international drug trafficking. Even a very high UN exponent from Vienna, and he repeated it here in Brussels, denounced the role of banks in international trafficking, in covering the capital of drug trafficking. This report is not enough, and we are not going to vote on it for that.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Mr. President, in recent years there have been many times when the subject of discussion in the Plenary has the publication of documents that reveal some of the owners of offshore companies. It should be noted that, unfortunately, these lists almost always include the names of politicians, often well-known. Of course, I suspect that, as in previous times, this time too, different views will be expressed, but in the end we will have zero real result or perhaps - the best case scenario - prosecution against some scapegoats and everyone else continuing to exploit gaps in the international financial system. And they will continue to exploit them, because it is these offshore companies that are the backbone of this system. The international corporatism, towards the full domination of which we are steadily moving, could not survive without the offshore companies, and the political leaders are now content with the role of the simple handler of various cases of the large multinational companies. So there is no way to deal with this phenomenon with the existing economic system and the only solution we propose is to overthrow it.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: - Mister President! As chairman of the committee of inquiry, I would like first of all to thank all members, the secretariat, the rapporteurs, but also Commissioner Moscovici for the fair and good cooperation over the past year and a half. We held 25 hearings, initiated eleven studies and made seven on-site visits. The result is now and it is up to the political groups to adopt the recommendations drawn up by the committee. I have the great request that we do not end up drafting this report in such a way that we no longer have any demands. We have to keep up the pressure! That is why I am also in favor of a special committee being installed by the end of the legislative period. And I hope the groups will find a common line here. "Transparency is the key," said Mr Moscovici. However, I doubt that we have already achieved the paradigm shift. The cooperation between the Member States and with Parliament leaves much to be desired. Before the EU member states decide on sanctions against third countries, they must put their own areas of responsibility in order. That is my conclusion from the Panama Papers. And that is why I say: personally, I will also vote for Amendment No 14 by the Social Democrats, which names four Member States. And I ask everyone to work out a resolution and a proposal tomorrow that will also generate the necessary pressure.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Mr President, Mr Langen, as chairman of the PANA committee, you have been an excellent chairman and you have just demonstrated it. I therefore invite you to convince your group, if you do not want to lower the level of ambition of this report, to withdraw all the requests for separate votes which have been tabled by your group or for amendments which still aim, after having shared a report on the scandal represented by tax evasion or tax fraud, to broaden the scope of exceptions or to reduce the scope of the legislation that we implement. I also invite the spirit of good cooperation to which Mr. Rosati has appealed. We invite him to be ambitious, by our side, in denouncing the role of intermediaries, because this is the next important step, when we have adopted this report from the PANA commission. Finally, with regard to the list of tax havens, I too obviously support the amendments by my colleagues Peter Simon and Paul Tang, which should help shed light on practices within the European Union. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Ms Berès, I am afraid that only one minute was communicated to the Secretariat. I do apologise.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: - (FI) Mr President, the report of the PANA Committee of Inquiry has raised many opinions for and against. The listing of tax havens within the EU has been particularly emotional. Whatever solution is now reached, it is clear that sooner or later this problem will need to be addressed. In the slightly longer term, this is also in the interests of the citizens of the states providing tax haven services. If the financial and tax planning sector gets too much power, everyone will eventually lose. There are also many other important points in the PANA report. I call for the development of a common definition of tax havens, better regulation of free production areas, raising the level of ambition of money laundering surveys in third countries, strengthening the code of conduct for companies and tackling tax evasion and avoidance intermediaries. The key initiatives are united by the fact that they require long-term monitoring. Therefore, the good work done by the PANA Committee of Inquiry needs to be continued even more closely… (The President cut off the speaker) (The speaker refused to answer the blue card question (pursuant to Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: - Mr President, on the basis of this report and the 200 recommendations that accompany it, it is urgent to tackle tax evasion and tax evasion by bringing our actions into line with our words and with this text. It is time to put an end to this madness which costs European workers 1 trillion euros, according to the European Commission figure. This is more than ten times the budget of the European Union itself. It is also ten times more than what the Paris conference decided to allocate to the Green Climate Fund. We must therefore make great strides towards effective harmonization of corporate and banking taxation, since it would allow money to be redirected towards job creation and environmental transition: tax financial speculation, demand banking transparency and prevent organized fraud, in particular VAT. An effective act would also be to come out of powerlessness and use the springs of Article 116 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which authorizes the modification of the unanimity requirement in the European Council.

name: Eva JOLY
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it has been eighteen months since our committee investigated the “Panama Papers” scandal. Tomorrow we will vote on our final report. We, Members of the European Parliament, must be there! At a time when citizens no longer support impunity and inaction in the face of the tax privileges of a few, it is unacceptable, and above all incomprehensible, that some in this hemicycle seek to weaken our recommendations to combat the tax evasion. Let us live up to our responsibilities, let us adopt an ambitious report in the face of Member States which systematically block the necessary reforms of tax transparency and harmonization. Our Parliament must remind them of the meaning of the general interest. To those who are still hesitant to vote for some of the key recommendations, I would like to reiterate this: tax evasion is a destructive process that plunders public finances, accentuates inequalities and threatens the foundations of living together. Whoever refuses to act against it destroys Europe. (The speaker accepts to answer a 'blue card' question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Madam Joly, everyone wants to continue this committee. I wondered if you would agree with me that perhaps a good name for it should be the ‘Robespierre committee’, because it just seems to be an excuse for a bunch of lefties to give big business and little businesses who are trying to protect themselves a good kicking. So perhaps, Madam, you would agree with me, the ‘Robespierre committee’ should be the name given to this committee in the future?

name: Eva JOLY
text: "blue card" response.- Here I find your usual attitude of negating climate crises or financial crises, and the role of tax havens, and in particular that of England, which has a network of tax havens which are extremely harmful for the rest of the Union, and I certainly hope that, in the second part of the negotiations, we will succeed in ensuring that your country is required to apply European regulations to your offshore territories in order to have access to the single market.(The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Thomas MANN
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mrs Joly, we both had the opportunity to work on a report on money laundering.My question is the following: Are you in favor of us having the black list with names, including European countries?Second, is it not absolutely important to follow the proposal made by Jean-Claude Juncker, who said that this terrible unanimity of taxation among the Member States must be changed.How do you feel about it?

name: Eva JOLY
text: "blue card" response.- Obviously, I will vote for the amendment which proposes to cite tax havens within the Union.This is very important and I thank Peter Simon for tabling this amendment.We have to go beyond unanimity in the Council, which is a very outdated provision.I take note of the promise that Jean-Claude Juncker made to us to use Article 116. It is therefore a hope and I would like the members of this assembly not to weaken our recommendations in this direction.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: - Tax evasion is a criminal offense, tax avoidance is not. In principle, everyone has the right to pay as little tax as possible as long as they stay within the boundaries of the law. The crux of the problem is that while every individual and every company has the same rights, they don't have the same capabilities. An SME in West Flanders simply cannot afford the services of Appleby. This is what I call class taxation. The Panama Papers and afterwards also the Paradise Papers revealed the extent of this. Now we have to make the political choice for tax justice and we have to do it together. The recommendations submitted by the PANA committee are necessary, but as long as the member states do not follow the logic of fair taxation, it will continue to fight with one arm. The statutory auditor also mentioned it in his introduction. The Commission and especially the Council must participate in the bath. As a government, it is important to establish a legal framework without legal loopholes and with transparency as the main guiding principle. But a government must also know its limitations. We win nothing with a manhunt. Nor, by the way, with a political joust between member states. Colleagues, our reputation as a European Parliament is at stake here. I therefore call on everyone to be aware of the impact that our recommendations will have. We must be ambitious, but we must not lose ourselves in unrealistic, populist proposals. Member States must be convinced and not set against each other. If we fail to do this, the Member States will continue to blindly follow the logic of multinationals and they will ultimately be the winners.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as you well know, the issues of fiscal policy have become central in the discussion of the European Parliament and institutions, especially due to the scandals, unfortunately - first "LuxLeaks" and now "Panama Papers" - for this reason we need ambitious and effective actions to counter the phenomenon of tax evasion as well as that of avoidance. So we need to introduce mechanisms that effectively protect the whistleblowers who have allowed us to know the state of things, we must prohibit the creation of front companies, we must introduce stricter criteria and effective sanctions in the definition of European lists, and we must define a quota minimum tax rate in the European Union for all businesses. However, I believe that the most important things are, on the one hand, explicitly indicating which European countries are to be put on the black list, that is, those that practice and favor processes of evasion and avoidance of the businesses resident there. But even more, the negative consequences of the unanimity rule must be overcome through the use of Article 116: it is not possible to leave a country with the right of veto over tax policies.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: - Mr President! I would first like to thank Mr Langen for chairing the committee and the other colleagues for their work, although I cannot agree with all the points in the recommendations. In our committee work, we have seen how difficult it is for financial intelligence services that collect this information and financial market supervisors to work together, not only across borders but also at other times within the same country. Therefore, in my opinion, the key is not to build new institutions, but to ensure the exchange of this financial information and information from financial market supervisors. But during the Panama Committee, we also saw how diverse and different the understanding of political ethics, the legislation governing conflicts of interest in the various Member States of the European Union, and also tax legislation, and we met ministers - government ministers who were great experts on trust companies. issues. At the same time, we met Members who still work as tax advisers and legislate in their spare time, and then it is no wonder that blatant crimes such as the murder of journalists are taking place in these countries. Dirty money does not bring happiness. It is followed by dirty people with their unethics. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Do you think with all these rules and regulations that are being brought in by the European Union on the back of this report that business is going to flood into the UK immediately after Brexit because people want to put their money where they feel it is safe and is not going to be plundered by a lot of left-wing individuals who just want to destroy businesses and create a Communist super state?

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: blue-card answer. – The short answer is no.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: - Mr. president. I think we have a good report. I regret the amendments tabled and the partial votes by the liberals and the popular and I would like to make a specific request to those popular and liberal deputies who do believe in tax justice: that, please, support us tomorrow to have a good report. And I am convinced that there will be many Members who will not vote in favor of the official amendments tabled by their group or groups, and I hope so. Furthermore, we need a very strong report - which we have - because we know that we have a problem in the Council. And a risk of this legislature is that after all the work done, all the questions will be blocked in the Council. And we currently have the Directive on fiscal transparency, the common corporate tax base, the black list, which has obviously left us a bitter aftertaste, because it has many limitations, practically non-existent sanctions, it does not mention European tax havens. There is a battle to be fought in the Council, and this Parliament must produce a very ambitious text tomorrow. And I also join the request to the European Commission to use Article 116 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union to make tax proposals in codecision and to get out of this unacceptable blockade of the Member States.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: From now on, for time reasons, no blue cards will be accepted.

name: Markus FERBER
text: - Mister President! The review of the Panama Papers has essentially revealed two things for me. First: In the fight against tax avoidance and tax evasion, we of course need international cooperation. But that is only possible if we also build up the appropriate pressure to work together. And secondly: We have to make it clear that we also have legal areas within the European Union where tax-saving models and tax structuring options are available. I would have been pleased if the Social Democrats had already approved my motion in committee and not now promoting theirs. The fact that it has not been possible to include legal areas of the European Union in the black list that the finance ministers have decided shows how little developed the sensitivities are here. And second: Those who made it onto the list - these 17 unfortunate states - don't even have to expect sanctions. I believe that we as Europeans should be a little stronger here in order to contribute to the fact that money laundering strongholds are dried up.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: - Mister President!The international journalist consortium has shed light on money laundering, fraud, the most aggressive tax avoidance, hiding money from the rich and multinationals, with the help of henchmen like Mossack Fonseca.We in the European Parliament, we Social Democrats, are on the bright side of legislation.I see the Commission is too.Above all, now is the time for the Member States to stop hiding.It is about the implementation and further development of the money laundering directive.It is about public reporting by country.It's about the famous list of tax sumps: EU countries also belong on it.It's about finally banning letterbox companies.It's about defining the digital permanent establishment.There is a lot to be done.Incidentally, I therefore believe that unanimity in the Council on tax issues should be abolished.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, tax havens harm the poorest, burden taxpayers, damage competition, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, undermine and also undermine economic growth and our social model. The journalists, we thank them, joined in several consortia, denounced and gave visibility to a problem that, in order to be effectively tackled, it also needs a new consortium, on a global scale, that of governments, but also demands from us what we can do now from the European Union. It is not necessary to standardize rates, but we can standardize the tax base, at least, the concepts and definitions. Right from the start, we should have a common and rigorous definition of a tax haven in the European Union. The proposals we have are also simple: the existence of a tax identification number for the European Union, the automatic exchange of information between tax authorities, the introduction of a common consolidated tax base, the control of resident companies and the penalization of companies that do not comply with the legislation.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: - Mr President, the masks are finally falling. The first step was last Tuesday, when the Member States approved a completely distorted list of tax havens: no sanction, no EU Member States concerned, no precise monitoring mechanism for Switzerland, Jersey or the Cayman Islands, for example. The United States, meanwhile, is not even mentioned. The second stage is taking place before our eyes. We see a right wing wanting to greatly weaken a text that contains, finally, substantial proposals to fight against the scourge of money laundering and tax evasion. The third step, finally, is the attitude of certain member states in domestic politics, starting with my own country, Belgium, whose right-wing federal government is dragging its feet to concretely apply several anti-money laundering provisions relating to beneficial owners. So in truth there is a deep hypocrisy among the Conservatives between the indignation that follows each leak and the weakness of the actions taken. So I hope that everyone will vote for all the elements of this text, otherwise those who vote against will be responsible for the next tax scandal.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, democracy is a regime of public opinion. Therefore, it is inexcusable to congratulate the consortium of journalists who bravely denounced the tremendous scandal that has given rise to the work of the PANA Commission. In my opinion, a common definition of tax haven is a priority. And it should also be noted that, although some Member States do not appear on the black list, it is not tolerable that some behave as tax havens. We must distinguish between tax evasion and tax avoidance. Evasion is always punishable and its pursuit must be relentless. Tax avoidance may be legal, but it is unethical. Laws must be prevented from allowing tax avoidance. There are laws that are not ethical, and, therefore, they must be modified to prevent the existence of privileged areas that, even complying with the laws, can avoid moral and social commitments. Finally, I would like to remind you that the role of the European Union is to promote the reform of the laws of the member states so that their jurisdictions are competent to judge not by the place where the illicit act takes place, but by who promotes it, and thus to be able to rule against the offender.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: - Mr. president. I dare say, ladies and gentlemen, that this is one of the most important reports that this Parliament is going to adopt in this legislature. And I join those who ask the right not to dilute the content of this report, the strength of these proposals. I believe that we are facing a gigantic financial machine in general, all over the world, to evade taxes. And tax evasion provokes social alarm, in large part because it is lethal to the welfare state. There will be, in my opinion, three main lines of struggle in this long march for tax justice. The first is the fight against paradises. It is an idea that has begun to take shape, the European Union is already making the list. It's not perfect — I know — but it's a list that no one in the world has made. And it is the first step. The second is the fight against fiscal opacity, bank secrecy, and intermediaries. I believe that this is key in this long march that we are wanting to carry out. And the third is international collaboration. We are facing an international issue that requires the effort of all of us.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen!Europe is losing thousands of billion euros to tax havens and tax evasion.Something can be wrong there!It is hair-raising what we discover every day in every new investigation, in every new committee of a lack of political will, a lack of sanctioning mechanisms, instruments and tax loopholes.The biggest problem is not just outside the European Union, the problem begins in the middle of the European Union: the lack of European and international cooperation, the disagreement and selfishness of some Member States and the lack of a common European tax policy.Because there is not enough Europe, we have too many tax havens and too few options.I want taxation where the added value takes place, disclosure of all Member States that do not obey the rules ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are two lessons to be learned from the work of this committee: the European Union cannot afford to give discounts on tax avoidance and evasion, and the battle at home is far from over. The Council must do its part. We have a black list now, but we are disappointed that there are no sanctions and that there are some excluded: our own tax havens, which incentivize aggressive tax planning practices, allowing multinationals to "zero point" rates; it is necessary to overcome unanimity on fiscal issues and approve the instruments that are needed, first of all the reporting state by state, on which this Chamber has already expressed itself. Finally, the work of the commission has finally made it clear that the phenomena of avoidance and evasion are global, and it is on a global level that the necessary solutions must be adopted. Developing countries pay the highest price: we want impact assessments of European tax policies on developing countries and that the Union pushes for a true intergovernmental body at the UN level that rewrites global tax rules under conditions of parity with all countries.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: - Mr President, we are unequivocally in favor of combating tax evasion, tax evasion and money laundering. But no one has the legitimacy, in the name of fighting tax illegality, to level the tax competition in the European Union, to level the ability of member states to pursue and determine their own tax policy, which is their sovereign right and one of the key elements. free economy, unless we want to return the European Union to free, closed, centralized economies. We ourselves can not try to put the European Union out of financial assets; it can not attract business; it can not attract investment but at the same time impose high tax rates, which will kill small and medium-sized enterprises. We say "yes" to fair tax competition, "no" to unfair tax competition. But, Commissioner, I think it was inappropriate for you to raise the issue of the majority with regard to tax policy decisions. There are other non-serious issues and lower issues… (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - Arms trade, terrorism, drugs, corruption, tax evasion, enrichment of multinationals.This is what we are talking about today when we talk about distorting the origin of money and property, tax evasion, tax evasion.Something illegal, something unethical, and certainly all this is eating away at the structure of both the European Union and the world as a whole.As we have heard, in one year in the European Union, as many taxes are lost as our seven-year budget.That is to say, this is a serious fiscal problem, which is why we do not have the development we would like, and above all we do not have a quality life for those people who also live from paying taxes.We do not have a quality social system, we do not have a good education system, a health care system, so it is essential that the measures are clear, decisive and that we do not want to look through our fingers, even if they are on the issue of EU member states.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the committee of inquiry set up after the "Panama Papers" is an important manifestation of the commitment made by the European institutions to eradicate the scourge of illicit finance in the single market. The result we have achieved with the updating of the black list of tax havens is certainly partial and much remains to be done. But it is certainly a fundamental step towards strengthening transparency and accountability in the financial system. Our duty is to give a concrete follow-up to the precious investigative activity carried out in recent years by journalists and NGOs, revealing a disturbing underground fact of corruption, fraud, conflicts of interest, tax evasion and dangerous infiltration of organized crime in the market, and that among other things it cost the life of Daphne Caruana Galizia. Freedom of information must be protected with a strong sense of responsibility and morality, and we must always bear in mind that the steps forward that Europe takes towards real financial transparency do not only concern the market or banks, but first of all democracy and citizens.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, the blow to tax evasion and avoidance in the European Union lies with the Council. That is the key. Serious decisions have to be made there and there are Member States which not only do not want specific decisions to be taken but also hinder decisions. So we have aggressive tax planning, which is essentially the second nature of the European Union, because the European Union itself wants gray areas. It essentially wants to create this unfair tax competition between Member States. So I think that's the key. Decisions must be taken with the following in mind: multinationals and anyone making a profit in the European Union should be taxed in that Member State. Where profits come from, they must be taxed. If this basic principle is passed, then we start very well.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Madam President, we live in a world where the percentage of the wealthiest owns half of the world's wealth. Ten percent of the richest even own eighty-nine percent, and paying taxes, however, is probably against social bonmot, and so the economic scissors between the richest and the rest of us continue to widen. Ninety-nine percent of the population experienced cuts during the economic crisis, and one percent enjoyed tax havens. This is what is destroying the world and the hope of a just society. I consider the fight against tax havens to be absolutely principled and absolutely necessary for the socio-economic stability of the state. Laws and rules are meant to protect the most vulnerable, not just the richest. I refuse to get used to the fact that the powerful and the rich simply refuse to pay taxes and thus rob the society that helped them to wealth. We have to stop after every escape, just to show our horror and really start doing something. This report may be a start, but we need to take it to very concrete steps.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
