text: - Madam President, money laundering is an old practice that has flourished in recent years. The bad thing in this case is that the corruption that results from both the Paradise Papers and the Panama Papers but also from other scandals of the past has been revealed by journalists and not by the competent state authorities. This proves the weakness but also the reluctance of the states to fight the illegalities. Of course, every country needs a fair tax system and not like the one imposed by international moneylenders in Greece, mainly in the Greek islands, which pushes citizens to tax exemption and tax avoidance. Of course, cooperation, transparency and control are required. But none of this is going to happen, because those politicians who have to make the right decisions are funded either by multinational corporations or by other invisible financiers with dark intentions. But all these weaknesses should by no means be a pretext for abolishing the principle of unanimity, as suggested by Commissioner Moscovici. This will destroy the unity of Europe.

name: Romana TOMC
text: - We can be satisfied with the work of the PANA Committee, which is, of course, thanks in particular to Mr President Langen and the two rapporteurs.However, we did a lot of work together, we also pointed to many very concrete cases of tax evasion and money laundering, including money laundering in the largest Slovenian state bank.Of course, our powers are limited.We cannot act where countries should act.This is their job and we have no executive power.However, taking action in these cases, when it comes to tax evasion, when it comes to money laundering by individual countries, also shows how seriously countries are prepared to face and tackle this problem.Some do nothing at all, so of course I also support the amendment proposed in this direction, that the competent authorities and countries must take action as soon as they detect suspicions of irregularities.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: - Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the fight against tax evasion and money laundering must be in the common interest of all the Member States of the European Union. However, the mutual exchange of information, but also the willingness to cooperate in this area, has great gaps, as we can see. The inaction of the competent institutions at national but also at European level, as we always respond to some new published information, data and scandals, all this causes a great deal of disappointment among citizens. And especially for those entrepreneurs who pay their taxes honestly. We must be honest and admit that not only mailboxes or VAT fraud, which cost up to billions of euros, but also various forms of tax relief for various forms of business, as we see in Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Cyprus, Ireland and others, for example. countries, do not contribute to good and, in particular, fair practices in the European Union. A particular problem is the mailbox companies, which participate directly in money from the European Union budget and in various projects that the European Union offers to improve the environment in its Member States.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, the EU is making great efforts to identify and sanction entities involved in money laundering and tax evasion. This is the right path because everyone has to give their financial contribution to society in order for it to prosper. In several places, the lack of resources that bothers the Commission, but also the competent national authorities, has been highlighted. Let's be realistic, an effective fight against money laundering and tax evasion requires large financial resources. The irony is that a significant part of the funds spent on such operations comes from the taxation of small and medium-sized enterprises and citizens, ie those who, even if they want to, cannot afford to hide money in tax havens. The big ones are hiding money, and we are additionally burdening the small ones to prevent them from doing so. That is why I believe that, in addition to improving the methods of combating money laundering and evasion, we need to work seriously on tax policy. In addition to prevention and punishment, a very important factor in this fight is the demotivation achieved by stimulating policies that reward reinvestment, employment and growth.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Madam President, almost all of us in here are against tax evasion and avoidance. But I think, ladies and gentlemen, that we are not all honest and you will see it in the polls when we see what the colleagues of the European People's Party will vote for. There, when we go to the time of decisions, the thing takes another turn. It has been said and it is very true that another tax evasion and another tax evasion. Tax evasion is legal. This is where the European Parliament must act, so that this thing is abolished or the restrictions of the law are introduced. There is a third issue: The billions lost through tax evasion and avoidance - one would rightly say - would go into the economy, but beyond that there are the trillions that are parked in tax havens and that could also go to the European economy and to be more properly allocated to the social rights of citizens. I close with the following phrase: to fight tax evasion and avoidance, but we must also take into account the specificities of the Member States' financial industries.

name: Milan ZVER
text: - I would like to emphasize that ... I would first like to congratulate all the members of the PANAMA Committee for a job well done, the report is excellent, there are many recommendations that can have a good impact on regulating this problem, both in Europe and in the Member States.In particular, I would like to say the following: in all the Member States, the democratic public, which is fighting for the rule of law, is not strong enough to successfully deal with the financial mafia that rules in some places.The latest example of a major affair already mentioned in the hall, the NLB Irangate, where more than a billion dirty Iranian money was laundered for suspiciously dangerous purposes, is already one such.That is why we need a strong European Union and effective institutions that will not only point the finger at mistakes, but also take action.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - I do not think anyone would argue: we are facing systemic problems with the use of different techniques of tax evasion. It is clear that transnational businesses or people with huge fortunes are successfully evading their tax obligations, causing outrage on the part of citizens and shaking their faith in the fairness of sharing the burden. We cannot pretend not to see: some countries and state institutions are accomplices and financial beneficiaries of these mechanisms, which poison our societies and also discredit governments, institutions, political movements. Solving the problem requires a complex set of legislative, enforcement, regulatory, control and sanctioning procedures. It is a question of whether we are taking these steps now or when the phenomenon is causing even greater damage. This is because the rule of law requires not only the observance of the law, but also the enforcement of social justice. And if current politicians are unable to do so, citizens will look for new ones instead.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: member of the Commission. - Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, I thank all parliamentarians, on all benches, because I note all the same, beyond the normal, legitimate differences, a common desire to fight against escape tax, tax evasion and tax optimization. Since the start of this mandate, you have known that this is also a high priority for this Commission, and it is certainly mine. Together, we have done - this is undoubtedly due to a context, but it is also due to a will - more in three years than in the previous twenty years on this front, thanks to the journalists - to whom I pay tribute - , thanks to whistleblowers - whose role I recognize - thanks to Parliament, thanks to your work, and I also hope a little thanks to the Commission. What are the successes that we have already achieved over the past three years? Let’s not neglect them, don’t make it seem like we’re starting from a clean slate every time, because it has a bit of a discouraging side. The automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts, and thus the end of banking secrecy, is still a real revolution for a whole generation or generations. The country-by-country declaration for business is not yet public and I call again on the Council to move in that direction, but it does exist. The two directives for the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion which will, little by little, prohibit a whole series of reprehensible mechanisms, some of which - it's a bit of an optical illusion - are already a thing of the past, while their effects are revealed. I welcome the adoption in Council last week of the VAT proposal for e-commerce, which will also reduce fraud. So you can see that we are moving forward. We advance, sometimes with big steps, sometimes with smaller steps, but we advance. Can we be satisfied with this first assessment? By definition, no. We must continue, we must go further, we must never release the pressure, we must continue to supply proposals. You know that, for my part, I will not let go and that the Commission will be active on this front until the last day of its mandate, I assure you. European citizens are asking us to do so. More than that, they demand it. Each of us - and this goes for the Member States first - will be held to account on this front. I say it clearly, we must not wait for the next scandal to act. The Commission is assuming its responsibilities. In this sense, we have relaunched the project for a European corporate tax base. I am saying here that this reform, which is not just an anti-fraud reform, which is the definition of business taxation for the 21st century, is the mother of all reforms. I will not be able to finish this term satisfied with my work as Tax Commissioner if we do not succeed. You are right, we must speed up and I call on the Council to speed up and conclude this file before the end of this year 2018 which is about to begin. We must therefore put into practice a simple principle according to which companies must pay their taxes where they generate their profits. You know that the fact of having a common consolidated base - and I insist on the term “consolidated” - precisely makes it possible to avoid the transfer of profits, which is an absolutely massive source of fraud, that is what is true. tax justice in action. The Commission will also make proposals for fairer taxation of digital businesses which, by their very nature and the archaism of our tax systems, largely escape corporate taxation. It is not acceptable that the effective tax rate for digital businesses is more than half the rate for traditional businesses. There is something there that is a distortion. Preparing for the future also means adapting our tax system to adapt it to these new realities. I wanted to assure you of the will of the Commission to move forward in this direction. I would like to respond to some of the very many questions raised by members. I'll start with the blacklist. I want to be clear on this point: this blacklist is not the Commission's list, it is the Member States' list, it is the Council's. The Member States and the Council have chosen a modality which is to go through the code of conduct, to have an intergovernmental development method. Well, that’s their responsibility and it’s the finance ministers who have to justify it. I see my name, every time it would be the Moscovici list. No, this is not the list I proposed. What I proposed was that there be a list, but it was the Council that made its list, with its strengths and weaknesses. Having said that, I still want to say one thing to this Parliament - which I know well, I have been a member of it -: sometimes the best is the enemy of the good. This list, undoubtedly, is progress, first of all because it exists - it is the first in the history of the European Union -; secondly, because the process of screening, of dialogue with the Member States was carried out in a serious manner; finally, because these results are not negligible: 17 countries on the black list and 47 on the gray list. What is important to me is that, is that the very process of listing, of listing, has led a lot of countries to make commitments. So I put it that way, I think that discrediting this list, seeing it as harmless, null and void, unnecessary, is not a good process. If we do so, we will discourage this still incomplete goodwill, whereas we must, on the contrary, go further. Yes, this list is progress, limited progress, incomplete progress, but undeniable progress. How to ensure to complete it? First, be extremely serious about the commitments. It’s the heart for me. Second, to forcefully call on the Member States to put in place sanctions, and real sanctions, and then be able to initiate a process. This is not a photo, this is not a discharge. Behind that, we will have to bring this process to life. So, there is a big question that is asked, I saw that there was an amendment that had been tabled, on which I will refrain from expressing myself, whether or not there are tax havens in the European Union. If we look at the criteria that were taken at the start, if we do a systemic analysis, if we compare ourselves to others, I think this point is questionable. I said it. Moreover, I think, here again, that putting such and such a country on the list of tax havens would be a little discouraging or encouraging them not to pursue the efforts they have already made, and I do not want them to do so. name, but the automatic exchange of information, it exists, the application of BEPS, it exists. There is no country in the European Union that has a zero tax rate. That said, there are very serious problems and very serious shortcomings in a number of countries in the European Union, and if Parliament considers that this justifies listing them as tax havens, it is your right to do it. For my part, I tried to explain what the process was. This is what I want to stress, not just on the lists, but on the tax systems of the Member States, because that is the problem. It is the fact that some of these tax systems are favorable, it is true, to practices that we condemn. The fiscal transparency agenda is also being built and implemented within the European Union. It is the implementation of BEPS measures - I spoke about it - it is the convergence in tax matters, which must remain an objective. There, I urge parliamentarians, but also citizens, to hold their governments to account, to denounce those who refuse to move forward on the path of transparency. It is true that there are still marked differences, cautions, and that, when the media fires again, when there is no more scandal, I myself see a return to this kind of human and political nature which so that, suddenly, the natural returns to the gallop and shyness is required again. For my part, I will continue to call on Member States to work on changing their tax rules, those that remain favorable to aggressive tax planning and optimization, to adopt real sanctions - I really believe that it must be. a very operational conclusion for all of our work - and I also hope that - I have heard contrasting points of view on this - we move towards the end of the unanimity rule. The Commission will publish a communication on this at the beginning of 2018. Finally, I hear the calls to use Article 116 and I undertake to move forward on this path by the end of the mandate, with, all the same, a finality. , which is not to misuse it. We have a tool called "enhanced cooperation", which has never been used conclusively. I would like, if we use section 116, we do it in a positive way. Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, once again thank you for your involvement and your determination. You are going to vote tomorrow on the amendments and the final report of your committee and, in the role which is mine, I invite you to maintain the highest level of ambition. The Commission has already answered and will continue to answer, to answer your calls and I will spare no effort. Let me say it again: together, let us not lower our guard against tax evasion and opacity. We have already won battles. The war, it is far from being won and therefore, as we used to say in my youth, let’s continue the fight.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I appreciate the debate and the contribution and the overall approach by Commissioner Moscovici. When it comes to the report itself, I want it to be based primarily on the findings of our investigations. We have a committee of inquiry, not the committee of impressions or prejudices. Therefore, my Group does not support the paragraphs which either go against the compromises we have reached, those that are entirely out of the scope of our investigation, or those which would give some unworkable recommendations. The vote on those amendments was not fully representative of the balance of the committee. We would have liked to streamline the report for the plenary and make strong and credible recommendations. It is more or less the same as what we have done with the draft report and compromises, which were supported by a broad majority. Finally, I would like to call on the Commission and especially on the Member States to take our recommendations seriously and to follow up on our proposals. Our citizens expect us to deliver on tax justice.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, thank you so much to my colleagues for this very important and good debate. I also appreciate the strong support for the report and recommendations and I want to thank Commissioner Moscovici for the great work the Commission is doing in this field and also – in his words – ‘to end the culture of secrecy’ and, I would say, obstruction in the field of taxation and avoidance and to create a culture of transparency and sincere corporation in this field between Parliament and Commission and hopefully also, in the future, with the Council.  The Council needs to open up, it needs to be accountable to the citizens, to the public in Europe and we need to discuss this in the open. When countries block progress, they need to be named and shamed. We need to have an open and sincere debate. That is what the citizens of Europe deserve in such a serious matter as tax avoidance and taxation. I also would like to thank the EPP Group. I heard Mr Rosati saying that we had a very strong and good report. I want to urge all of my colleagues to keep it that way because tomorrow we are going to vote and, as some have noticed, there are a lot of split votes unfortunately, but I just appeal to Parliament for us to have a strong and good report, as Mr Rosati said and others said. Do not water down the strong recommendations we have.  It is time now to stand up for the citizens of Europe. I also urge the citizens and the media to look into each and every vote tomorrow and see who is on the side of citizens in this very important fight. We have to win that fight. This Parliament must take a brave stand with this report. We are not going to end with this report. We also call, from the S&D Group, for a special committee to be set up until the end of the term to investigate, to further follow up on all of these 211 recommendations, because there is a lot of work to do. We have made progress and will continue to make progress, but we can only do that if we have a strong vote tomorrow.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: in writing. - The European Parliament's committee of inquiry, which has been investigating the Panama Papers for one year, has delivered a shocking verdict. The lack of political will in some EU Member States has made it possible to circumvent tax laws. The Commission is making heavy accusations against European governments who have been involved in black money laundering and tax evasion for over 20 years. MEPs agree that the European Union as a whole must play a vital role in the global fight against money laundering and tax evasion. However, you should be realistic about the problem. The effect of the Commission's work so far in the form of final reports, which I cannot support due to some provisions, may be questionable. It is about repeated provisions on the harmonization of tax law, the introduction of a common, consolidated tax base, and the abolition of the unanimity rule in the Council. In my opinion, this would violate Poland's tax sovereignty. I am therefore abstaining from voting.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: in writing. - It has become clear from the Panama Papers that the world’s financial and political elite is trying to hide a significant portion of its assets from the public through various offshore companies and countries. Since then, countless similar cases have been made public: the Paradise Papers, the Azerbaijani money laundering, which are based on the same logic: to hide assets of dubious origin through a complicated web of companies, income so that there is no need to account and no tax to pay. Meanwhile, there are, in principle, strict anti-money laundering rules within the Union, and both banks and banking supervisors have strict control systems. Unfortunately, EU legislation does not cover all loopholes, but transposition into national law and even implementation and enforcement are not carried out properly. Basically because the web of corruption and financial interests is interweaving the world of economics and politics, taking advantage of the incoherence of the legal background. To increase efficiency, the EU would have to make a number of decisions that would tighten the rules. Among other things, it should prohibit commercial relations with legal arrangements established in tax havens if the final beneficiary cannot be identified. With regard to corporate networks, publicity must be increased and guaranteed. EU funds should not be paid to companies suspected of tax evasion, and companies from offshore backgrounds should be banned from participating in public procurement.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: signed up.- After several postponements, the European Commission has fulfilled its commitment to publish the list of tax havens that do not cooperate on the prevention of money laundering and tax evasion.It required objectivity and in-depth analysis.What is questionable, however, is the much longer list of those tax havens and other tax jurisdictions that are on a different list, namely those tax havens that have pledged to take the necessary steps to become fully cooperative..Here we need rigorous monitoring of these tax havens so that, if they do not fulfill their commitments, they will be blacklisted for non-cooperation.We are now awaiting Commission proposals for the sanctions that Member States must apply to uncooperative tax havens.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing. - Money laundering involves the illegal concealment of money, including through the use of international criminal networks to disguise the nature of the illicit proceeds in order to appear to have been obtained legally. In 2016, Parliament set up a Committee of Inquiry into allegations of breaches of Union law and maladministration in the application of Union law in cases of money laundering. His conclusions are shocking. The leaks in Panama’s documents include confidential data from 213,634 overseas companies, along with the names of twelve current and former heads of state, nearly 200 politicians from around the world and many celebrities from various fields. In most cases, no investigations were carried out to identify the main beneficial owners of the entities or such investigations were incomplete. The consequence of this is that it is not possible to identify the owner of the entity and the structure that controls it, or the information obtained about the purpose and intended nature of the business relationship. That needs to change. Profits should be taxed at the place of receipt. The current Union legislation is inadequate, which has led to the actions and financial structures revealed in the Panama Papers. There is an urgent need for a common EU approach to combating front companies in third countries, overseas countries and territories and the outermost regions, in order to put an end to practices that avoid paying a fair share of taxes in the EU.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next order of the day is the debate on the report by Udo Bullmann and José Manuel Fernandes, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the extension of the life of the European Fundfor strategic investments (COM (2016) 0597 - C8-0375 / 2016 - 2016/0276 (COD)) (A8-0198 / 2017).

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! When EFSI, the Fund for Strategic Investments in Europe, launched in 2015, the Commission let us know that it put the annual investment needs, the investment gap, at EUR 700 billion. Today the European Investment Bank tells us: With the new fund, we have succeeded in narrowing this gap by 100 billion euros. What does that show us? First: the fund is useful, it helps. But secondly: it is nowhere near enough to meet the additional investment needs in the European Union. That is why we need the combined efforts in the Member States, and we will, ladies and gentlemen, need a Commission proposal for a comprehensive investment strategy. That is what our report also calls for and what we expect the Commission to present it. Nevertheless, let me say today: I am filled with joy and pride in what we have achieved together. Yes, there were voices that wanted to give us the advice, just let it go. The money is called, it fits. Yes, quantitatively, the first stage, the first two years, was already successful. But the European Parliament wanted the fund to get better, to become more modern and to reach the regions where the need for investment is greatest. I would like to thank José Manuel Fernandes, my co-rapporteur, and all the rapporteurs, shadow rapporteurs, the committee chairmen, their teams, the many, many helping hands in the background who have made it possible for us to have a very good report today, a very good one good extension of this strategic investment fund until 2020. Because the 91% support that we got in the two committees is proof that they worked hard and that the Colleagues behind this modern investment instrument. What was achieved: additionality? No, in addition, a project is no longer only considered if the European Investment Bank has calculated that it is particularly risky. It's a math formula that doesn't really help us. We want at least 40% of the initiatives to contribute to the fight against climate change. We are obliged to do this, and that will be the great new task. The cooperation with the regional and national development banks will improve because it will benefit the small and medium-sized enterprises that we particularly need in this struggle for prosperity and modernization, for our industry, for our commercial operations in modern times. The system becomes more transparent and the allocation of funds becomes more clearly understandable. Yes, we have created a fixed system of indicators that objectively assess which are the best projects and which projects should be particularly supported. Business as usual is no longer possible, not even within the European Investment Bank. Ultimately, we will send an independent expert to the steering committee who will improve transparency and cooperation. All of this will move us forward. I am looking forward to a refreshing discussion here in plenary, to a good vote and then to an active, really modern fund for the next few years up to 2020.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: reporter. - Madam President, I would like to congratulate the Commissioner and Vice-President of the Commission, all colleagues, all colleagues, to thank and thank my correlator Udo Bullmann for the excellent cooperation, for the loyalty, for the results we have obtained, for the committee chairs, chairman of the Committee on Economic Affairs, Roberto Gualtieri, and also to the chairman of the Committee on Budgets, Jean Arthuis, to all political groups and their shadow rapporteurs, a special word for Othmar Karas who also made an essential contribution to economic issues. The European Fund for Strategic Investments is a very important fund that has helped to mobilize investment, reduce inequalities and also create jobs. More than 250 billion euros have already been mobilized and more than 400 thousand small and medium-sized companies have been supported. Its success is impressive, which does not mean that the ambition does not continue to improve geographic distribution, and that is why we have strengthened the Advisory Hub, which is an investment advisory platform so that territories that have more difficulties can be supported . I remind you that this investment advice platform is free for public entities. Small and medium-sized companies only pay a third of the cost and we have reinforced the proactivity of Advisory Hub, of this investor advisory platform. In addition, we have also broadened the scope of the Fund: the forest, the social area and social services, agriculture, fisheries are also clearly present in this European Fund for Strategic Investments, which is an additional fund. And here additionality has also been reinforced: an additionality where nothing is automatic and where the impact in terms of employment, in terms of investment in the place, has to be seen, taking into account reality. Less favored regions tend to be more supported. This is not a fund for territorial cohesion, but it is a fund that should help territorial cohesion and it is a fund that does not replace the cohesion policy, but it also requires complementarity with the funds that we have, namely the Structural Funds. Small projects are cherished, this is also extremely important, and hence the work we did in this area. Investment platforms remain a gamble, but the role of financial development institutions is also strengthened and, here, I call attention to the fact that Member States strengthen their financial institutions for development, their development banks, and those who do not have them must create them because the financial instruments will be here to last. It is also extremely important the greater involvement that Parliament has. We also have a European Fund for Strategic Investments, also known as the Juncker Plan, which has the Parliament most involved. There is also a greater presence, at the bottom, of Parliament in this Juncker plan, in this investment plan. I would like to reinforce my thanks, ending with a thank you to the Commission that was creative in a series of solutions, namely in terms of financing, and hence this final thanks to the European Commission.

name: Eva KAILI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Madam President, the conclusion of the trilogues on EFSI showed that all parties had strong incentives to improve it by correcting its inefficiencies, namely the concentration of the funds to economies and sectors that needed it less. So I want to congratulate the success of the co-rapporteurs, Udo Bullmann and José Manuel Fernandes, for their efforts to achieve significant improvements.  On behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE), our main concerns regarding the expansion of eligible sectors in the digital economy, the funding of SMEs, extension of SMEs window, the blending of EFSI and ESIF funds, and environmental considerations were properly addressed this time. However, one point I would like to highlight, which is important for the ITRE Committee and which remains unresolved despite our efforts to emphasise it, is that the requirement of delinking the EFSI guarantee from the Member States’ macroeconomic requirements under the Stability and Growth Pact.  There is also a straightforward message: reductionary fiscal policy kills the demand for lendable funds, and the EFSI is a supply side instrument. Now we know that supply cannot create its own demand, so it sends a clear message to policymakers regarding the limits of supply side financial instruments as long as the demand is weak. No significant improvements will reach the real economy. Our new challenge should be exactly this: how will an EFSI3 programme in the future manage to boost demand and produce ... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. - Madam President, we Socialists have welcomed this investment plan from the beginning to boost the economy and employment through investments that, by themselves, the Member States - even those in excessive surpluses - did not undertake. But soon we began, anyway, to lose some of the initial enthusiasm when verifying that the funds for the guarantee were going to entail important and paradoxical cuts in programs such as the MEC, which were already investments of great European added value. However, the criticisms, the debate we have had, the monitoring of the projects, some good and others bad, have led us to reduce the cuts in the EQF in this new EFSI, "EFSI 2". almost in half through the use of margins and part of the EFSI profits - because it gives profits. It has been possible to resize the size and the hunger - let's say - of the bank guarantee and, finally, it has been recognized that the European road infrastructures also deserve investments - if we think above all about electric cars, trucks and buses already running LNG—, that it is necessary to equip them with infrastructures for alternative energies and that require maintenance. Thank you, then, Mr. Katainen.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Vice-president of the Commission. – Madam President, this is a great day for all of us who have participated in the EFSI project, but also and especially for those who will benefit from additional investment in our Member States and regions. I want to thank the rapporteurs, Udo Bullmann and José Manuel Fernandes for their great cooperation and also all the chairs who run our trilogues very smoothly and skilfully, like Mr Gualtieri and Mr Sarvamaa, and other MEPs who participated in this effort. Let me take stock of the investment plan’s achievements before I turn to the changes under EFSI 2.0. Up to now, EFSI has managed to trigger additional investment worth EUR 250 billion. In other terms, it will create new jobs and new financing opportunities for infrastructure, investments and SMEs. In addition to large infrastructure projects and industrial investments, some 530 000 European SMEs and mid-caps have already benefitted from EFSI financing. In other terms, according to the European Investment Bank, EFSI investments made up to now will increase European GDP by 0.67% by 2020 and this will increase the number of jobs by 690 000. This is only the result of EFSI investments up to now. The overall figure will be higher when EFSI expires later on. This is only the result of EFSI. This is not the result of the entire investment plan for Europe. There the third pillar in particular plays a role. Geographically, EFSI has also functioned very well. I will give you a list of the countries which are the five best users of EFSI and it looks quite good. Estonia is number one, Bulgaria is second, Greece third, Portugal fourth, and Spain fifth. Our idea was to address market failure and it seems to be functioning as we planned.  Let me give you some concrete examples of EFSI projects. In Poland the EIB is providing a loan of over EUR 30 million for the construction of 1 300 affordable houses for low-income earners. In Greece, the EIB is lending to a telecoms operator to roll out high-speed broadband, bringing better internet access to rural and remote areas of the country. In Finland, EFSI supports the first ever social impact points scheme in Europe. The scheme will support the integration of up to 3 700 migrants and refugees in the Finnish labour market through training and job matching assistance. In the Czech Republic, a start—up called Frusack received an EFSI—backed loan to scale up their reusable bags business. In Germany, the EIB is lending EUR 35 million to a medical device company to support the development of a new approach to treating the most aggressive type of brain cancer, and in Romania, EFSI is helping a recycling company called GreenFiber to broaden the scope of their business. Under EFSI 2.0, we ensure that all the projects continue to match the high expectations which we have set. This EFSI extension will increase the target of investment to be triggered to at least EUR 0.5 trillion by 2020. EFSI 2.0 comes with a number of enhancements as a result of the input and commitment of the co—legislators. Let me outline some of them. First, there is a more precise definition of ‘additionally’, and, second, investment decisions will be better explained and the scoreboard on which they are based will be published. This is a measure of transparency and also of increased accountability. Thirdly, technical assistance to project promoters at a local level will be strengthened so that even more regions and sectors can benefit from it. Finally, EFSI 2.0 will better focus on EU political priorities, such as climate change and environmental projects.  I would now like to focus on three areas where the Parliament’s constructive, but determined, pressure was key and take this opportunity to two rapporteurs, Udo Bullmann and José Manuel Fernandes. The first relates to the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Money Laundering, Tax Avoidance and Tax Evasion. Thanks to Parliament’s efforts, due diligence on European Investment Bank operations under this regulation will include a thorough check of compliance with EU and international standards on anti—money laundering, the fight against terrorism, financing and tax fraud, and on tax avoidance. The second area where the European Parliament has clearly left a footprint is increased transparency. Thanks to Parliament’s efforts, the scoreboard of indicators will be made public after the signature of each project and the investment committee will substantiate its decision on the granting of EU funding.  Finally, Parliament’s efforts are also clearly seen when it comes to support for small—scale projects. As Mr Fernandes rightly pointed out, what is perceived as small in some countries or regions is actually a large-scale project in others. Better use of platforms, a delegation model with national promotional banks and a reinforced advisory hub will help smaller projects to benefit from EFSI more than they have been doing so far. Before I conclude, I would like to highlight that much still remains to be done. EFSI plays a major role in catalysing private investment, but the impact of these funds would be enhanced by further addressing barriers to investment in Member States. I refer to the third pillar of the investment plan that is a joint European and national responsibility. Thank you very much for the great cooperation.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank my colleagues for the good agreement they have brought home, for their work which has achieved important results. The REGI commission had raised some issues with amendments which were substantially accepted, and for this we express our satisfaction. First of all, a better territorial distribution, greater involvement of regions and local authorities, support for regions in transition and those of cohesion, better use of national and regional platforms, as well as macro-regional and cross-border ones, control of the effective additionality of investments, also evaluating the criteria at regional and local level, and greater involvement of the regions and local authorities, in particular in those projects that see the convergence of EFSI and structural funds. For the future, we believe that it must become a permanent instrument for financing investments in Europe and that we must also take into account the regions that have ended up in the so-called middle income trap, for which there are really no major structural investments.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: author of the draft opinion of the Employment and Social Affairs Committee. - Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen! In more than two years of operation, the EFSI has proved that it has the potential to stimulate investment and stimulate growth and competitiveness. However, I think we need to highlight some points that need to be corrected. First of all, it is worrying that there is a significant disproportion in the use of funds between the so-called the old fifteen and the member states of Central and Eastern Europe. I believe that combining the EFSI with the Structural and Investment Funds can help achieve the desired results in terms of improving this situation. However, it should be emphasized that the cohesion policy as the main investment policy of the European Union has already brought proven results not only in terms of creating investments, but also supporting structural reforms, developing human capital and creating sustainable jobs. Therefore, care must be taken to ensure that the EFSI in the future financial perspective does not in any way replace or supersede other European Union funds and instruments and that their separateness is preserved.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, Commissioner. I obviously want to start by congratulating the rapporteurs for this report, Mr Bullmann and Mr Fernandes, because I think they have done a fantastic job and the groups and shadow rapporteurs have tried to help where possible. The investment plan has been in place for two and a half years. And I remember that when we made that assessment report for its first year of operation, we already detected some flaws, certain shortcomings. And that has been what we have tried to solve in this version 2.0 of the investment plan. The first one was the additionality criterion, and I believe that with the requirements that we have added we can achieve true additionality. Because if we use the European budget as a guarantee, it has to be to ensure that those projects that are going to benefit from the budget could never have been financed in any other way and, if not, we would be giving away public money. We have also talked about a better geographical distribution, and with cooperation with national investment banks and the elimination of obstacles to small projects - among other measures - I believe that we can greatly improve the implementation of the investment plan throughout the territory European and also in the sectorial part, because we had detected that some sectors were not benefiting sufficiently. And for this reason, with new specific criteria, we are going to place more emphasis on job creation, the fight against climate change, new technologies or sustainable transport and, finally, the budgetary part. And here we must recognize that the Commission, which we did not manage to hear us in the budgetary part in the first part of the investment plan, here has put much more appropriate financing on the table. In the first investment plan, we already asked the Commission to reduce the need to provide the guarantee and here in this second investment plan it has made a reduction and, therefore, with the same money we will be able to finance many more projects.!! Congratulations!!And hopefully now we have a real investment plan.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! With the EFSI, the EU is taking a big step towards state economic control, and that is fundamentally the wrong direction. We need free markets, we need a social market economy, but no state economic control. This is wrong. The EFSI also has birth defects: It wants to initiate additional investments, and nobody has yet been able to show me how they can really be measured seriously. Instead, it is always said that it is additional investments. In truth, however, we have to assume that we are dealing here with malfunctions and predatory competition. Because we have a zero interest rate policy in the EU, we have a glut of money, there is enough money to finance meaningful projects. You have to ask yourself: What do we actually want to achieve with the EFSI? I am convinced that there are many wonderful things in the shop windows that will not stand up to closer inspection and analysis. Therefore the EFSI is to be rejected.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, first of all congratulations to the two co-rapporteurs, Mr Bullmann and Mr Fernandes, for the quality of their work. The funding deal was an incredible obstacle course, the result of which I applaud. Unlike Mr Kölmel, I say that the Juncker Fund, even if it needs to be improved, is a good instrument. He pursues good goals and he gives good results. In my country - Belgium - the volume of financing currently stands at 1.2 billion euros, which should ultimately generate 5.8 billion euros in additional investments. Sixteen infrastructure and innovation projects have already been approved and more than 4,400 small and medium-sized enterprises are expected to benefit. A good instrument which pursues good objectives and gives good results deserves to be extended and improved. I therefore welcome the decision to extend the Juncker Fund for three years, I welcome the objective of setting the total amount of investments to be mobilized at 500 billion, thanks to the leverage effect, and I welcome the improvements made to the initial system. to make it more efficient. By adding new sectors likely to benefit from EFSI funding, more SMEs with new ideas will be able to benefit from them in agriculture, the fight against climate change, cultural industries and creative, in the social and solidarity economy. Thanks to the improvement of the advice and assistance system, the Fund will be able to better respond to realities on the ground and support projects in all regions of Europe. Thanks to the strengthening of governance and greater transparency, the investment committee will have to justify publicly the decisions taken, which is both a requirement and a guarantee. In short, my group will vote this report with conviction.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - As we said at the beginning, we do not follow the logic and objectives of this investment fund. We think that, at the moment, what was needed was a broad public investment plan, aimed at all Member States and with positive discrimination criteria for heavily depressed regions. There is no lack of resources, as can be deduced from the ECB's quantitative expansion policy. This Juncker plan, with its competitive character, favors above all the wealthiest regions, does not guarantee additionality and promotes the delivery of public infrastructure to public-private partnerships. But, if we look at the results in Portugal, we see that it is the logic behind the plan that is not verified. What we essentially have are loans from the European Investment Bank that could be granted without the Juncker plan. Most of all, we do not support the extension of this plan. We do not follow the idea of ​​creating yet another constraint instrument for national states, an investment fund that decides in an undemocratic way which investments to make and in which country. For our part, we continue to defend a solidary budget, with public funds, but in which national governments decide how the investment should be carried out in order to respond to the needs of the populations and then drag private investment against which we have nothing. .

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank the co-rapporteurs, Mr Fernandes and Mr Bullmann, for their hard work on this file. As with EFSI 1, we continued our work on EFSI 2 and with good results. The point is still that there are success stories, and the Commissioner rightfully put them out. There are also a lot of projects about which people are raising doubts. Is this now really what EFSI should be subsidising or supporting? For that reason, we also had a very critical report which Parliament adopted at the beginning of this year which claimed that EFSI 1 was not functioning yet. If you look now at the improvements that we made in EFSI 2, you will see that we have made some big improvements. Firstly, on the definition of additionality: we made sure that additionality really means something that otherwise would not have happened at all, and not only something that follows the European Investment Bank (EIB) definition of additionality. On the scoreboard, that it is really going to help in prioritising what EFSI is going to promote, and not just a kind of well-being there that does not really help in prioritising transparency, how our decision is being taken, or the earmarking of climate action to make sure that EFSI 2.0 is more going in the direction of real climate action. In the end, what is important for us as Parliament is to keep our control on the EIB. There are improvements on governance, but we as a Parliament need to be more serious in monitoring how the EIB is reaching their decisions, and certainly in the context of EFSI 2.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, first of all I really want to commend the effort, the initiative but also the work done by the two rapporteurs, Mr Fernandes and Mr Bullmann. It is truly an admirable task, assisting all the member states of the European Union. I consider it very important to mention, especially on the occasion of the presence of the Commissioner, Mr Katainen, that it is particularly important that this new initiative, with the extension of the plan but also with its revision, focus on small countries as well. It seems that small countries did not have the tools and means to be able to cope and make concrete proposals. If there really was such a huge impact on this plan, given that for the first time in the European Union more than 535,000 small and medium-sized enterprises are going to benefit, it is a challenge for my country, Cyprus, to be exploited. I believe that the management and administration of the European Strategic Investment Action Plan must take initiatives to help my country, which has the potential to develop energy infrastructure, has the potential to really support small and medium-sized enterprises, which are in a difficult position. , but much more, because there was a reference from Mr Katainen, an important reference in Finland, that there were also social projects and social programs, I believe that a country like Cyprus, which has a population of 200,000 refugees, can support this plan refugees in Cyprus for housing, reactivation, development and to give a strong message and example that this project is not only for large projects but also for small and medium enterprises and for social infrastructure and social projects.

name: Marco VALLI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to ask Commissioner Katainen if he really thinks that this tool, in addition to the data it tries to promote in every way, is really stimulating demand within the European Union, because looking at the data on what is the real stimulus that this instrument is bringing, plus the "core" inflation which remains very low, the underemployed people who are increasing precisely because of the reforms that you, as a "hawk" of the Commission, are proposing out of all proportion, especially in the countries of Southern Europe, these are the problems and much more public investments would be needed. Unfortunately, the private investments that the Juncker fund will bring, if we go to do the calculations to show that its data are very inflated, we will reach 500 billion perhaps, in 2020, of investments generated, therefore 100 billion a year, divided by 28 countries : three and a half billion a year per country. Here, a rather ridiculous figure compared to what the economy needs today. I am in favor of a rationalization of public spending on truly productive investments, but we need to loosen the bridle of austerity, otherwise for some countries there will be no hope of repaying this monstrous public debt, which for example my country has, but a public debt of 135 per cent of GDP cannot be repaid, in my opinion we must make GDP grow in a sustainable way, so that the denominator is demolished. And, using only this tool, he understands that he will not be able to get out of this situation. As for the projects financed to date by the Juncker fund, unfortunately I do not see much additionality, and within the proposals that exist, I do not understand why the Greens continue to support it, precisely because there are still projects focused on fossils, on non-renewable sources and therefore - I had a minute and a half, Madam President - and so I wonder how it is possible that sustainable projects are not being funded.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Ms. President!The primary objective of the European Fund for Strategic Investments is to support projects that deliver social and environmental benefits, high-quality and sustainable jobs.The fund should act as a tool to boost the Union's economic capacity, helping to close the investment gap with the latter.How can the fund meet this objective if 91% of the infrastructure and innovation support framework has been allocated to the old 15 Member States.It is clear, therefore, that the Strategic Investment Fund will not replace the cohesion funds and similar instruments, so they must be maintained in the future if we are to reduce the gap between the countries of the center and the periphery.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: - Madam President, I would like to congratulate Commissioner Katainen and his team on the success of this European Strategic Investment Fund.Undoubtedly, it is a success and it shows us once again what it means to combine both public and private funds, combined with technical assistance, which has been very helpful.I also congratulate the two rapporteurs, who obtained a very large majority from all their colleagues in extending the fund.What I want to suggest is the importance of technical assistance for a number of countries that have difficulties in preparing projects, such as, for example, my country, Romania.I also think that this positive experience of the fund should be seen as it could be used at national level as well.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Madam President, Mr Vice-President, you will recall that it was my group, the Socialist Group, which was very desperate when Jean-Claude Juncker was inaugurated for this investment plan to exist. It was the European Parliament that wanted the EFSI 1 to be considered as an extension. Here we are at the meeting point. I can only be happy about this, as this investment plan is a stone in the overall strategy that we need for the European Union if it is to face up to the challenges it faces in terms of investments, and first, sustainable investments. You will recall that, in the first debate, for the first investment plan, my group, along with a few others, wanted to contain part of the investment in favor of ecological transition at 20%; that had not been possible. Today we are at 40%, we can only be happy about it. But I would also like to welcome a side effect of this plan, which seems to me to be quite positive: it is the way in which it has led many Member States to draw inspiration from the model of national development and promotion banks in order to promote the capacity to draw up, in each Member State, investment plans which are now better selected and in development. This has also led to changes in the governance of the European Investment Bank, even if there is undoubtedly room for progress. This is why I welcome the fact that we continue to focus on ensuring that the European Investment Bank does not use tax havens in its operations and that the European Parliament has an active and visible role in the committee. orientation. That seems to me to be progress that is going in the right direction. I wish us successful implementation of this plan.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: - The extension of the EFSI period until the end of 2020 and the increase of the EFSI investment target to EUR 500 billion should be strongly supported, as boosting EFSI investment has a positive effect on the economy of the Union as a whole. It should also be emphasized that an important priority of the fund should be re-industrialization of Europe, and not only the proposed climate protection, and the implementation of such a priority requires stable investments in energy-intensive industries. The eligibility of projects in the defense sector, which is so important for the economies of many EU countries, should also be considered. A desirable solution would also be to allow the use of the EFSI as a national contribution for European funded projects and the Connecting Europe Facility. Until now, this is not possible, whereas with traditional EIB financing it is possible.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Katainen, I welcome the compromise found on this file.  Europe has an investment gap of a minimum of EUR 300 billion a year. EFSI plays a crucial role in filling this gap and intervenes where the market fails to do so, but we must reiterate that only a comprehensive framework for investments, structural reforms and common policy will foster growth in the EU. These three dimensions are complementary and necessary to each other.  EFSI will bring EUR 500 billion up to 2020 for more projects, allowing citizens with innovative ideas to access finance more easily in order to launch new projects. This will also make EFSI bigger, greener, more local and more transparent. EFSI keeps a strict approach to the additionality concept, making sure the projects selected are risk-based and would not have been financed otherwise. This is very important, to avoid past infrastructure projects financed such as ghost airports, highways without traffic and high—speed railways without passengers. EFSI should not become a new cohesion policy instrument. I agree with geographic balance in Europe, but we are talking about investment and growth, not about new solidarity instruments.  EFSI also contributes to the COP21 objectives, to keep sustainable development and environment objectives in mind. EFSI also increases the local presence level through the reinforcing of the European Investment Advisory Hub. The decentralisation of EFSI is also a key element, in my view. Who better to identify local needs for the economy than local governments? Of course, this has always to be accompanied by European supervision in order to select projects that have a real European added value.  My congratulations again, especially to the rapporteurs.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, cé go gcuirim fáilte roimh infheistíocht mar go bhfuil géarghá leis, is léir nach bhfuil an EFSI ag obair ar son na ndaoine. Níl sé ag obair chun fostaíocht a chruthú, níl sé ag obair ar mhaithe le seirbhísí poiblí, níl sé ag obair mar thacaíocht d’fhiontair bheaga agus mheánmhéide, agus níl aon rian den infheistíocht a bhí beartaithe don earnáil Comharchumann, nó an eacnamaíocht shóisialta. Bhí deis againn a bheith straitéiseach, bhí deis againn difríocht a dheánamh don tsochaí leis an EFSI ach arís is arís eile, feicimid gurb iad na forbróirí príobháideacha atá ag baint an méid is mó tairbhe as. Níl an EFSI trédhearcach a dhóthain, agus tá sé fíordheacair ar sheirbhísí poiblí éileamh air.Tá os cionn 8000 duine in Éirinn gan tithíocht, 3000 páiste ina measc, agus is mór an náire nach bhfuil Rialtas na hÉireann ag éileamh ar an EFSI chun an fhadhb seo a réiteach. Tá siad níos tiomanta chun airgead dár ndóigh a chur i bpocaí na ndaoine siúd go bhfuil fuílleach acu cheana. Caithfear athrú iomlán a dheánamh ar an gcultúr infheistíochta mar a sheasann sé agus díriú orthú siúd atá i gcruachás. Mar sin, ní féidir liom tacú leis seo agus an tslí go bhfuil sé ag feidhmiú.

name: David COBURN
text: – Madam President, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, also known as the ‘Juncker Plan’, wants to overcome the investment gap in the EU by mobilising private money. For many reasons, I am not in favour of this report, nor do I wish to extend the duration of the EFSI Fund. One should ask oneself: why do we need such an investment fund at a time when interest rates are already extremely low and the market is flooded with cheap money? The answer lies in the nature of the plan. The European Fund for Strategic Investments is explicitly funding risky projects, projects that are not able to obtain funding through the financial markets at a time when money is easy. Very dodgy indeed.  The European Investment Bank and European Commission admitted many times, and I quote: ‘The EFSI projects’ portfolio risk profile will be higher than the average risk profile of the other EIB projects and assets. The EFSI provides a first loss guarantee so that the EIB has been able to invest in more risky projects.’ Let us not forget that at least EUR 16 billion – the equivalent of more than GBP 14 billion – in the EFSI project are guaranteed through the EU budget, plus EUR 5 billion – an equivalent of GBP 4.4 billion – is coming from the European Investment Bank, which is owned by the EU Member States, including Britain, and that will be so after we leave, I should think.  Besides funding projects in the field of energy, EFSI is often used to fund semi-governmental infrastructure projects which are harmful to private business. It sets up in competition with private business. In theory, this megalomaniac EFSI project sounds like a good example of free market capitalism and wealth creation. In practice, however, it is old school Keynesianism and state intervention. This EFSI bubble economy is set to burst and that will be bad for the EU and bad for Britain.

name: André ELISSEN
text: - Today we are discussing the proposal to extend the duration of the European Investment Fund, EFSI. The EU's propaganda machine is running at full speed again. The proposal is a major hymn to the beneficial effects of the EU. Domestic production has been growing for several years in a row and yes, all thanks to the great EU, while the effects of the EFSI on growth cannot yet be determined. All successes are by definition attributed to the EU rather than the Member States. Not simply saying that the original goals have not been achieved, but a warning against the drive to achieve quantitative goals. Attributable and accountable result is apparently not important. In normal Dutch: numbers don't matter. Weaknesses and risks are hidden in camouflaging language. Whether it concerns the construction of wind farms in the Arctic, the construction of a water storage facility in Portugal or the construction of 13,000 energy-efficient homes in France, it remains one very expensive EU campaign and propaganda that costs the citizens with money. I have tabled an amendment with my colleagues from the ENF Group to reject this proposal.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: - Another Dutch speaker but with a completely different story.The EFSI is an excellent initiative and therefore deserves this restart.We have learned from EFSI 1 and a number of points have been explicitly adjusted.The additionality and additional higher risk.Second, the geographic distribution.There will be such a scoreboard and I want to follow the Commissioner closely.That it is really being balanced through Europe and that it is not only the more developed rich states that benefit from it.And the third point, today we reached an agreement on the omnibus to better merge the structural funds, to have more synergy in those investments, with the EFSI fund.I am happy with that because we were also looking for that synergy.Mr Fernandes has indicated that the Structural Funds and Cohesion Policy are in their own objective.This is supplementary.And one more comment: please have more direction towards banks.They are too reluctant to get in.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I really think it was a good page of parliamentary democracy, the one that led us to approve this text. I share the pride and joy expressed by Udo Bullmann, and I would also like to thank Vice President Katainen for his role and also for the generous words he expressed today. There is no doubt, I think, that the new "EFSI 2.0" can strengthen both the quantity and the quality of the investments mobilized. This was something of our problem: reconciling quantity and quality. More quality with earmarking to combat climate change, with the scoreboard, with support for small projects, more quantity and better regional distribution with pricing rules and blending with structural funds, and finally more transparency and more democracy with changes in governance. We now expect consistency in the implementation of the regulation, and the European Parliament will also be at the forefront at this stage.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: - Madam President!Ladies and gentlemen!From the very beginning, the Polish delegation in the ECR group appreciated the EFSI as an important initiative that can effectively support both large structural investments and smaller ones in the private sector.Once again, we also appeal to the Commission to increase the target funds in the project for the development of a training system for entrepreneurs in the field of project preparation, because we see large disproportions in the spending of funds from this fund between the so-callednew and western Europe.The mere proposal to extend the EFSI implementation period is valid, but I hope it will not lead to a weakening or substitution of other sources of funding, such as, for example, the Connecting Europe Facility.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: - Madam President, Mr Vice President, we must encourage investment in the European Union, and the EFSI, which has now been over two years old, is bearing fruit in that direction. Welcome the agreement to increase the period and the amount. We welcome efforts to improve its transparency and complementarity with other European funds. And welcome its impact on SMEs, which are the economic engine of the Union. At the moment, all kinds of projects have been financed and in all areas, but let me highlight one example from all of them, a project in my land, in the Canary Islands: the Bus Rapid Transit in Las Palmas. A project in progress, with a term of two years and that will create more than a thousand jobs during the construction phase, before it goes into operation in 2021. But we cannot settle. I am confident that the Commission's estimates that the € 500 billion in additional investment in the economy will be mobilized by 2020, and also that the EIB will actively and loyally engage with national promotional banks and private investors . I end by congratulating the speakers for a job well done.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: - Madam President, I would like to congratulate our rapporteurs for their remarkable work. The EFSI made it possible to achieve the investment objectives set in terms of amounts. The call for air from this public investment has helped raise a cautious private investment. However, qualitatively, the tool had to be improved. It's done. The new EFSI should in particular allow the implementation of the principle of additionality to permeate the selection of projects. This additionality can be understood in its three dimensions: financial, geographic and sectoral. I thank our rapporteurs for the strengthening of parliamentary control, which improves its transparency and democracy. I also note, with satisfaction, that this extension does not translate, for once, into new cuts. I regret, however, that we have still not succeeded in reconsidering the cuts made neither on Horizon 2020, nor on the mechanism for interconnection in Europe. Finally, after 2020, this must be an opportunity to reorient the EFSI towards the future, that is to say towards the ecological transition.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: - Madam President, Vice-President Katainen, the expansion of the European Strategic Investment Fund proves in practice that Europe can be an attractive, multi-pronged investment field for investment risk takers. But we can do better. We can do better if we increase the additionality of resources; that is, if we succeed in various investment efforts to leverage resources from the Junker project, the Community budget - we call it ESPA in Greece - and the private sector. In the new phase, it is particularly important that EFSI be able to send its benefits to small and medium-sized enterprises. You said a while ago that in Greece we are champions. Indeed, with € 1.6 billion, we will leverage € 5.5 billion. But all this concerns very large and large companies. The bet is that we will give smaller companies access to these resources and we can do this with the strong presence of the European Investment Advisers node for faster maturation and smoother digitization of potential investors. We can also do it with the national investment banks, which according to the third evaluation, is not clearly described specifically for Greece and the added value that will… (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: - Madam President, the agreement reached in the trialogue for the review of the Juncker Plan is a good agreement and I therefore want to salute Parliament's negotiating team and our two rapporteurs.With this new version, we will have an extended, reinforced and fairer investment plan.Finally, the problem of the insufficient geographical distribution of investments that tends to favor the most powerful economies instead of promoting territorial cohesion was recognized.It is true that the dynamism of the countries can minimize these constraints, as evidenced by the case of Portugal, which, thanks to an excellent work by the Government and local authorities, is today one of the countries most supported by the Juncker Plan.But we need these new rules and instruments to improve the geographical distribution of this fund and so that it can become, as it should be, another strategic investment in favor of economic convergence in Europe.

name: Romana TOMC
text: - The EFSI is probably one of the most successful projects of this mandate of the European Commission. Despite the fact that at the beginning of its operation, many doubted its success. Some were even right, especially those who said that smaller countries would find it harder to use this fund. It is clear that larger and richer countries have an advantage. Both in attracting private investors and in self-financing a certain part of investments. However, I would like to point out something here in my speech, namely that, after one year, the issues that remain open and unresolved are still emerging, the issues that I pointed out last year when extending the EFSI, namely , that nowhere has been published an estimate of how many jobs this major European project has brought, and this year I remain with the Commission on the same issue. However, given that I still have time to speak, I would like to point out one more thing. Again, we have a shortage of funding for social services, which are very important and extremely important for today's part of society. Let us not forget our population, which is made up of more and more people with disabilities, the population is aging and we urgently need a greater balance in favor of social investment.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the approval of the EFSI plan and EFSI 2, of the European investment plan, are certainly a sign of a Europe that has finally restarted and that has bet on itself, but there are two objectives which we have a duty to pursue, which this Parliament always invokes in the work of the Commission and the work of the Council. On the one hand, investing and betting on small and medium-sized enterprises, which are also the backbone of our continent, and on the other hand, finding the resources and the same ability, the same strength we had in approving the investment plan, also for the struggle for a social Europe. A social Europe means fighting unemployment, especially youth unemployment, poverty. We have in front of us, and we fill our mouths and we are very proud, to finance, to invest in the so-called "industry 4.0", but we continue in Europe to have a "welfare 1.0", which is no longer adequate for its times. The states can't take it anymore and we need instead a Europe that can make up for the states and is finally able to put forward proposals on social policies.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: - Madam President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I would like to thank the two rapporteurs, José Manuel Fernandes and Udo Bullmann, for the excellent work of both EFSI I and EFSI II. We broke new ground here and we were successful. Thanks to the European Parliament, the EFSI is becoming more powerful, more targeted and more transparent. We are topping up the EFSI financially, we are extending it and we are improving it based on the experience we have gained in dealing with EFSI I over the past few years. We are improving the financing, we are expanding the European hub of investment advice, we are anchoring the direct allocation of the EU guarantee so that small-scale projects can be better incorporated into large research ideas, we ensure that precisely those high-quality projects are funded that are part of existing ones Instruments are not implemented, we are strengthening governance, we are ensuring more transparency, improved pricing policy and the implementation of the COP21 climate targets, and we are calling for further investment efforts because we are still lagging behind when it comes to investing in regions and as a continent. Please agree!

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Due to the delay and because our colleagues are settling in, I regret that I cannot organize the on-demand intervention phase (catch the eye).

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, it is very nice to see a full House here. It is a very important moment because, once you vote in favour of the extension of EFSI, it means that you will raise its firepower up to half a trillion euros by the end of 2020. It is a significant tool for improving Europe’s competitiveness and for increasing the number of jobs.  I must say that the biggest challenge we still have with EFSI is the lack of awareness. (The President called for silence) Many companies, many regions, many municipalities and authorities have never heard of EFSI, even though we have been communicating massively. If you look at the countries and regions which have benefited the most from EFSI you can see that local authorities, and also private banks and MEPs, have been actively promoting the opportunities which EFSI can offer. I can give you some examples of very active MEPs. I am sorry not to mention them all but, for instance, Ms Spyraki from Greece, Mr Kelly from Ireland, Mr Gualtieri from Italy, Ms Kaili from Greece and Ms Maydell from Bulgaria have organised a significant number of events promoting EFSI opportunities for local entrepreneurs and local authorities. I encourage you strongly to promote this good example.  The second point I want to make is that EFSI has not created a division between East and West.  (The President called for silence) If you look at the list of the countries which use EFSI most, Estonia, Bulgaria, Greece, Portugal, and Spain are the first five, then you have Finland, Latvia, Lithuania, Italy, Poland, France and Croatia. So, EFSI can be used everywhere but it depends on the activism of local authorities and entrepreneurs, and also MEPs, as to how well informed people are of the opportunities.  I would like to stress the importance of combining EFSI opportunities with structural funds because this would further expand the opportunities for cohesion countries to use EFSI.  My final point is that, since EFSI is a demand driven fund, it is not the medicine for all diseases. We have to make sure that companies working in the circular economy field, in artificial intelligence, in agriculture and forestry, and in energy efficiency, to mention just a few areas, use more EFSI financing, because it can give better opportunities to invest in new innovations. I would like, once again, to thank this House for the fruitful cooperation.  Commission statement As a result of the political agreement between the European Parliament and the Council on the financing of EFSI 2.0 an amount of EUR 275 million will be redeployed from CEF financial instruments, which represents a reduction of EUR 225 million in comparison with the Commission proposal. The Commission confirms that the financial programming will be revised to reflect the corresponding EUR 225 million increase of the CEF programme. In the framework of the annual budgetary procedures for the years 2019-2020 the Commission will make the appropriate proposals to ensure an optimal allocation of this amount within the CEF programme.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Rapporteur.- Madam President!In view of the advanced time I will not use the two minutes.I will make one point, which I believe is the most important: this fund for strategic investments in Europe is necessary and it is useful.But this House, the European Parliament, neither waved through the concept the first time at EFSI I nor the second time it was renewed and nodded its approval.No, we designed it.It is, it was and it remains sorely necessary that you, ladies and gentlemen, get involved in the implementation of this very necessary vehicle, because we make it an instrument for a better quality of life and work, for more sustainability and formake the future of Europe.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: reporter. - Madam President, this is an open fund that is not required, but that is proposed, and proposes to support, above all, Member States and investments in those Member States where there is more difficulty in accessing the market. It is also a solidarity fund that shows the importance of sharing in the European Union. With the guarantees of the Union budget, we provide investment and create jobs. More than 250 billion euros have already been mobilized in less than three years, more than 400,000 small and medium-sized enterprises have been supported, more than 600,000 jobs have been created in the European Union. It is a fund that will continue until 2020 with greater monitoring by the European Parliament where more transparency is required, that decisions are reasoned and public.
