I am sure that with instruments of this nature, with more sharing, with more solidarity, we will achieve the objective of employment, of helping the most disadvantaged regions. This is an instrument that shows that the European Union is worthwhile.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place in a few minutes.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - I believe that the European Fund for Strategic Investments has achieved its objectives when it was launched, so it is justified to extend the program. However, looking through the list of completed and ongoing projects, we may feel lacking. The EFSI has really only performed well in the western, more developed Member States and regions, and we will find very little investment in the new Member States and the less developed regions, so more attention needs to be paid to geographical balance in the future. Furthermore, the mechanism offered by the EFSI should not serve as a basis for a possible reform of the Structural Funds after 2020. Cohesion policy must preserve the fundamental objectives in accordance with Article 179 of the Treaty and ensure that grants continue to play a dominant role alongside financial instruments, which is the only way to ensure that economic disparities are effectively reduced.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: in writing. - The compromise proposal of the European Parliament and the Council increases the EU guarantee behind the resources provided by the European Fund for Strategic Investments from EUR 16 billion to EUR 26 billion. By increasing the EU guarantee, the Investment Fund's investment portfolio will increase to EUR 500 billion by 2020. On the issue of funding, we agree with the compromise text and support it, as it states that the European Commission will adhere to the framework previously adopted in the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework. The compromise reinforces the Investment Fund Advisory Platform, which will in future be able to employ professionals at local level to help those interested in investing in their decisions. This can strengthen the diversification of the use of resources, ie so that all European regions can benefit equally from the support provided by the Investment Fund. According to the agreement between Parliament and Council, the Investment Fund will in future be able to provide assistance for motorway investments in cohesion countries. At the same time, we have succeeded in carrying out an independent review of the operation of the Fund and reviewing the results achieved so far before a possible extension of the Investment Fund beyond 2020. In order to reach a compromise, we can accept the European Commission's amended draft, as the agreement is accompanied by a Council statement stating that the agreement does not set a precedent for the future and respects the provisions of the Treaty.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written. - The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) was set up by the European Member States to encourage private and public investments in the fields of energy efficiency, renewable energy, infrastructure, transport, health and digitization . EFSI was initially established for three years in order to mobilize at least 315 billion euros in additional investments in the real economy by 2018. The Commission now wants to extend EFSI in terms of both duration and financial capacity. So far, investments have mostly been concentrated in large Member States. With better coordination, more EFSI funds will now flow to smaller Member States, including Austria. The investment decisions are explained in more detail through explanations published online, which makes it clear that the selected projects would not have been financed at the same time or to the same extent without the support from the EFSI. In addition, investment decisions become more transparent. The Investment Committee will explain in more detail why it believes the criteria for EFSI support are met. Austria currently has six signed projects, mainly in the areas of transport (regional train infrastructure) and renewable energies. These correspond to an investment volume of EUR 2.3 billion. There are six more projects for the 2018-2020 period, including investments in energy efficiency, new school and hospital infrastructures.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - Today we are voting on the interinstitutional agreement which aims to double the duration and the intervention capacity of the European investment plan. This flagship initiative of the Juncker Commission was launched at the end of 2014 to change the EU's political priorities after the financial crisis by favoring a revival of investment in Europe. Today's vote intends to continue it so as to bring its strike force to 500 billion euros by 2020 (and 630 billion by 2022). I would remind you that since the fall of 2015, support of 250 billion euros has been provided to more than 500,000 businesses, thus creating 690,000 new jobs. I welcome the fact that, in this new version, the additionality criteria have been strengthened, making it possible to select projects that would not find, or only to a lesser extent, funding to see the light of day. It remains to focus it even more on the Member States which need it most. I also naturally welcome the possibility of supporting innovative projects in the cultural industries and in the economy and social infrastructure. I can only stress the need to invest again and again in the social sector! It's urgent.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: written. - The European Fund for Strategic Investments, the EFSI, aims for growth and jobs. Their implementation depends, among other things, on the complementarity of the funded projects, ie that the projects would not have taken place without EFSI funding. However, if we look, for example, at the recent decision by the European Investment Bank, the EIB, to finance the Tripla shopping center in Pasila, Helsinki, with EUR 130 million in EFSI-guaranteed credit, I wonder how complementarity will be achieved. The project itself may make sense, although the main beneficiaries of the project are private companies. In addition to the EIB, the financial package, which has been hailed as competitive, includes other banks, a solvent Helsinki and plenty of private financing. Funding seems to have been sufficient in the midst of all the European Central Bank's funding supply, which makes it difficult for me to believe that the project would not have taken place without the involvement of the EFSI or the EIB. If additionality does not materialize, it is a waste of EFSI money. Complementarity must be assessed at the time of funding, and the absence of such impact assessments raises doubts. The use of funds and the impact assessments carried out are not sufficient to justify the continuation of the EFSI.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item on the agenda is the vote.(Results and other details of the vote: see minutes)

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Rapporteur. - Mister President! In a nutshell: The regulation is intended to simplify the clarification of rights for online content and thus make more content accessible to Europeans and allow Europe to grow closer together. Contrary to what has been discussed, the regulation does not introduce a pan-European license. It is still possible to limit the range. The ordinance also explicitly prescribes remuneration. Indeed, I would have liked to see stronger rules for authors here, but that could not be done with the majority. The report in the Committee on Legal Affairs lags far behind the report of the Consumer Committee, and it rightly lags behind the report or the opinion of the Committee on Culture and thus follows the Committee on Industry. I cannot see a balanced proposal. What we will see is that consumers continue to use illegal access such as VPN to be able to consume content. No creative person in Europe will see an extra cent for this. I think that we Europeans shouldn't leave the audiovisual media to the big American corporations, but rather enable our European providers with better rights regulations to enable access for our citizens. I want better access for the citizens, for linguistic minorities in the European Union, and I want fair remuneration for creative people. One last note: The portability regulation, which is celebrated as a success, does not help here because it only applies for a limited period of time, because it only applies to access from the home country. That is why we should reject this mandate here today in plenary and discuss it again together. The future of creative, digital Europe is too important.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! I would ask you today to vote in favor of granting the mandate to start trialogue negotiations on the CabSat directive. We discussed this dossier in several committees for months, and the report, which is in line with what was decided in the Industry Committee and also in the Culture Committee, was then adopted by a solid majority of 15 to 8 votes in the Legal Committee. I would just like to say one thing about the content: what is this report about? The point is that we strengthen our creatives in Europe, that we strengthen our filmmakers, that we strengthen our scriptwriters, our performing artists, our directors, that we strengthen our creative content. What defines Europe is our creative content. It's all about this. It is not about consumer protection regulations, access to content is not regulated - last year we passed the portability directive with a large majority - that is not what it is about, it is purely about the issue of clearing rights within the online exploitation chain. And I really ask you: We have been working intensively on this dossier for months and agreed on a compromise line. And if we go into the trialogue negotiations now, that is not the end of the story either, there will always be developments. But let's start the trialogue negotiations! Then we will come back and have another opportunity to discuss the report.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Rapporteur.- Mister President!Thank you for this vote.In fact, I've been working on this dossier in the Legal Affairs Committee for about a year, trying to make Europe more digital, to bring people closer together.I have never seen such lobbying as in this dossier.That's really interesting.This is also reflected, for example, in a very interesting debate in the sessions we have had about it.In any case, I will not go into the trialogue negotiations with this mandate and will therefore withdraw my name from this report.I believe that digital Europe deserves better.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: - Mr President, I just wanted to point out a precedent which - I think - concerns our assembly and which we must emphasize and not admit.For the first time, on this issue for which we have just adopted the mandate, we have seen that there are various positions, but it is a debate that belongs to this chamber.It is very regrettable that a Commissioner, a Vice-President of the Commission, saw fit to write to parliamentarians to explain to them what should be the content of their vote.So here I wanted to denounce this attempt to influence.Regardless of the outcome of the vote, it is unacceptable for the Commission to interfere in the deliberations of our chamber in this way.I hear that the sovereignty of our chamber be remembered, that this be a unique precedent and that it will not be repeated.

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: demonstrator.- Mr President, a process that has lasted for many years is now coming to an end in this vote in Parliament.I think it is important to emphasize the importance of its great work in calling once again on the Kazakh authorities to release political prisoners and strengthen the human rights dialogue that is already under way.If that happens, we as the European Parliament can be proud of these votes.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I hereby close the vote.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: - What worries us most about this report is the disappearance of the compulsory figure of the active farmer, because this means that golf courses can receive aid again and that the money ends up in the hands of those who monopolize the land and do not generate wealth for the village. We also fear the free way for the CAP money to go to financial companies, something that we understand will only help to continue increasing market speculation with food, while in the world forty thousand people die every day from hungry. They say they want to strengthen the role of producers in the value chain. However, they establish controls so as not to nullify competition, lest the producers really have any power to jeopardize the profits of the large distributors. But of course, we know that it does not matter. We need a common agri-food policy that puts the defense of peasant rights and the vision of women at the center. More value to those who can mitigate the fight against climate change and less power to large corporations and agribusiness. As simple as that. A CAP in that sense could change things, but we already know that you are not interested.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Mr President, the measures we have adopted in the framework of the Omnibus package today have a real chance to give a new impetus to European agriculture. Producer organizations are still not attractive enough in some Member States, such as mine, Bulgaria. I hope that with the new simplified rules, producers will be able to walk the path to sectoral unification. More flexible rules in the implementation of the Young Farmer measure will also help to engage more people in the Agriculture sector. As rapporteur on the beekeeping sector, I am extremely pleased that set-aside land planted with honey crops can now be recognized as ecologically oriented areas. This is good news for beekeeping in Bulgaria and in the European Union. The measures that I also supported also include a stronger position for producers in the milk sector. The attitude towards them, especially towards sheep breeders, goat breeders and cattle breeders, is inadmissible. Contracts for the purchase of raw materials will provide more security and will make the sector more stable, and hence more attractive.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, I voted against this. I voted against it because, in reality, the Emissions Trading System (ETS) has been an absolute, complete failure. Now, it is a very good report. I am not criticising the author; I am criticising the aspect that the ETS system is fundamentally flawed. It has got little to do with lowering emissions. It is designed to raise revenue as a stealth tax, and it is also designed as a protectionist measure. The net effect of the proposed changes to the ETS in aviation policy will mean more taxes on tourists, more taxes on business travellers, and it will push up the price of imports. That helps European Union-based manufacturers and farmers, but ultimately does not help the aviation sector.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I was pleased to vote in favour of this report. Up until last year, obstacles were continually posed by third countries to European legislation being applicable to their airlines, and this was to the extent that aviation had never been applied to the emissions trading system (ETS) in its original scope. EU provisions on flights between the EU and third countries have been suspended twice with a view to encouraging the International Civil Aviation Organization process to agree on a global strategy to decrease aviation emissions. It is imperative that we take measures to limit greenhouse gas emissions, particularly from international aviation. This is essential to keep global warming below the two degrees above pre-industrial levels as agreed in the 2015 Paris agreement on climate change, where I had the honour of representing this Parliament. As the international aviation sector is a rapidly developing source of greenhouse gas emissions, this report marks a welcome step in Parliament’s work on the EU ETS, and I support the progress on the same.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, once again I voted in favour of this report, which proposes to extend the duration of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), which is indeed a very welcome development.  I must thank also Commissioner Katainen for specifically mentioning me in relation to my promotion of EFSI in my country. The fact it is being extended now is an indication of its success. If it wasn’t successful, we would not be extending it. Sometimes I think people in this House are too slow to give credit where credit is due. This is a wonderful development. It has been used in my country and in many other countries and will continue to be used into the future, for which Commissioner Katainen and President Juncker deserve great credit.  One thing I would say, though, is that in extending it they should look at smaller projects, especially in smaller countries, because a small project in a small country can be relatively big in the overall context. This is a great development. I look forward to further promoting it in my country in the new year through public hearings.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the life and state of the European Fund for Strategic Investments in Greece has provoked strong reactions, because instead of contributing to the increase of investments, instead of contributing to additionality, it has become a tool for financing the seizure of the Greek public property of multinational lenders and mainly of Germany. Thus, Fraport, within the framework of the European Strategic Investment Fund, was financed with a loan of 280 million euros, an amount that reached 400 million euros through leverage, in order to facilitate Fraport to grab 14 Greek regional airports instead of a lentil plate. Similarly, Cosmote, a subsidiary of the state-owned Deutsche Telekom, was funded under the European Strategic Investment Fund with 450 million euros. The memoranda thus imposed the privatization of Greek companies, which are being looted by German state-owned companies with loan funds from the European Strategic Investment Fund. Shame!

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr. President, today I supported the continuation of EFSI because it is important to maintain the level of investment in the European Union, but especially in private, innovative and risky projects.The EFSI is not sufficiently present in less developed Member States, and in particular in neighboring candidate countries.The reason for this is not the lack of projects in these countries, as is often heard, but the lack of administrative capacity.That is why in the continuation of the EFSI we need to strengthen the role of the European Investment Advisory Center, which should increase its activities in less developed countries and strengthen the role of national development banks and work on creating territorial platforms for assistance.Compared to other instruments from the European budget, the EIB, the EBRD or other institutions, the EFSI should be an upgrade, not a substitute, and must act in synergy, not interfering, intertwining and overlapping with others.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Mr President, before the crisis, European Union investment was close to 23% of GDP. Today it barely reaches 20%, threatening the viability of our production model. Due to the cuts, public investment has plummeted 25%, a situation that the EFSI has done nothing to resolve. The European Union has instruments to bring financing to the real economy. On the one hand, the EIB, whose structure must be strengthened so that its resources help to stimulate credit to SMEs and projects of general interest. On the other hand, the European Central Bank, which should be reformed to eliminate any conditionality in its intervention in the public debt markets. What the European Union lacks is a budget commensurate with its needs, capable of territorially uniting Europe and ensuring solidarity among Europeans. The EFSI not only replaces European public investment, on the contrary, it redirects it exclusively in the interest of private investors. In this way, a project for Europe cannot be built, exclusively in the hands of the markets, and that is why my vote was against.

name: Thomas MANN
text: - Mister President! Whenever we ask the question: “What are we actually doing in Europe? Is that visible, can it be experienced? ”I then realize that EFSI is one of them. We call it the Jean Claude Juncker Plan; To ensure that strategic investments can take place. I am happy about this solidarity fund. I am happy that we can say: We just don't have a division between East and West. Mr. Marias is constantly working on his requests to speak on the motto “Always against Germany” and on the topic of austerity and the like. That's totally wrong. Such companies must also be promoted. It should also benefit the Greeks very well. So I think the EFSI is really an important milestone. Not everything has been right in many details, but the direction is right. The baseline must be made clear. We don't leave people on their own so that really strategic investments with a future-oriented character can be realized. If we continue on such a path, you will feel more: Europe is there not to leave people alone. In my opinion, Jean-Claude Juncker succeeded in doing this absolutely. I am happy that we had a clear vote today. I naturally voted in favor of the excellent report by Mr Bullmann and Mr Fernandes.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, I have just voted for, and we have just adopted, a very important report on strengthening citizenship. There is a group of people, though, who would love their citizenship rights to be strengthened. Right now, that said, they would give everything for those rights just to be respected, maintained and guaranteed. In adopting this report today, Mr President, I believe we have made very clear again in this Parliament that citizens’ rights, the rights of EU citizens in the UK, are not there to be negotiated. They are not negotiating currency; they are not there to be offered to people or for concessions to be made to people. They are much more important than that. This Parliament will have to continue to be vigilant against that and against threats to that in these coming months, and I am sure it will be. We have already seen the so-called agreement unravel very quickly from the end of last week. Citizenship rights, the rights of citizens across Europe are not there to be negotiated away by politicians.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: – Mr President, I voted against this report because many important things have been pushed out and, on the contrary, some off-topic things like rejection of unilateral changes in internal borders were voted in this report. In my opinion, it is scandalous that this citizenship report says almost nothing on the existence of so-called non-citizens – of which there are about 300 000 in Latvia, my country, and 100 000 in neighbouring Estonia. These people are deprived of a number of rights and, despite having filed with the Committee on Petitions a petition bearing more than 10 000 signatures from Latvia and Estonia on voting rights for non-citizens, this problem is not tackled in this report. Eight years ago, this problem was mentioned in a similar resolution, and Parliament voted for this. This problem is still not resolved, and the rights of 400 000 people – permanent residents of the European Union – are still being denied.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, well for me when Mr Timmermans addressed the Committee on Constitutional Affairs meeting recently and stated that petitions should not be seen as a tool of direct democracy, this underlined the farce of the European Union guarantee of citizens’ rights and democratic voice. When there are European Union calls from this Chamber to ban a national referendum, as the Green Party leader did only a short while ago, and when the European Union has made the application of rights such a critical part of the Brexit talks, actually it is all about control and has got nothing to do with delivering rights because they will not offer a reciprocal deal for United Kingdom residents living in Europe. I could not support this report. If those issues had been included, addressed and reviewed there might have been a chance.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr Chairman! We are talking about civil rights on the 25th anniversary of the guarantee of citizens' rights in the 1992 treaty. This great EU idea concerns 500 million people. And this is also a very important goal for us, although it should be clearly noted that it has not been fully achieved yet. It is worth emphasizing at this point that the idea of ​​citizenship in the European Union also means achieving and maintaining in the united Europe and in the Member States the fundamental values ​​of the European Union, which include freedom, equality, democracy, equality, non-discrimination, and for such reasons. such as gender, nationality, sexual orientation, age, language, ethnicity, religion or disability. When talking about citizens' rights, one should also remember about guaranteeing European Union citizens the right to health care and pension security, regardless of where they live and from which Member State they come, if they are within the territory of the European Union, within the territory of a united Europe.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, most of our trade rules date back to the analogue time. We urgently need to make them fit for the digital age. Decent working conditions, privacy and fair competition are all being challenged whilst the rules of the game are outdated. I welcome this report, which complements the work of this Parliament, which we already did on issues including, in particular, the Trade in Services (TiSA) negotiations. I am particularly pleased with the fact that a consensus is emerging on excluding data transfer rules from investment protection provisions. This report strongly reaffirms the conditions that we have laid down in relation to the TiSA negotiations and any future agreement. It is now up to the Commission to rise to the challenge of digitalisation. We need strong rules to synch technological with social progress, ensuring really fair trade for all.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I hereby close the explanation of vote.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item on the agenda is the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Afghanistan (2017/2932 (RSP)).

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, dear colleagues, Afghanistan and its people are a priority for the European Union and we definitely care about peace in that country, and the possibility of a national renaissance. The Brussels Conference on Afghanistan was a turning point in our cooperation. We Europeans have stepped up our engagement with Afghanistan, both financially and through a new diplomatic push with regional and international players. Now, one year later, we can see progress in a number of areas. Key achievements include the National Strategy for Combating Corruption, and also the successful work of the Citizens’ Charter, Women’s Economic Empowerment National Priority Plan, and managing migration in the country. Progress has also been made on budget and fiscal reform; and the government has taken several measures to create a more competitive, export—oriented and job—creating economy.  But the work is not finished. The security situation remains fragile. There have been a number of attacks in Kabul and other areas against security forces and places of worship affecting innocent civilians, including women and children. We are alarmed by the high level of violence and the number of civilian casualties – and, frankly, reconciliation and sustainable peace are the absolute priority for Afghanistan and also for us as the European Union – but a peace process can only be successful if it is led and owned by the Afghans themselves.  The Afghan Government can count on the EU to be a partner in its search for peace. We will not stop working to create the right environment towards a negotiated settlement, including through the work of the recently appointed EU Special Envoy for Afghanistan.  We want to support the country in the areas where it needs it the most. And precisely to discuss these priorities, last February we have signed a Cooperation Agreement on Partnership and Development with the Afghan Government. The Cooperation Agreement is a political commitment to set up a constant dialogue on all the issues we care about, from the economy to migration, from women’s empowerment to human rights. First, we are with the government as it tries to bolster the country’s fragile economy. This includes support to the rural economy, but also to the fight against drugs as well as illegal mining. Helping to strengthen Afghanistan’s regional connectivity is also quite important for us.  Second, there can be no sustainable development when human rights and fundamental freedoms are not respected. Whilst some progress has been achieved in this field, a lot still needs to be done to improve women’s and children’s rights, to abolish the death penalty, to prevent torture and ill—treatment, to guarantee access to justice and the freedom of expression and to support human rights defenders.  The development of Afghanistan also requires women and girls to be able to contribute in full to the country’s social, economic and political life, as well as to the future peace process. So we are working to empower women in Afghanistan – helping girls go to school, training policewomen, and supporting innovative projects by female entrepreneurs. Third point, we have started a comprehensive dialogue with Afghanistan on migration. Let us be clear on this: managing human mobility is an interest we share with the Afghan people. We both want the Afghan youth to find better opportunities at home. We both want to prevent that the people of Afghanistan risk their lives in dangerous journeys across the world. We both want also that those who return home can have the opportunity to a better life. To this end, we have already mobilised almost EUR 200 million to ensure the returnees’ reintegration into society, and we will continue to work in the framework of the Joint Way Forward (JWF), a common political engagement for managing migration in a sustainable way, based on solidarity and dialogue. Finally, we are working to strengthen democracy in the country, and also the rule of law and promoting good governance. Part of this work is the fight against corruption. The Afghan Government has stepped up its anti-corruption measures and adopted in October a national anti-corruption strategy. Implementation of this strategy is now what truly matters.  We also as the European Union continue to support the civilian aspects of the security sector reform: a new police advisory project will be launched soon.  Next year, in 2018, Afghanistan is expected to hold parliamentary and district elections, followed by presidential elections in 2019. These elections need to be transparent, credible and inclusive, including for women. The Afghan authorities still need to implement a thorough electoral reform to ensure the trust of the electoral stakeholders in the process. We have already committed around EUR 19 million to support and accompany a democratic electoral process. My dear colleagues, the Afghan people deserve democracy and human rights; they deserve peace and prosperity. The European Union will continue to work with its partners in the Afghan Government to achieve this. It is not an easy goal. At the same time, we will further develop our engagement with our international partners, to make Afghanistan and our common region more peaceful and more prosperous. Our commitment to Afghanistan and its people is here to stay.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the EU and its Member States have cooperated with Afghanistan since 2001 in a joint effort to counter the terrorist surge and create the conditions for stability and sustainable development. Without a stable and secure Afghanistan, there can be no peace and stability in the region as a whole. It has proved a difficult and controversial but also a rewarding task, with encouraging progress in some areas like the economy and education, and renewed problems in others.  Recently, security has been weakened by the increased terrorist activities of the Taliban and the resurgence of al—Qaeda and ISIS groups. Last year, there were about 600 000 newly displaced persons internally. Our message today is that there is no alternative to the continuation of the strong international engagement under the auspices of the UN. The EU is an important and constructive part of that engagement. It is also crucial to keep the 39 nation NATO—led Resolute Support Mission operating as it is vital for building and strengthening Afghanistan’s security forces and institutions.  Second, striking out the financing of terrorism. The continued production and trade of opium has a devastating impact not only domestically, but also for security internationally. Only an all—inclusive Afghan-led peace and reconciliation process will be a viable way towards a sustainable resolution of the conflict, and I would draw attention to the need to include disarmament and the reintegration of former insurgents as part of that.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - I am sorry, Commissioner, but shame the European Union strategy for Afghanistan, taking as one of the priorities a readmission agreement signed without any democratic scrutiny by this Parliament. Following in the wake of anti-immigrant rhetoric from the far right in Europe, the strategy overshadows the tragic reality in Afghanistan, marked by conflict, terrorist attacks, structural governance failures in a country where corruption, drug trafficking is rife, where the violation of rights women, children and the Hazara minority is systematic. This agreement is inhumane, it violates the values ​​of the European Union. Afghanistan is not yet a safe country for anyone, let alone asylum-seekers being deported. I greet the German pilots who have been refusing to transport them back. They save more than flight safety, they save the memory and honor lost by so many in Germany and Europe. Contrary to what the Commission and the Council want, deportees do not return home, but are thrown, without choice, into exclusion, left at the mercy of terrorists and organized crime. It is in the fight against drug trafficking for good governance, education, justice, economic development that promotes employment and opportunities for young people that the European Union's strategy for Afghanistan should be centered, always based on respect for the human rights of all Afghans, in the majority of the abused citizens who are women and children.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the situation in Afghanistan does show some signs of improvement, but we must not shy away from the very clear gaps in security that still persist. GDP does still continue to grow. Life expectancy has been extended, and more and more young girls are finding their way into education for the very first time.  The Taliban, nevertheless, poses a sustained and credible security threat, with ISIS and the Haqqani network among the terrorist groups compounding the problem. Attacks against the Supreme Court in February, as well as a blast in the diplomatic quarter of Kabul in May, illustrate this problem only too clearly. Across the country, 2017 has seen a record high in terms of terrorist—caused civilian deaths, the highest number for 16 years.  The link between security at home and security in Afghanistan cannot be ignored, and it is important that this link is continually underlined, particularly in the face of a sceptical public opinion throughout the European Union. It is vital, therefore, that the EU and Member States remain engaged and at the forefront of international efforts to support the Afghan Government in its efforts to stabilise the country in terms of both the economy and security.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, last year the Brussels Conference on Afghanistan showed an exceptional international commitment to the country. Today, we have not moved much closer to the overarching goal, which is to achieve Afghanistan’s self—reliance. The EU, together with its Member States, is Afghanistan’s largest donor and this in itself brings us extraordinary responsibilities. However, there is no other solution than that of building a coalition with other international and regional partners, the government and civil society that works even more effectively.  I strongly believe that we should focus on four crucial pillars. To begin with, it is fundamental to continue promoting peace, stability and security. We must aim to achieve an inclusive peace process, as only a regional solution can be sustainable. Secondly, ahead of next year’s elections, we have to advance with the difficult task of state building, with special attention given to women’s rights and the uncompromised fight against corruption. Moreover, we need to accelerate economic and social development. For example, we can explore the ways in which Afghanistan could use its vast mineral potential. Finally, regarding the EU engagement on migration challenges, those coming back home from Europe or its neighbouring countries must find a safe environment with real opportunities to restart their lives. This is essential. The people of Afghanistan deserve our support and cooperation. We must carry on our common work for each and every one of them and their future, as well as for our success.

name: Sabine LÖSING
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mister President! Daily attacks for over 16 years, thousands of civilian victims, the destruction of livelihoods every year, hundreds of thousands of people on the run, NATO troops and unlimited US military action - does that sound like a safe country, a safe country of origin to you? In fact, it is the second most unsafe country in the world. To put it in the words of Pro Asyl: Afghanistan is not a safe country. And yet, despite the disastrous security situation, collective deportations from EU member states to Afghanistan are carried out, again only last Thursday in Germany. What a grotesque, inhuman logic! Even if some things have gotten better, nothing is really good. The military side of the conflict not only caused numerous deaths with a huge number of unreported cases, but also devoured huge financial sums. The sovereignty of the Afghan state is still not guaranteed after more than a decade of US and NATO-led interventions. On the contrary: the country is highly dependent on its external donors, security continues to deteriorate, budgets for civil society tasks and democratization are cut, and the military presence, especially offensive operations, is fueling the conflict. And yet this unsuccessful, destructive strategy is to be continued.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President! The security situation in Afghanistan has worsened again and according to the UN, there are over 1.8 million internally displaced people in Afghanistan. On average, 1,500 people fly internally per day. In 2016 alone, there was an increase of 650,000. Afghanistan is also one of the poorest countries in the world and the situation is exacerbated by the social and economic difficulties of integrating all internally displaced persons and thousands of Afghan refugees returning from neighboring countries daily while all Afghan youth also to enter the labor market. In Pakistan alone, 1.7 million Afghan refugees live and in Iran 1 million that the authorities there want to send back. It should be added that EU countries, which actually contribute to receiving a very small part of the Afghan refugees, also send back t.o.m. young people who have been refugees all their lives and never set foot in the country. And how is Afghanistan supposed to recover, reach peace, get out of poverty, corruption, drug trafficking and meet the challenge of creating jobs for both those who already live there and those who return, when the great danger is that those who are sent back are captured up by the Taliban, Daesh or other criminal gangs as the only way to support themselves. We are not solving this by simply expanding our military operations or, for that matter, the civilians. What is very problematic for me in our policy is the contradiction that at the same time as the Member States are expanding the military presence in the country due to deteriorating security situation, we are sending Afghans back against the background of an improved security situation. How are we supposed to feel? If it is so safe that you can go back without problems, there should be no need to send more soldiers.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the book Eršād al-zerā'a - Guide to agriculture, by a scholar of the fourteenth century, it is said that in Afghanistan, in the Herat area alone, over one hundred distinct varieties of vines, almonds, apricots, pomegranates, mulberries, pistachios and figs. Afghanistan was an Eden, with a particularly favorable climate compared to its neighbors. Today the UN tells us that Afghanistan has broken all records for opium production: 9,000 tons of poppy grown on 328,000 hectares of land; more 87% of production, more 63% of surface area compared to 2016. Most will arrive on our roads, transformed into heroin, and will finance the eternal Afghan conflict, which 17 years after the first US intervention shows no sign of abating. In fact, at least three parallel wars are being fought in the country: one against drugs, one against the Taliban insurgency and one against corruption. And all three are getting lost, proof of this is Trump's decision to employ 4 000 new men in Afghanistan, after a complex 2017, where the Taliban insurgency was joined by Isis, increasingly active and ready, according to several analysts internationals, to build their next stronghold in the country. Europe rightly calls for an Afghan-led political process, in which all parties can sit at a negotiating table: a difficult solution, especially as long as the conflict continues to be a goose that lays golden eggs for all parties involved; for the Afghan forces, who, through corrupt officers, divert to the rebels, in return for payment, the weapons and aid received from their Western allies; and for the Taliban themselves, who through the cultivation of opium, the exploitation of natural resources and various other illicit trafficking, are accumulating fortunes of the order of billions of dollars. However, there are some positive data: GDP per capita the country is growing, life expectancy is getting longer, access to health care and education is increasing, albeit slightly.We need to build on these data, focusing above all on young people, who are struggling to change the image and management of the country.The EU should take action by putting in place policies that aim to enhance them, which will contribute to the maturation of the entire Afghan society, while at the same time removing fertile ground for terrorist recruitment.It will take maybe twenty years, but it is the only way forward.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Afghanistan is a real disaster. It is all the more dramatic as this country has been in theory liberated and democratic for sixteen years. At the security level, outside the big cities, the government of Kabul is still facing the warlords. Economically and socially, as my colleague said, 9,000 tonnes of drugs are produced, twice as many as in the days of the Taliban, supposedly the worst diet - and it was the worst diet. Must it be said that the production of drugs is also done with the complicity of the West? The poppy is equivalent to 35% of the GDP, employs two million Afghans and yet there is more than 40% unemployment. At the geopolitical level, the Afghan disorder has moved to Pakistan and, since the fall of Musharraf, this nuclear power, which was entitled to its bomb, has also been totally adrift in the region. The Union must not add disorder to disorder by wanting to intervene at all costs. By bringing together the regional actors - Iran, Russia, China - and by supporting the balance of powers, it will work for peace, and not by intervening directly.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: - Mr President, the danger of an extremist-led theocratic Afghanistan-Pakistan nuclear unit still persists. Parts of Pakistan, nuclear powers, the Taliban controls. The same Taliban has threatened and continues to threaten neighboring Afghanistan. That is why, ladies and gentlemen, international control and an international military presence in Afghanistan are still needed today. Relations between the European Union and Afghanistan are governed by the Partnership and Development Agreement. The European Union's new strategy towards Afghanistan was presented in July this year. They are useful documents in support of stability and regional security. Nevertheless, I believe that we are not sufficiently addressing the burning issue of former Afghan colleagues. They are often civilian employees of foreign armies. These include interpreters. They cooperated with a foreign army and thus put themselves and their families at risk. Thousands of Afghan interpreters found themselves unprotected after the outgoing coalition forces. We need special visa and asylum solutions for them. We cannot afford to throw them overboard, as is often the case in my country, the Czech Republic. I am thinking of interpreters for Czech troops in the province of Logar. We are putting them at the forefront of extremist Islamist forces, which are using the feelings of guilt of our former collaborators.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there were more than 8 000 civilian casualties in Afghanistan in 2017, and one in three is a child. And these numbers, colleagues, would be enough to tell of a country that lives a reality of daily war. These numbers would be enough to tell us how the situation in Afghanistan remains seriously and highly unstable. Attacks on hospitals continue, attacks on humanitarian aid centers continue, corruption remains at the highest levels, as is the incessant drug trafficking and illegal arms trafficking, in particular, we must say, towards terrorist organizations. And therefore we certainly cannot define Afghanistan as a stable country, we cannot define Afghanistan as a safe country, especially for its own citizens, especially for children, for women, and the return to the country of refugees, in particular of those who no longer have a social or family network, is equivalent to a death sentence. And it is good to reiterate it today, it is good to reiterate it in this House.

name: Patricia LALONDE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Afghanistan is at a crossroads. In recent months, Daesh fighters have settled in the provinces of Nangarhar, Logar and now Djôzdjân in northern Afghanistan. They entered these provinces to help Taliban fighters and use women and children as human shields. A French fighter and an Algerian fighter are also among the Daesh fighters who have just arrived from Syria, which is very worrying. The national unity government is currently unstable and is accused of corruption. President Ashraf Ghani and Prime Minister Abdullah Abdullah must find a way to work together more effectively. This is why it is important that the post of Prime Minister be formally created in the Constitution. Fortunately, the US decision to stay in Afghanistan is a good decision, but former warlord Gulbuddin Hekmatyar entered Kabul six months ago, greeted - disturbingly - by President Ashraf Ghani. Hekmatyar was supposed to strike a deal with the Taliban, but no one can deny that since arriving with his fighters from Pakistan, the security situation is deteriorating very rapidly and no progress has been made on negotiations with the Afghan Taliban. I am talking about those who wish to accept the current Constitution, guaranteeing in particular human rights, democracy and especially the rights of women. The destabilization of Afghanistan also passes through Pakistan, which, through its intelligence services, forcibly returns Afghan migrants to their country and continues to support Islamist groups allied with the Taliban, such as the Haqqani network. Afghan democracy is also in great instability since strong suspicions continue to weigh on the independent electoral commission and the electoral complaints commission.The country's insecurity and the resurgence of attacks in Kabul and in the provinces make us fear that the country may be on the brink of civil war and fall into the hands of extremists.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, our policy in relation to Afghanistan has proved an abject failure. Whilst the last military campaign was relatively successful, the UK has been heavily involved in this country since 2001 and our state-building efforts must now take second place to the ability of the Taliban to use the narcotics trade to build up a huge war chest. Since the retreat from Kabul in 1842, my country has faced various painful interventions here, and it could be reasonably argued that very little has been achieved. Humanitarian intervention has seen much blood and financial expenditure on my country’s part, with little improvement to the lives of many Afghan citizens.  The UK must continue to contribute to international security, attempt to combat the supply of narcotics and of course secure our national interests. Judging by last year’s record opium poppy yield and heroin production figures in Afghanistan, the means by which we do this are not currently working. It is time for a radical rethink.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: – Mr President, in October, the European Council adopted the new EU strategy for Afghanistan. The Council wants an inclusive peace process although the security situation is worsening. Taliban attacks on both civilian and military targets continue. Given this, it is not acceptable that the Council refrains from mentioning the role of neighbouring Pakistan in harbouring Taliban fighters. Contrary to Pakistani claims that it has solved this problem, the commander of the NATO forces in Afghanistan stated just two weeks ago that Pakistan had yet to act against Afghan Taliban. As an example, the Haqqani network is still operating from Pakistan. Owing to its brutal attacks on innocent civilians and foreign embassies, Haqqani is considered the most ruthless terrorist network in Afghanistan. Combating Taliban terrorists is imperative for the whole region. Pakistan must take its responsibility for regional stability. Pakistan must not be a safe haven for the Taliban. The EU should say this, and we should say it loud and clear.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, the European Union and its Member States have engaged in a partnership with Afghanistan together with the international community, a partnership underpinned by a common strategic interest in fighting terrorism and extremism. Nowadays, Afghanistan’s situation has improved in terms of economic and social development compared to 2001. However, the progress made so far is threatened by a difficult security situation, with a high level of violence and a high number of casualties, by weak democratic institutions, with an administration in Kabul that controls less and less territory, coupled with a fragile economic framework and difficult state of human rights. Our commitment to supporting an Afghan-led and Afghan-owned peace process has to remain unabated. I fully welcome the new EU strategy on Afghanistan, which focuses on the necessary conditions for a political solution to the conflict and on developing the country’s institutions and economy while also tackling migration-related issues.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Mr President, in the last decade, significant progress has been made in Afghanistan. Millions of children go to school, infrastructure has been built and, despite the resistance of conservative powers, women have far more rights than they did under the Taliban. The recently provisionally applied Cooperation Agreement on Partnership and Development will further strengthen the areas of human rights – particularly the rights of women and children – and rule of law. However, the war in Afghanistan is returning. The Taliban is again gaining control and influence in parts of the country. With more violence on both sides, the number of civilian casualties is increasing. Judges, government officials and even mullahs are being killed. Corruption and the illicit drug trade are still uncontainable. Many people stopped looking at Afghanistan years ago – the typical fate of long—lasting conflicts – but Afghanistan still remains at the bottom of the World Peace Index, together with Syria.  The number of Afghan people in Europe is increasing rapidly. Therefore, the international community and the European Union in particular has to continue its engagement in Afghanistan to help rebuild the country, develop its economy and fight terrorism. The progress already achieved is very fragile and its sustainment requires further reforms and continuing international support for security and stability in Afghanistan and the entire region.

name: Boris ZALA
text: – Mr President, despite many improvements, Afghanistan certainly cannot be counted as a clear success story of international intervention. Sixteen years after toppling the Taliban, we are no closer to a negotiated political settlement that would bring lasting peace. What is now clear is that such a settlement must include Pakistan, which has a huge stake and influence in Afghan stability. So far Pakistan has failed to play its part. Many Taliban militants still have a safe haven in Pakistan. This must end. This is also where the EU should insert its diplomatic clout, as a partner for democratic governance in Afghanistan, but also as a political power that can help induce Pakistan to be more constructive. The EU can no longer limit itself to economic and developmental aid, but must act as a strategic player in the wider region.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Afghanistan has been in a state of constant war for 17 years since the US invasion. So it has turned into a refugee bomb. Already 1.5 million Afghan refugees are in Pakistan, 450,000 are in Iran, more than 20% of those who flooded Greece in 2015 and in recent months have come from Afghanistan. Stability, politically and economically, must therefore be strengthened in Afghanistan, but NATO countries conducting military operations there must take responsibility for hosting the refugees. This is true of China, Russia and Iran. Beyond that, it is a given that at least 10,000 Afghans trapped in Greece must relocate to European Union countries. And yet Mr Tusk is turning a blind eye and is now calling for the abolition of mandatory refugee distribution quotas in the Member States of the Union. This is unacceptable.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: - We have heard an extensive debate here on the situation in Afghanistan.We held that conference last year and we all see that the situation has not really improved.Europe is one of the largest donors, so we have an important role to play there.Colleagues, 2-3 weeks ago I spoke for an hour and a half with an Afghan refugee boy who was smuggled to Europe by people smugglers.The story of his route - if I have to tell you here - goes through the bone.Smuggled in the trunk of a car, over the mountains in Turkey for days, children murdered on the way, adults murdered.We must bet on those people smugglers.We must ensure that we can combat it.Moreover, we must of course ensure that the situation in Afghanistan is normalized and that people there can build their lives in peace with good economic support.That is our responsibility, colleagues.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, the tragic situation in Afghanistan has been adequately described by many colleagues and by all. Constant tension, factional war, refugees, poverty and corruption. De-escalation can only occur with the de-escalation of the military presence. Thousands of people are leaving, who are unfortunately then repatriated from European Union countries. We need to look a little wider, to solve the problem as much as we can. Pakistan is the country where members of terrorist organizations find refuge and much security. Let's take a look at this country and take punitive measures if we want to see the situation improve. Finally, the war on opium trade is key to any normalization in the country.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, how long has the war in Afghanistan lasted? It has been going on for 17 years, it is an endless war that is not even talked about in our media anymore, except in a sporadic and marginal way. It is a war that can be described as somehow forgotten. The advent of Trump has not changed the trend either, and the withdrawal of NATO troops and its allies, which was initially scheduled for 2014, has been postponed to 2020 and beyond. Many say it is not fair to leave work before it is done. But what work are we talking about? Unemployment has increased from 8 to 40 percent, Kabul has gone from one million to five and a half million inhabitants, and the only relevant activity is the production of opium. Many kids join up because they have no other choice to make a living, but as soon as they can they desert and leave. Today it is important here to welcome the initiative of the International Criminal Court to initiate an independent investigation into war crimes and crimes against humanity perpetrated during the Afghan conflict. I believe that a transparent attribution of responsibility is necessary and desirable, regardless of the parties involved, considering that there is a risk that a third one will be added, namely Daesh.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, the war in Afghanistan is a clear defeat for the United States and its allies with heavy losses in human resources and waste of money. It is a field of strategic science research (and it does not, of course, directly concern the European Parliament) to look for the reasons why three chronically different superpowers, the British Empire, the Soviet Union and the United States, were defeated in Afghanistan. Recently, President Trump announced an increase in the military presence in the country. We must therefore ask ourselves why this was decided, at a time when the losses of the allied forces are enormous on a daily basis, while the bloodbath of innocent Afghan civilians continues and, above all, the mass illegal immigration to Europe. The reasons are obvious: Westerners do not want to leave leaving the field open to Russians and Chinese. In a country rich in deposits of iron, cobalt, copper, hydrocarbons and mainly lithium, but also a huge production center of opium and other drugs. In this international game of power, Europe must have a clear leadership in decision-making, planning to carry out the necessary actions at the political, strategic, operational level, for the benefit of the Member States and European citizens.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: - Mr President! Commissioner! Yesterday a plane flew from Sweden. There would have been 20 people on that plane, but thankfully, thanks to activists, lawyers and brave people who put a stop to it, only 5 people went on that plane. But these 5 are a grief. They went to war-torn Afghanistan. They were sent there and I think it is a shame for the EU and for Sweden that these deportations, these forced deportations may continue, and that the EU's cooperation with Afghanistan is to such an extent conditional on these deportations. I would just like to say thank you to the more than 200 German pilots who have refused to take off with their planes for war-torn Afghanistan. Every plane that does not take off and land in Afghanistan with deported refugees is a victory for all of us and for humanity. So my question is - when will you put an end to this policy, Commission? When will you choose human rights, hope and humanity instead of this type of racism and deportation policy?

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, Afghanistan is one of the most insecure countries in the world. For the 17th consecutive year, the war conflicts continue in this country, which has a great strategic value and where the interests of many different forces are in conflict. The government of the country does not exercise substantial control. The Taliban and ISIS are strong and threatening to seize power. In addition, there is no strategic possibility to address this risk. NATO recently announced a 3,000-strong increase in its force. The whole situation leads to a bloodbath in Afghanistan. Mostly civilians are killed and the situation is out of control. For these very reasons and because this will continue, it is not wise for the European Union to intervene at this time. A period of time must pass, the situation must be balanced, normalized, and then the European Union must intervene politically and diplomatically.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I believe this has been a very useful exchange and I thank you so much for your interventions and your contributions in this debate. From this debate I conclude that we all share a common interest in using EU diplomatic power and EU financial instruments to their full potential in support of a peaceful and prosperous Afghanistan. In 2016 the Afghan Government made strong commitments towards self-reliance, responsibility and ownership of its political course and development policy. The European Union, as part of the wider international community, remains firmly committed to supporting the Government and the people of Afghanistan in this endeavour. The Government of Afghanistan’s continued engagement and appropriation of its commitments will be essential for this to be successful. Our European support to Afghan refugees has been demonstrated in many areas and in many aspects. I personally visited Iran twice to show the tangible European solidarity on the ground in various areas there. In particular, I witnessed in a very demanding field, education in emergencies, our tangible solidarity there. So I strongly believe that, as the European Union, we are fully committed in order to provide any assistance to the Afghan people, not only inside Afghanistan but also outside Afghanistan. A few words about irregular migration. Irregular migration to Europe is a reality and it needs to be addressed. Together with the country of origin, we do address it from a comprehensive angle in the spirit of the partnership framework, looking in the wider context at the causes of migration: poverty, conflict, insecurity. We are trying to remedy those causes with our instruments, political and diplomatic security, and development cooperation. In our discussions and actions we pay particular attention to sustainable reintegration of returned persons, not only from Europe, but also from the region, from where the biggest numbers of returns take place. It is about creating opportunities in the country of origin so that young Afghans find reasons to build their lives there, and not choose the dangerous irregular migration route and become victims of human traffickers. Finally, let me thank you and the European Parliament as a whole for your continued support of all efforts leading towards lasting peace, stability and prosperity in Afghanistan.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The motions for resolutions to be tabled pursuant to Rule 123 (2) would be announced in the House at a later stage.The debate was closed.The vote will take place on Thursday, 14 December 2017.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation of the Rohingya people (2017/2973 (RSP)).

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, last month I was in Bangladesh together with the Foreign Ministers of two Member States, Germany and Sweden. This was another way of showing teamwork and the joint action of European Union institutions plus Member States. I was in Bangladesh in one of the largest camps hosting Rohingya refugees. When you see the camps with your own eyes, when you talk to the people there, when you hear the stories, and when you see the reality on the ground, it makes quite a difference. The thing that struck me the most was the number of young children – I have to say children of my little daughter’s age, six or seven years old – taking care of younger children who were two or three years old. These were children who were travelling together. The older ones were raising the little ones, but we are talking about children we normally consider very, very, very little. It is hard to imagine what that must feel like because these kids are forced to grow up. They are stripped of their right to childhood, and this is going to stay for the rest of their lives. I also met a group of women and heard from them about the violence they had suffered and the violence against their children. When you have heard these stories once, you will never ever forget them. When you hear these stories, action is no longer just a political priority, but it becomes a sort of moral imperative. I am telling you this because sometimes we have to link the political dynamics to stories, faces and people. That same night, I met with the Prime Minister of Bangladesh, not only to express the European Union’s support for the country, but also, and most importantly, to discuss possible solutions to the crisis. Since the camp is in an area where it is certain that when the rainy season starts, the situation will become impossible to manage. It is a camp hosting some 650 000 people in one place.  The day after that visit – the day after I talked to the Prime Minister of Bangladesh – I was in Myanmar for the Asia-Europe meeting. Right before the summit, we asked to set up a special meeting with all the ministers who were there, including Aung San Suu Kyi, to discuss the situation of the Rohingyas and to find a way forward together. It was a quiet meeting with no cameras and no publicity, but it was a very important one. We agreed at that meeting on a shared perspective to start facing the crisis, step by step, but with commitments and with strong regional and international involvement. Just a few days later, – actually, if I am not wrong, three days later – a deal between Myanmar and Bangladesh was announced and signed. We had discussed that deal during that meeting. We had encouraged the two parties to discuss together the first steps that could be made.  We know very well that it is still an extremely difficult situation and that implementation of that agreement will have to be accompanied and monitored extremely carefully by the international community, but this is finally a first step in the right direction after months, if not years or decades, of inaction or actually, even worse, sometimes of turning a blind eye. It could be an entry point to address the crisis from a bilateral point of view between Bangladesh and Myanmar and, together with the agencies, starting from the UNHCR.  For us, this comes after several months of intense engagement. I was here when you adopted your last resolution in September. One month later, we adopted conclusions on the crisis in the Foreign Affairs Council. In the light of the disproportionate use of force by the army, we also decided to suspend invitations to the Commander in Chief of the Myanmar Armed Forces and other senior military officers, and to review ongoing practical defence cooperation.  Meanwhile, we have been active at the UN Human Rights Council. First, we supported the extension of the fact-finding mission’s mandate. Second, we supported a special session on Myanmar last week and the resolution proposed by Bangladesh. We also supported the resolution at the UN General Assembly’s Third Committee. Beyond public statements and beyond the political and diplomatic work we have carried out in these months, we stepped up our humanitarian assistance and co—hosted the UN Pledging Conference in October in Geneva. As usual, the European Union has pledged more money than anybody else. If you look at the European Union and Member States together, we pledged more than the rest of the world combined. Let me add that our pledges always turn into real money and real projects that help real people, meaning that we always deliver on our pledges.  But the humanitarian work alone is not enough. We have to solve the problem. It is now up to Myanmar to improve the situation in the Rakhine State so that everyone can go back to their homes in a safe and dignified way. The rule of law and full humanitarian access must be granted as a first step. So far the Government has granted access to the Red Cross and the World Food Programme in Rakhine State, but we will continue to press for full access to the broader UN and NGO community. At the same time, the people of Rakhine must be guaranteed the right to education and basic social services, and the difficult issue of citizenship must be addressed, all in line with the Annan plan. Let me say that this is perhaps the most important political point to me. The authorities of Myanmar have declared their intention to fully implement the Annan plan. Aung San Suu Kyi has expressed her willingness and commitment to do so, not only in our private meetings, but also in our common press activities and publicly several times. We know very well that she faces an extremely complex situation in the country. The democracy of Myanmar is a very young one. The country is still somehow in a democratic transition, and the path towards an inclusive and pluralistic democracy is never easy, particularly after so many years of military rule. I believe that Aung San Suu Kyi needs and wants our support to implement fully the Annan plan, to translate the political commitment into real action, and to do it, step by step, accompanied by the international community and other countries in the region.  In the coming days and weeks, we will continue to work for dignified voluntary returns based on the bilateral agreement between Bangladesh and Myanmar. We will push for humanitarian access in Rakhine State, based on the first openings made by the Government, and we will work to address the root causes of the crisis and push for the full implementation of the Annan report. I am sure that the European Parliament will continue to contribute to such work that will hopefully bring results, although probably not within a very short time period. However, I believe that the first steps in the right direction have finally been taken even if, again, I am not hiding all the limits, difficulties and shortcomings that we will still be facing in the months ahead. This is why we have to continue working in that direction together.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mister President! Thank you, Mrs Mogherini! I would like to express my thanks on behalf of the European People's Party for your commitment. You have not only fought for the rights of the Rohingya with words, but you have convinced yourself on the ground and promoted international agreements. Many thanks from our side! This means that Parliament's demands in September are also on the right track. I believe that in Myanmar, as the European Union, we can especially contribute to ending the violence, intimidation and displacement of the Rohingya Muslim minority. As chairman of the ASEAN delegation, I would like to express my thanks for your letter from yesterday in which you listed again the measures that you have taken. We stand with the Commission, and I am particularly grateful to you for the concluding remark in which you said: Myanmar is a young democracy. I doubt it's a democracy yet. The military has the upper hand and Aung San Suu Kyi is unfortunately not a full head of government, but is the President's Special Representative and Foreign Minister. Therefore, their possibilities of influence are unfortunately limited. We visited them in spring and were able to see for ourselves how difficult the process is. Today it's on the agenda. It is right to sanction the military leadership. It is right to enforce returns to Bangladesh. It is right to give humanitarian aid to the Rohingya. It is right to look again at the devastating situation in February. We therefore support all of your activities, Ms. Mogherini, and we hope that there will soon be a sensible solution for the Rohingya minority.

name: Soraya POST
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the situation of the Rohingya people is our grave concern. As people, as politicians, as human rights defenders, it is our obligation to take immediate action. I am happy to hear the Commissioner talking about the action taken, but I do not think it is enough. We have to speed up. It is our obligation to end the ongoing genocide in Myanmar. We have to use every tool available – arms embargo, punitive sanctions, trade agreements – and we have to strive for justice for the Rohingya people. Six hundred and fifty thousand Rohingyas have fled their homes, their villages set on fire with petrol bombs. They have endured rape as a weapon of war; they have seen sex trafficking of women and the kidnapping of children who are being sold as sex slaves. The military forces cannot have impunity. They need to be put on trial. As for the Nobel Peace Prize winner Aung San Suu Kyi, her prize should be withdrawn if she does not stop her silence. The Rohingya people need to be recognised as an ethnic minority in Myanmar and should be compensated for all the violence they have been facing. It is now up to us, the international community, to give justice to the Rohingya people. As human rights are universal, so also our solidarity should be universal.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, if anyone questions whether what is happening in Myanmar is ethnic cleansing, I say look for the hallmarks. Men and boys separated and murdered, women and girls raped and disfigured as a means of subjugation and control, homes and crops burnt, whole villages destroyed overnight and left smouldering and stinking of death. At the last plenary I called for a point of order to have another debate and another resolution, but this time should be the last. Last week, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights said that an act of genocide cannot be ruled out. Last week, Alex  Crawford, this extraordinary Sky News correspondent who went under cover in Myanmar, testified at my conference that of all humanitarian crises this is probably the worst she has ever witnessed. And still the world wrings its hands over how to respond. We cannot let this suffering be met with only shrugged shoulders and bleeding hearts. The EU can be powerful in galvanising a global response, but to do so it must lead, not look for middle ground. That voice must roar not whisper. There can be no repatriation of the one million refugees unless they are recognised first as citizens of Myanmar and unless the UN is present as well as the media and humanitarian NGOs. That is why I hope that our motion can persuade the Commission and Council to use their good offices in calling for an international summit on the Rohingya. One day, our grandchildren may ask how we used that power, when a whole population has been killed and persecuted. Please let us choose to have an answer that is decent and honourable.

name: Urmas PAET
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the situation in Myanmar is horrific. The Rohingya people are being killed and repressed, their rights denied, their homes burnt, people are starving and stuck at the border and those that have managed to flee to Bangladesh are in dire need of help.  The killings and violence must stop immediately. Those responsible must be held accountable by international tribunal. Even though an agreement has been signed between Bangladesh and Myanmar, more is needed. Before any Rohingya refugees can return, there must be credible assurances that they can do so voluntarily, safely and under full UN oversight. Landmines must be removed immediately, if needed with the help of the international community. There needs to be a time frame for the provision of citizenship rights. Monitoring of the situation of the Rohingyas in Myanmar by human rights bodies and helping them by NGOs and relief agencies should be allowed. Humanitarian aid must continue, the EU, its Member States and the international community must increase financial and material support for the refugees and their accommodation. And we need to increase the pressure on Myanmar. The European Union should adopt punitive sanctions against those responsible for human rights abuses in Myanmar, prolong the existing arms embargo and suspend trade preferences and the negotiations on the EU-Myanmar investment treaty. One more thought: the role of Aung San Suu Kyi has been extremely disappointing. We should seriously start a discussion on the possibility of reversing international awards – the Nobel Prize, the Sakharov Prize – in these kinds of situations. It makes no sense that a person that has received such an honorary award is now also responsible for ethnic cleansing.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. President, “My name is Kamal, I am seven years old. In the village where I lived, the policemen and soldiers came, ordered us to go into our houses and they shot. The bullets went through the walls. I received several bullets in the body. Then they set our houses on fire. My panicked father hugged me and my five-year-old brother to hide in the yard and returned to the house to look for my twin sister and older brother, but my father came out alone. Today, he and I live in a camp. We are afraid, we are hungry. I miss my mother, my brother and my twin sister ”. Madam Vice-President, I hope that these children, in order to grow up, will be able to somewhat forget these horrors, which will forever haunt their childhood memories. But it is up to us, today, to act and to proclaim our indignation for all the Kamal, the Mohammed, the Nacira, the Yasmine, for all the children born Rohingya, so that this unspeakable injustice and this ethnic cleansing in the Myanmar finally cease.
