Senior politicians up on Capitol Hill said to me: ‘the army will be used to shore up your external EU borders, right? Or clamp down on radical Islamic extremism, those men raping and assaulting women and Jews, those terrorists that are blowing you up. Is that what your money is going to be used for?’ I said no, it won’t be to protect the citizens. It will be spent on vanity sabre—rattling by Verhofstadt, Juncker and that gender-quota recycled Communist, the high priestess Ms Mogherini. Be afraid! Yeah, I’ve got your attention now. Be afraid when they get their hands on the weapons!

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - I am reading this report and I learn that we are threatened and even being waged against us by some hybrid war. I don't know what a hybrid war is, I haven't found it anywhere, but I know that Russia is supposed to do it. Well, Russia in Syria did not do any hybrid war, it just sent planes, helped to crash the self-proclaimed caliphate and simply took the planes, withdrew its troops, which the report does not mention at all. But I have a second question: If hybrid warfare is so dangerous and dangerous, why don't we do hybrid warfare? I don't see a hybrid war being planned by the European Union. Why is the European Union not doing some hybrid war, not responding with hybrid war to hybrid wars? There is simply no such thing, it is just about military orders, and I suspect that it is simply about taking bribes for supplies again, and that is for tanks, something more or less needed, as long as there are bribes for politicians. And that is probably the purpose of establishing this PESCO.

name: Julia PITERA
text: - Mr Chairman! According to a recent Eurobarometer survey, Europeans are deeply concerned about geopolitical developments in the world. 68% of those polled want the European Union to do more for security and defense. The unstable situation in the world requires a more conscious and responsible Union focused on foreign policy and security. Both the McAllister and Gahler reports underline that in an increasingly conflicted and unstable international environment, it is important to combine effective EU projects and action to tackle major challenges. It is also important to maintain the EU's tough stance on sanctions against Russia. Thus, I welcome the conclusion by the European Council of the agreement on the implementation of the PESCO Permanent Structured Cooperation mechanism and the creation of a European defense industrial development program. Both of these initiatives are an opportunity to increase the military capabilities of European countries and increase investment in defense. Finally, let me ask a question about the consistency of new projects and greater involvement of European Union Member States with their obligations towards NATO.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, many thanks to David McAllister and Michael Gahler for trusting and productive cooperation. The McAllister report sums it up: it is about a combination of effective multilateralism, joint soft power and credible hard power. That's exactly what it's all about: the combination of soft power and hard power. We can be proud of our soft power, and we must continue to develop it in the future. Because it's not about a pendulum that now swings from soft power to hard power, as if one was yesterday's news, so to speak, and the other our future, but rather both. But it just doesn't work without hard power. There is a lot to do. How can we work better in the EU? More efficiently, for example, through joint procurement and research. I simply do not leave it as it is when Mrs Lösing from the GUE Group makes the same false claims every time, as if we were trying to set in motion an arms spiral here, and then leaves the room because the debate is not really about it Interested. In this respect, we should not allow this to be offered to us without contradiction. "The world is out of joint," said a former German Foreign Minister. We can no longer rely on the US alone. We must take security in Europe and around the EU into our own hands. That is fair to the USA and unfortunately also necessary, especially since the US President is increasingly developing from a guarantor of security to a security risk. We will have to discuss a lot more. What financial contribution will the Member States make? What role does parliament have to play in concrete terms, and how will we shape the joint project of limiting and controlling arms exports? We made a good start. In essence, we have that to you, Mrs Mogherini owe you to your clear, straight line and your tenacity.You have the confidence of the major groups in the next steps, even if they will not be uncritical.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: - The Council decided that PESCO should be inclusive and ambitious, that is, involve many countries in cooperation, and at the same time bring tangible results. How can this be achieved? Well, in my opinion, it is necessary to negotiate the participation criteria and the principles of PESCO management to ensure equal influence of states on the directions of cooperation development, in particular military capability development programs and sustainable development of the defense industry of all EU states. Second, there are unacceptable attempts to use PESCO's cover to soften the commitments made in NATO. This and the lack of synchronization of PESCO with the NATO defense planning process may significantly undermine the political cohesion of the alliance. And from the point of view of the security of the eastern flank, projects to support the mobility of troops and equipment initiated under PESCO should be analyzed more closely. Harmonious action and quick decision-making in this matter is crucial for the security of Central and Eastern Europe.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: - Mrs Mogherini, I am very pleased that, in the year of the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome, we can make very concrete steps forward in our common security and defense policy. And let's be honest, this was necessary, absolutely necessary, because if we just counted out, together with the 28 countries, we spent 45% of the US defense budget with an output - you said it yourself - of only 15%. Then we all know that we can do much more and much better if we do it together. We have made more progress in the last two years than in the past 30 years. That is, of course, a result of the security challenges at our borders, but also of President Trump's election and statements. Of course, Brexit will also play a role. I am especially very happy, Mrs Mogherini, with PESCO. We say to us: "The Sleeping Beauty has awakened". Invest together, research together, develop together, deploy together. That is what Europe must and can do. Very concrete projects with 25 countries together. But we wouldn't be ALDE, and I wouldn't be I if I didn't want to be even more ambitious. Mrs. Mogherini, I have said it many times here: "I have a dream". I have a dream that within ten years we will have a European army instead of probably 27 national armies. I hope you will join the cart. Go for it! You have our support. (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Mrs Vautmans, thank you for taking my question. To quote what you have just said: ‘Sleeping Beauty has finally woken up’. Does that not underline the military ambitions, the federal ambitions of this place? What would you say to the citizens? My country, thankfully, is leaving the European Union, but what would you say to the citizens of Sweden, of Austria, of the Republic of Ireland – neutral countries, traditionally neutral countries – what would you say to them about the direction of the European Union?

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: "blue card" answer.- First and foremost, of course, let me answer that I still deeply regret that your country is leaving the European Union and that I am also convinced that the new, young generation in Great Britain will want to return to Europe in ten years.I am convinced of that and I hope so.And, second point, what I say to those neutral countries is very simple.We will be carrying out very concrete projects with 25 of the 28 countries that will also benefit their safety.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, my family knows a little about common European defence: my grandmother saw Zeppelins over Tipton in the West Midlands; my great-grandfather left Lancashire to be a tunneller in the First World War; my grandfather Herbert Etheridge served in a tank and helped to liberate Europe from oppression in the Second World War. We know that the UK has never, ever shirked its responsibility to Europe. Whilst we may be leaving the EU, we will never shirk our responsibility to keep Europe free. We have an excellent defence alliance: it’s called NATO. We work with the last remaining superpower in the world, the United States, to protect freedom in Europe and other places. Despite the fact that our treacherous United Kingdom Government is deliberately and systematically running down our defences, we still do not require a union such as this. This is purely a political union to create a United States of Europe that the people of Europe were never consulted about. What I would say to you is very simple: no British Government should ever commit to this. No British money should ever be spent on this. And not one single drop of British blood should ever be spilled in a cause that is not directly in the remit of ‘for Queen and country.’

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: - Mr Chairman! Politicians are very eager to say what people like to hear. And this is exactly what the topic of common defense policy is. But let's say something about the realities of this topic. After all, politics is competition, so threats and conflicts are, in a sense, its nature and essence. Moreover, on a global scale, politics is precisely the field that generates conflicts and threats. And these threats are very different for different countries: completely different for Greece, different for Poland, different somewhere in Belgium or the Netherlands. Therefore, the implementation of something like a common defense policy is only another step on the way to liquidate the sovereignty of European countries. And that's true about the process we're starting. The European states have already been deprived of the possibility to decide on monetary and fiscal policy and legislation. Yet foreign and defense policy will be taken away and European states will become a fiction. Europe will resemble the United States, but only in the sense that European countries will be like some set of American Indian reservations. In each reserve you will be able to sing different songs and wear different costumes, but these will not be yours anymore. And, unfortunately, in politics, they do not only beat those who give up without hitting. This is exactly what the European Union offers to Europe. A disaster!

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: - Mr President, no matter how much you use the words peace and defense, the European Union cannot hide. You can not hide that you are intensifying preparations for new imperialist wars and attacks on peoples. A dangerously complex Euro-military Union network is being built in addition to NATO and independently, with a separate fund, funding and performance appraisal mechanisms to skin the peoples and strengthen military equipment, with an upgraded, structured military framework and headquarters, with flexible units for immediate military action where they claim the profits of European groups in their intensifying competition with the US, China, Russia and within the European Union. Boiling hotbeds are multiplying in this territory; Syria, Iraq, Libya, Ukraine, Yemen and again Palestine, Turkey's provocations are just some of them. The Greek government, by giving bases, land and water to the imperialist plans, seeks upgraded profits for the Greek groups, upgrading the risks for the peoples. No rest within the European Union and NATO! Popular struggle, vigilance, not to shed the blood of peoples for imperialist interests.

name: Michèle ALLIOT-MARIE
text: - Mr President, Madam High Representative, I am particularly pleased that the various institutions of the European Union have finally realized the dangers that threaten us - the current dangers and the future dangers - and therefore the urgent need to acquire a security and defense policy that is at the same time strong, credible and structured. We can congratulate ourselves that, thanks to your commitment, also thanks to the actions of each other, we are able to present concrete measures today, in particular through the two excellent reports that were made on this subject: capacity building of the Defense Union, permanent structured cooperation, the establishment of a European Defense Fund or the launch of the European industrial development program in the field of defense. But the most important thing is, indeed, for Europe to move concretely and permanently in this direction, in order to finally be able to better protect its fellow citizens in the future. The problem - this was underlined, in particular, by the Committee on Budgets - is that the funds earmarked for this are actually, really used. So, Madam High Representative, I would like to ask you one thing: are you ready to do, before this Parliament, the annual review of what has been done, through a report from the Commission to Parliament, which will allow us to follow what will have really been realized and what would have been misappropriated, because funds would have been used, as in recent years, for policies other than that of defense and security?

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: - Mr Chairman! Madam High Representative! Every year, in this Chamber, we evaluate European foreign policy, and one of the elements of this policy is, of course, security and defense policy. As a rule, these assessments were cautious and critical. It was clear to the naked eye that the Union's capabilities did not correspond either to the increasing scale of tasks or the increasingly complex challenge of ensuring the security of the Union and Europe. After all, this year it can be said that there is a chance to overcome this powerlessness, for real and stronger cooperation. This is confirmed, inter alia, by the establishment of permanent structured cooperation PESCO. If we are wondering what this cooperation can bring, I would like to draw attention to the fact that in the long run, the effects of research and development and implementation of modern technologies may be particularly important. Today we have two problems. The first is that defense spending is too low in Europe, and the second is that too little is spent very badly. This is illustrated by the fact that every year all EU countries spend 40% of the US defense budget, and unfortunately our effectiveness is only 15%. Therefore, if this cooperation is effective and real, and not apparent, then I think we have a chance to break the tendency that Europe has a chance for greater autonomy in terms of security and defense. And if we could achieve it together, it would be a great joint success.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: - Mister President! The EU's common foreign and security policy has many facets. I welcome closer cooperation in the area of ​​procurement as well as research. It makes a lot of sense. It also makes a lot of sense that within the EU we should complement our diverse defense capabilities; not everyone has to have every specialization. But the whole thing has absolute upper limits. I say explicitly that with the current state of the EU - this state of division - I cannot see at all how we can talk about a common EU army at the moment. That doesn't make sense at the moment, we should get away from it. That would even be dangerous, because it suggests that we have a clout that we then would not have. Instead, we need to strengthen cooperation in NATO. NATO was and is the guarantee for peace and freedom, especially in Europe. Therefore, we need to focus on it and only take the steps that we can actually take in a reasonable direction.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Mr President, common EU action is needed to safeguard Europe’s security, tackle complex challenges, protect its interests and its citizens, and to defend its values. EU defence cooperation is necessary and the timing is right for this.  That is why yesterday’s decision by the Council to adopt the decision establishing PESCO is of the utmost importance. It creates the much-needed opportunity for 25 Member States to work together on defence projects, to cooperate more in defence and security, to invest in shared projects, and to enhance the operational readiness and contribution of their armed forces.  Cyber defence has become one of the most critical issues in debates about defence modernisation and Europe’s common defence efforts. This needs cooperation and it is good that the newly established PESCO foresees projects in the cyber defence domain. In addition, joint training exercises between the EU Member States are vital in the area of cyber defence to build trust and understanding of possible cyber threats and challenges, as demonstrated by the training organised by the Estonian Presidency. The EU needs to have a clear plan that encompasses EU—NATO cooperation on cyber defence, cyber defence training and exercises, the promotion of civil military cooperation and the applicability of international law to cyberspace.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: - Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, ladies and gentlemen! In Germany we have a defense minister, Ms. von der Leyen, who has put the German Bundeswehr in a state in which submarines do not dive, helicopters do not fly, just as fighter planes and tanks have failed. The only progress that could be reported in the German Bundeswehr in recent years was the introduction of maternity uniforms for soldiers. Now, of all people, two representatives of the same party as Mrs von der Leyen, namely Mr Gahler and Mr McAllister, have been charged with bringing you closer to European defense policy. Well then cheers! So far, NATO has been supposed to help secure the security of Europe as a defense alliance, and it has done so as a defense alliance. However, where it did not defend, but instead actively intervened in third countries, it caused more problems than solved. There is a lot of talk about hybrid wars. The answer to hybrid wars is not classic armies. On the contrary, it would be the reintroduction of military service, also in Germany. A defense fund, that sounds nice. What is actually planned here is something else: aggressive capacities in the hands of some EU officials. I refuse.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Madam President, first of all, the promoted common security and defense policy does not have the required democratic legitimacy and does not express the popular will of the citizens of the Member States. Those who evangelize and support it act as self-appointed proxies, lack popular consent and violate the basic principles governing the law of the Treaties, such as the principles of equality of peoples, sovereign equality and independence of states and non-interference in their internal affairs. . But I would especially like to point out two basic conditions that govern military alliances and organizations. Firstly, there is no mention in the texts of what the Union's position will be in the event of a heated incident or crisis / conflict between Member States. Secondly, whether the Union will safeguard the territorial integrity and cohesion of a Member State in the event of an attack by a third country. If these two key questions are not answered, I see no reason why Member States should consent to their participation and pursue common European defense and security.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, my appreciation and thanks to both distinguished rapporteurs for a very good job. I am glad that we have moved quickly over the last year on security and defence policy. Earlier this year, we launched the European Defence Fund and yesterday we launched the permanent structured cooperation (PESCO). To this end, I would like to welcome yesterday’s Council decision on establishing PESCO and the commitments given by the Member States. I would like to congratulate the High Representative for her work and dedication to this important project. Security and defence has once again become the underlying issue of the EU integration project. It is clear that no single Member State can tackle the complex security challenges we are facing today alone. In order for the EU to be able to respond in internal and external challenges, we need to step up cooperation, pool our resources and focus on strategy priorities. I am aware that it will take time to reach full cooperation. However, the first projects to come out of the initiative, especially in the areas of training, capacity development and operational readiness, seem to be promising. In order to make full use of this cooperation, we will need to care about the seeds which we already sowed. This would also mean establishing fully—fledged EU civilian—military strategic structures, support from the Union budget and trust and cooperation on the side of the Member States.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Madam President, congratulations to the rapporteurs on the encouraging reports. Based on several initiatives in the past year, Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty, which is the common denominator of today's debate, is becoming increasingly important. At the meeting of 25 member ministers, joint cooperation in defense was agreed, the proposal of the Defense Fund was presented, and we adopted the Report on the Instrument for Stability and Peace. These significant shifts have almost exceeded the expectations of even the most optimistic among us who worked on the European Defense Union Report. I would like to emphasize the importance of continuing a credible enlargement process as the best guarantor of security on the Union's south-eastern borders, but also within the European Union. I also emphasize the need for clear communication of these achievements. It is not about the militarization of the European project or the European army. It is about meeting the expectations of more than two thirds of our citizens who prioritize security as a priority. We have duplicated actions for too long and spent resources uncoordinated. The needs for a European Defense Union are therefore justified and initiatives that deliver real content should be supported.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen! In our discussion today, one thread actually keeps coming back: building alternative, and in the first stage, perhaps just parallel military structures to the Atlantic Alliance in Europe. Some are very happy about it, others are very afraid of it. And I propose to ask one realistic question: will even such alternative - let alone parallel - military structures replace the United States at these most inflammatory and most sensitive points for European security? So far, we have seen something else in eastern Ukraine. During the Minsk peace talks, the most important countries in the European Union readily agreed to Russia's wishes that neither Poland nor any other European Union member state in a quarter of Russia be there that directly neighbor Russia or Ukraine. First, let's take care of solidarity. Then we will build instruments.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr McAllister and Mr Gahler on their good reports. I agree with them on the need for a common and coherent Union policy at the external level to defend the interests and principles of Europeans and effectively face the complex challenges and threats of today's world. The political weight and influence of the Union does not correspond to our important economic, commercial weight, in terms of development cooperation and humanitarian aid. An effective implementation of the Global Strategy approved last year seems to me the way to follow for the full development of the potential of our foreign action and the deepening in the field of defense. I welcome, as many have already said, the significant progress made in recent months, and in particular the launch yesterday of permanent structured cooperation in the Foreign Affairs Council. We will thus be stronger and have more response capacity as our citizens demand. That is why I congratulate you, Mrs Mogherini. One of our main external priorities is instability in the neighborhood, both southern and eastern. We also have global interests and we cannot stop acting in any region. The transatlantic axis is a key element of our foreign action. That is why, as Mr McAllister's report calls for, important links with the United States must be preserved. It is also relevant to increase our presence in the vast space of Asia-Pacific, whose stability we also need. We are in times of rapid change, uncertainty and serious threats such as terrorism and climate change. The Union must be able to respond to the concerns and interests of its citizens and be a global actor committed to multilateralism that helps generate peace, stability and prosperity.

name: Clare MOODY
text: – Madam President, these reports are very timely reflections on the progress that is being made at a European level on foreign policy, security and defence. Both the McAllister and Gahler reports highlight the effectiveness of working together at an EU level towards peace and security in our increasingly troubled world. Contrary to earlier statements by europhobic politicians, it is in the interests of all of us that the EU strengthens its position on the world stage. I also welcome the fact that both reports are looking to achieve a defence cooperation relationship between the EU and the UK in future. I sincerely hope that this will be achieved in both the industrial sphere, but also in the political decision-making sphere in these areas.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank our rapporteurs, Mr Michael Gahler and David McAllister, who have made an excellent report, and to you, Mrs Mogherini, I would like to quote you once. It is true, as you once said, that these are times of predictable unpredictability. We are really facing great challenges. Western democracies face great challenges. There are a lot of topics, from the situation or relations with Russia, China, the eastern neighborhood, then relations in Latin America itself (yesterday we talked about the Sakharov Prize related to Venezuela), then North Korea, Crimea, Ukraine ... For everything that is happening we need to find answers at the moment and therefore I really support these latest initiatives, which have been going on for several years, but I still return to the speech on the state of the Union made by Mr Juncker here in September in this House announcing the completion of the European Defense Union. I think that together with the European Defense Fund and together with this initiative on PESCO, we will certainly succeed in completing the European Defense Union by 2025. What makes me especially happy is that the Lisbon Treaty is in force, that it has made this possible for us, and also that this initiative takes place at the time of marking the 60th anniversary of the Treaties of Rome and is in a way a complete whole. Likewise, I want to say that we must respond to the concerns of our citizens. Their main concern is security, which they showed in a Eurostat survey, and we must respond to such initiatives. I therefore support this initiative.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: - Madam President! Mrs. Mogherini! It is important that there is a decision-making power in the EU when there are rapid changes in societal development and when risks arise or emerge. It can be about refugee crises, climate crises, but of course also security policy crises. However, as we live in a Europe of great diversity in this area as well, it is at least as important for this cohesion and this responsiveness that cooperation within Pesco remains intergovernmental. New institutional structures must be avoided. Assignments within the so-called common defense and security policy must be about peace and conflict prevention outside the EU. I'm not ashamed to say that I come from a country where we have lived in peace for over 200 years. This has meant that we have taken great responsibility for those who have not been able to live in peace, and I am not ashamed of that, and I demand intergovernmentalism in this area. Why should we be forced into war?

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Do we have the right to be optimistic? In my opinion, no. We have a duty to be realistic, and it is worth on this occasion to see what the previous reports looked like, what the votes were like and what ended with the adoption of the previous reports. Probably, in a sense, we will have an identical situation, that is, we will adopt the report, we will note with some satisfaction some kind of progress, while what will be the key is the next day, i.e. the day of implementation. I must say that today in the European Parliament we are de facto debating three issues at the same time: The creation of a common defense policy practically anew - after the experience in Crimea, after the experience in Ukraine, after the experience of emigrants and terrorism. Secondly, we note how we need new technology, our own research programs, our own strengthening of the defense industry and how important this new technology is to improve the security of us Europeans. And the third element is cooperation with NATO. Undoubtedly, what we are talking about today is not a substitute for NATO, it is not a duplication of functions, it is the right, additional component that is to build the security policy. And the last thing - what worries me in the room. Too often, security policy is equated with defense policy. Security and defense expenses are not always and not necessarily military expenses.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Federica Mogherini is right to be satisfied, and we, Parliament, are satisfied with her. Because today Altiero Spinelli's dream of a common European defense is within reach, after years in which any ambition was branded as politically impracticable. Today France, which once rejected the proposal, is as strongly pro-European as Italy and many other countries are. Britain is no longer an obstacle and Trump's United States has abdicated its role as stabilizers of the world, quite the contrary. So today it is the European Union that has the moral leadership of international diplomacy, and it is a title sealed by the Nobel Peace Prize in 2012, by Mogherini's excellent work on the field, and also by the will that you have reiterated here today - is This was a very difficult point, but for us in our group it was important - to use these instruments of power, even military, "in the European style", so it has been said, that is, in respect of our values. The signature of the defense ministers, the start of structured cooperation, the plan of action are historic, but we know that we are still a long way off, that many delays must be bridged and well filled. And I am also thinking of research for a strategic autonomy of Europe. I end here by saying that we know that many illiberal powers grow militarily and increase their power in this world. It is up to us to play a different game - I am thinking of Africa and Libya - to be truly a Europe capable of hard and soft power.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: - Madam President, I welcome the creation of a permanent structured cooperation, PESCO, which was officially consecrated yesterday. I am glad that my country, the Czech Republic, will also join this cooperation. For many years, after the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, we just stomped on the spot. Only an unprecedented number of conventional and hybrid challenges have forced us to reflect on our common potential and take action. No Member State alone is able to solve the complex security problems we are currently facing. That is why I agree with the clear and ambitious message of my colleague Gahler's report. For example, the names of threats are clear, be it terrorism, Russia's ongoing war against Ukraine, illegal annexation and militarization of Crimea, or North Korea's nuclear threat. It is also clear in the list of steps that should be followed to ensure our common security. I attach great importance to strengthening the mandate of the common security and defense policy missions and to reforming their financing. Their mandate should also include the fight against terrorism and support for the deradicalisation program. We also need to look at greater cooperation between these missions and Europol and Frontex. This is particularly important in the fight against international smuggling.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: - Madam president. Today we are discussing two very important reports to define the future of that defense union, just the day after twenty-five States of the Union agreed to put this permanent cooperation in place with the leadership of the High Representative, Mrs. Mogherini. It coincides with the drive by the Commission and this Parliament to promote this European Defense Fund that will improve investment in research and consolidate a single market to improve the Union's industrial capacity. And I believe that this should not be taken as a military escalation or as a militaristic vocation of the European Union, but quite the opposite. Because if we are able to jointly manage the defense, we can, in many cases, reduce the volume of financing, making it more efficient. And I think it is very important that in this new agenda we are aware that defense is already a part directly linked to security policies. Or put another way, that security policies and defense policies are not radically different. And that line in which the global strategy and the high representative work is a very essential part of the future of the Union.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to Ms Mogherini that these impressive and constructive reports are first of all about implementation. For that, our foreign policies need to be based on fundamental values. Mainstreaming human rights and EU values in relations with third countries, and making any progress in economic and political relations conditional on a convincing improvement in partner countries’ human rights records, should be a key element of the CFSP. There is, for example, a striking imbalance from that perspective in current Iran-EU relations. Second, a credible common policy means speaking with one voice and without delay. Our report concludes that the current decision—making process in the EU Council is the main obstacle to effective and timely external EU action. That means that qualified majority voting should also be applied for common foreign, security and defence policies. Third, we call on the EU institutions to enhance their ability to anticipate conflicts and rely more on long-term impact assessments of EU policies. This is especially relevant to hybrid warfare and disinformation. This means turning the StratCom Task Force into a fully—fledged unit within the EEAS, giving it all necessary support. Finally, sanctions are part of efficient EU policies. I propose that we should make these more efficient, targeting concrete individuals responsible for breaking international laws and human rights violations – a type of Magnitsky list.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Mr President, permanent structured cooperation with 25 Member States, including mine, has finally opened, committing to invest in defense synergies, an area in which the European Union must respond as citizens demand. No Member State has the resources to defend itself when transnational threats multiply in a world dependent on digital technology, which makes it imperative to invest in the cybersecurity and cyberdefense dimensions, including the protection of critical infrastructure and the resilience of our democracies in the face of terrorism and to hybrid war. This cooperation has to translate into a strengthening of the European Union's strategic autonomy and the European defense industrial base and more value for the money that our taxpayers already spend on national military equipment and capabilities. This Parliament must assume the responsibility of democratic control to guarantee trust, effectiveness and respect for international legality, in the CFSP, in the CEP and in the Common Security and Defense Policy.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: - We are living in a tense period that is particularly difficult in terms of external threats: terrorism, cyber attacks, aggressive Russia, unstable North Africa and the Middle East, which is shrouded in war and conflict. As a result, NATO remains the most important guarantor of security and defense in Europe. However, the European Union must also invest in strengthening the security of its members, as the tense security situation calls for a proactive response from the European Union. I am very pleased that yesterday, as many as twenty-five Member States took the formal decision to set up a new defense and security cooperation network, the Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO), that the initial seventeen specific projects were agreed upon. Congratulations, p. Federica Mogherini, and thank you. These decisions are a sign that Member States are committed to developing defense capabilities and increasing defense investment. Undoubtedly, there is a need to exploit and strengthen real cooperation between NATO and the European Union. Among the priority areas of cooperation, I see military transit, cyber defense, response to hybrid threats and coordination in the field of strategic communication. Security and defense are an area of ​​our lives where the European Union must hold its destiny firmly in its hands. I thank my colleagues David McAllister and Michael Gahler for their excellent reports.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: - Madam President! I very much regret that the report on the implementation of the common security and distribution policy only deals very marginally with the problem of arms exports. Yesterday, Chancellor Merkel publicly expressed her interest in standardizing the arms export criteria and guidelines in Europe. I think it's good that she is taking up the topic, but I expect from her that at least the existing European export criteria are also complied with by Germany. We cannot develop a coherent European foreign policy if the EU member states continue to export arms and ammunition to third countries in an uncoordinated manner. I have tabled amendments on this matter which, unfortunately, have not been included in the report by the rapporteur. In it I called on the member states to jointly decide within a European framework to which countries they would export arms. The European Parliament should also be involved in decisions on the export of armaments that are to be co-financed from the EU budget under the European Defense Fund. This also corresponds to a reflection paper of the S&D group on security and distribution policy from November this year.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: - Madam President, I congratulate my colleagues McAllister and Gahler on their excellent reports, which point to the importance of strengthening the common external, security and defense component of the European Union. Events and tensions in our neighborhood and the current security threats posed by terrorist threats, as well as migration crises that raise tensions in the Member States, call for effective responses to our citizens. It is high time to improve the joint coordinated capacities of the Member States of our Union. The European Union must play a more active role in stopping potential open conflicts at its borders, which could in turn lead to new waves of refugees, as well as instabilities in the future. If it wants to strengthen its global role, EU diplomacy must show its strength in the immediate neighborhood like Bosnia and Herzegovina, where even after twenty-two years we have no solution to get out of the Frankenstein structure of a constitution that froze war and brought imperfect peace. different visions of the past, and the future is still pending.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, European defense policy has taken concrete steps forward this year and is very positive and welcome. It is time for Europe to take more responsibility for its own defense as well. Undoubtedly, we can achieve significant economic and security benefits precisely by better planning defense together, directing procurement more together and responding to broad security policy challenges, complementing NATO's work. However, I would like to address in particular one issue that has also been raised in this meritorious Gahler report: that is Article 42.7 on common defense. Its content is still completely undefined, and we know that it is interpreted very differently by the Member States. As early as two years ago, the European Parliament called on the Commission to launch preparations that clearly defined responsibilities, operational processes and guidelines for the interpretation of that article. I would now like to ask High Representative Mogherini whether the Commission has launched any such work. If you have to use that article and want to use it, the process would be quite confusing, because there is no ready-made approach.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Madam President, Madam High Representative, indeed, the instability in the Middle East, poverty in Africa, the madness of some dictators and many other subjects, including the rise of terrorism and cyber attacks, should alert us again more on European defense issues. I add that the attitude of Donald Trump in the United States requires us to think again, because the European Union cannot remain defenseless. Even though we are all deeply pacifists, unfortunately we do not live on the planet of care bears. We must unleash the full potential of the Lisbon Treaty in this area and ensure permanent structured cooperation, a prelude to real common European defense, including cyber defense. Two projects deserve to be highlighted: the preparatory action on research and, of course, the project to pool military equipment in order to save money. These are important first steps, but we must go further. Of course, we have to find new money and not tap into the structural policies of the European Union.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Mr President, High Representative!Anyone who knows me knows: A clumsy “More Europe” is not my thing.I want a Europe that delivers.And that is precisely why I expressly welcome the increase in European defense policy - for peace, not as a pure arms supplier.I would like to express my gratitude to the defense policy experts of the Free Voters for their technical input.I welcome PESCO.Today 25 of the 28 Member States are already on board.I welcome the agreed priorities, from cybersecurity to training and the joint emergency center.It is also important for me to develop the technical structures in order to understand each other in the multitude of languages.In contrast, I see the headquarters in Brussels as critical.We already have command centers, including one in Neu-Ulm, which have experience and do successful work.These structures should be strengthened.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: - Madam President, permanent structured cooperation was presented as 'the ultimate' in terms of European independent defense. It seems to me that it will be one more bluff in terms of independence and, at least, as bluff as the Eurocorps was. Do you remember that European army created in 1991 by France, Germany, Belgium and Spain? And today it is just one part of the NATO Response Force. I am not saying it, you are saying it: strengthening the European pillar of the Alliance; deepen cooperation with NATO. Or, as the High Representative says, we cooperate more than ever with NATO. The EU replies and repeats like a parrot what NATO says. They ask us for 2%: we give it. They ask us for military mobility, a military Schengen: we say that we are going to work together with NATO. Look, we are not going to have more security with NATO; on the contrary, it is the denial of a common European security space. More military spending will mean more arms race. We have almost 507 million people, and what they do is put a tutor on it, make a subordinate European Union of geopolitical interests on the other side of the Atlantic.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - The years 2016 and 2017 are in fact ground-breaking from the point of view of the common security and defense policy. Thanking the co-rapporteurs, I would like to say at this point that we are all convinced that defense and security policy will not run counter to what NATO is doing. We believe that these activities should be coordinated. Today, with growing tensions, a renewed Common Security and Defense Policy may be the missing common denominator for many countries. The fact that 25 Member States are signing it is clear evidence of this. Moreover, it seems to me that common security and defense policy initiatives must respect the specificities of the Member States, integrate them widely, and not necessarily divide them, although there are often differences in some areas. Regarding the fund, I would like to say that it should provide an opportunity not only for large concerns, but also for small and medium-sized enterprises. Therefore, thank you for the provision in Art. 22 reports by the European Parliament on the implementation of the common security and defense policy.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: - Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, 25 Member States have endorsed the joint declaration known as PESCO. Purpose: a more comprehensive cooperation at European level with European orientations. Member States can maintain their own defense and exercise their sovereignty better through European cooperation, through synergies and savings, which will definitely improve the effectiveness of defense and, consequently, foreign policy. Of course, as the European Union we have challenges and risks, such as securing our external borders, energy security, terrorism and much more. For all this we can work together and have results so that we can all be better. For those referring to NATO, I make a very simple comparison: If Member States cooperate within NATO, I am sure they can cooperate better within the European Union as well.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Madam President, I think the tone is wrong here. I have to say that this is a sad day as an Irish citizen. This was meant to be a peace project and now it is to become a never-ending military project. And you’ve said it yourself, Ms Mogherini, missions can only grow into the future. Will you be paying for them, or will it be the ordinary people of Europe who can barely feed themselves who will be paying for it? It will be more cost, more resources, at a time in Ireland where we have record homelessness figures, where we have record hospital waiting lists. We then have a so-called socialist, an S&D Member, suggesting that this should become the most ambitious project of the Union. What about food security? What about climate change? But no, the most important thing is military – weapons, guns and bombs. The language used by Jean—Claude Juncker was no better. He used the word ‘beauty’. What’s beautiful about this? We should be spending the money on areas that need it, not on guns: on food, on housing and health. Not on death. Shame on you!

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: I'm sorry,but heredoes not allowsuchmanifestationsfrom beyondthe gallery,thatI ask youto exercise restraint.

name: Andor DELI
text: - Ms. President!I am pleased to note that the McAllister report speaks in a positive tone about the Western Balkans and places due emphasis on addressing the security challenges facing the region.I also share the rapporteur's view that stability and security in the Western Balkans must remain a priority for the EU as well.European integration processes have made a major contribution to maintaining regional peace and security.I particularly welcome the part of the report which proposes to the Commission the need to increase the pre-accession funds, the IPA funds, as it is unrealistic for the European Parliament to spend more annually on maintaining its two seats than, for example, the largest candidate country., Serbia will receive an annual IPA to support all ongoing reform measures.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Ms. President!It is also part of the political coherence of the European Union that the aim of the EU efforts we are discussing must be to guarantee European citizens the opportunity and security of life within the framework of a democratic rule of law based on our common values.strengthening its role.However, all this can only be a credible Community aspiration if, in the meantime, we can take joint and effective action within the Union against the phenomena of violations of democratic rights, mockery of European values and corrupt and authoritarian governance.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: - Madam President, the security of the European Union is a basic precondition for development in all areas of European society. Congratulations to Mr. McAllister, Mr. Gahler and Mr. Danjean, who have worked on this dossier for a very long time, persistently and with quality. Congratulations to Ms. Mogherini who wisely leads the process of improving defense and security policy. Initiating permanent structural cooperation is indeed an important step forward. It is important to pay special attention to the Western Balkans and ensure that these countries already pursue a common security and defense policy. It is important, furthermore, that hard and soft power go hand in hand, as the High Commissioner says, because so far we have been emphatically stronger in soft power. It is important, furthermore, to invest in closing the gaps in defense capabilities, to work more specifically on interoperability and operational readiness, and it is also important that after Brexit the United Kingdom remains in this project because we have a common interest in defending the European space.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, thank you to the rapporteurs, and to all of you. This is the result of a common work that needs now to be continued. Let me start by saying that I count on this common work to continue in the months and the years ahead. Some of you were asking if we can be optimistic today. I know that we are not used to that. It is about realism and pragmatism today more than optimism. To quote a great figure of the last century and partially also of this one, Nelson Mandela said that ‘it always seems impossible until it’s done’. This is exactly such a case, where everybody was predicting that this would be impossible for various reasons. The work on the European defence would be impossible because the political conditions were not there, and because of this and that, and we proved that political conditions can be created when there is determination and when there is the support of our citizens. As some of you mentioned – I think it was David McAllister – our citizens strongly support our common work at European Union level on security and defence and also on foreign policy, and this creates the political conditions for us to deliver. On this, there is a top priority for our citizens. This has also been possible, and will continue to be possible, which is even more important because we decided at a certain moment to move from the theoretical ideological approach and debate on European defence and security work to a practical, useful and concrete approach, consisting of single actions that could improve our work on security and defence, delivering on the needs of our citizens.  Madam President, I will address most of the concerns and questions of Members of Parliament who are no longer here, which probably means that their concerns were not so urgent. It is more difficult to work with facts and practical decisions to be taken than to stick with stereotypes. However, if you look at the facts, we are not talking about creating a European Union army: all 25 Member States that are launching the permanent structured cooperation are going to continue to keep their national forces. They are also going to continue to use their capabilities, either in European Union missions and operations or in NATO if they are NATO allies, or in UN peace-keeping missions or in other ways. What we are doing is not militarisation; we are not working on the militarisation of our Union. We are not turning our Union, which is and will remain a political union and a force mixing hard and soft power, as most of you remember. We are not turning this into a militarisation approach; on the contrary, when I say that our missions and operations will be even more needed in the months and the years to come, it is exactly because the world needs more and more missions and operations like the European Union ones, which are working for peace in a cooperative manner on the ground. This is what is required. This is a different approach – the European way – and this is what is needed in the world today. The force for peace sometimes also requires hard force and military means, but they must always be used for the service of peace. We have not weakened, duplicated or entered into competition with NATO. When I say proudly that we have never worked so well and so much together with NATO in the fields where NATO doesn’t have the instruments to work on some threats, and that we have useful cooperation with NATO as a military alliance, I find it a bit strange to hear that this would mean that the European Union would be subordinate to the United States.  The following two debates are going to be on the Iran nuclear deal and on Jerusalem. I have the impression that we are putting strategic autonomy in practice in these times, so maybe we might face the contrary problem down the road. But I think we have to get out of the pre-cooked ideological arguments that we are sometimes used to using in the political debate and look at the reality. Reality changes, and this reality has changed in the European Union, thanks in part to the work of this Parliament, to a lot of determination and sometimes to our stubbornness. The last myth that we have to overcome is that it is about spending. How much Member States spend on defence is up to national governments and national parliaments. It’s not even up to this parliament, but to the way in which these investments are made, whether it’s an efficient or inefficient way of investing which means together or not together, in a fragmented or in a coordinated manner. For example, investing in a European manner or buying in a European manner. Again, strategic autonomy in industry is an area in which the European Union can make a difference. So, there are national decisions, but the European Union is the only one – and NATO and our American friends have understood this perfectly well – that can change the fundamental factor of spending better on the European Union side. My last two points are very specific ones. One is to answer Ms Alliot—Marie: I am already preparing an annual report on the CSDP, and I would be very pleased to use this opportunity for the European Parliament to include a report on progress on this specific issue. I think it is going to be very useful to carry on the work in a practical, concrete and punctual manner, including on the resources that we will have to allocate in the future to sustain the ambitions which we are defining. The very last point, Madam President – and I am sorry to raise this – but this is a debate about European foreign security and defence policy. It’s about the comprehensive approach bringing together different tools and instruments. The work of the Parliament is extremely valuable in this field – unique, I would say. I would not have made it without the work of the parliament. It is quite sad for me to see that in one afternoon this plenary has eight points on the agenda on foreign policy. This is fragmentation, and it is a waste of the visibility and working capacity of the plenary itself. Obviously, it is your autonomous choice, but if you could streamline a little more the focus of foreign policy debates, I think this would be added value for the work of the Parliament.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: rapporteur. – Kiitoksia paljon arvoisa puheenjohtaja, hyvät kollegat, I would like to thank once again colleagues and a considerable majority in this House who support this policy on CFSP and PESCO. I would also like especially to thank the High Representative – sitting on the Council side she has another hat, the hat of the head of the European Defence Agency – for recognising and appreciating the contribution of Parliament today. Apart from that, it does not make sense to repeat wrong things, it does not make them more true. Just to reiterate, it is of course not about the militarisation of the EU. We will definitely not be financing military operations out of our budget in the future. We will definitely not be buying tanks or aircraft or helicopters out of the EU budget in the future. Rightly so, this remains with the national budgets and with the national governments and parliaments. But we have to become more efficient. This exercise is primarily a ‘more efficiency’ exercise, because if we plan together, if we procure together, if we train together, that makes us more efficient in the tasks ahead. There are some colleagues from the fringes, from the periphery, for instance in Greece, both the far right-wing and the far left-wing, who identify Mr Erdoğan as one of their major enemies. Well, in NATO he could block everything – if we had to rely on NATO, any veto from any Member State would definitely block our access to NATO resources. We need a certain amount of strategic and operational autonomy as the EU, in order to be able to do what we deem appropriate. And insofar as the world, unfortunately, does not consist solely of stable democracies, then we also need this tool within our foreign policy instruments that we are establishing here today.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Thank you, Mr. Gahler, I am always very impressed by your Finnish language skills.

name: David McALLISTER
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, everything has been said, so, in the end, I would just like to thank all colleagues in the House, especially those who are still present, for an open and honest debate. Thanks for your criticism and for your positive remarks. Instead of summing up the debate – which is anyhow impossible in two minutes – I prefer to cite the EU Treaty.  Federica Mogherini, I would like to thank you, pursuant to Article 36(1) of our Treaty, for consulting the European Parliament on the main aspects and the basic choices of the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) and Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) and informing it of how those policies evolve. I would also like to thank you in advance for Article 36(2) ensuring that the views of the European Parliament are duly taken into consideration. I think this was a very fruitful debate. Hopefully we will have good votes on our reports tomorrow. A final remark: the High Representative has just pointed out, correctly, that we are debating eight foreign policy issues in a row in the plenary. This is decided by the Conference of Presidents, and I would like to ask all colleagues to address this in their political groups so that we can avoid this in the future. In the meantime, we should all bring forward the good arguments that we have once again heard from the High Representative, but it is up to us to make it clear to the Conference of Presidents that we can organise this Parliament better than we are at the moment.  (Applause)

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The conversation is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 13 December 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: in writing. - In the annual report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy, no direct reference was made to the "Zapad" or "Slavic Brotherhood" exercises. There is also no word about the breaking of the INF system by the Russian Federation or the deployment of Iskander missiles at the border with Poland. Instead, far-reaching instruments aimed at establishing a defense union are proposed. I understand the defense ambitions of EU Member States. For many years, however, I believe that a necessary condition is to bring closer the common perception of threats. From this point of view, NATO remains the leading defense alliance. This is evidenced, for example, by the "Rapid Trident" maneuvers, in which a real effort to demonstrate unity in the face of the Russian aggression on eastern Ukraine and the Zapad maneuvers was undertaken by a coalition under the aegis of the United States, with the participation of Bulgaria, Estonia, Georgia, Canada, Lithuania, Moldova, Norway, Poland, Romania, Turkey, Ukraine, Great Britain and Italy. There were states of alliance on both sides of the Atlantic, former states of my region, including Georgia and Moldova, which have been the target of Russian aggression for years. It was also eagerly criticized by some capitals of Turkey. However, there were no main spokesmen for European integration in the field of defense and "strategic autonomy".

name: Eugen FREUND
text: written. - The EU is more influential than ever, but when it comes to foreign and security policy, the individual member states dominate. From the war in Syria to fighting poverty in Africa, to energy dependency and hybrid threats: the challenges Europe is facing have grown. Trump and the upcoming Brexit also require a united Europe that speaks with one voice - loud and clear. For this reason, the European foreign and defense ministers signed the founding act for PESCO. In the near future, there should be more intensive cooperation in the area of ​​security and defense between 25 EU countries. It is to be welcomed if the European Union does what it is particularly strong, to pool its resources and to agree on a common approach. But there are a few things that must not be ignored: Firstly, PESCO should create synergy effects, but a common European defense is another chapter. Secondly, we must ensure that PESCO does not lead to a two-tier defense, and thirdly, the needs of neutral states such as Sweden or Austria must be given special consideration. More urgent than any discussion about a deeper defense union, however, is better cooperation between the 28 EU member states, because Europe can only show its strength to the outside world through a genuine common foreign and security policy.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing. - Who can dispute that the Member States need a good defense? Cyprus in particular, more than perhaps any state, needs this strengthening of European defense against Turkish aggression and against the ongoing occupation. But is PESCO anything more than the development of another war industry? I am particularly concerned about Mrs Mogherini's statement that "Europe should finally become a global player". But what does this mean? If it is for dealing with external threats, fine. But is it for the EU to bomb those who are being bombed by others? I close by emphasizing that we do not agree with a so-called pacifism in a time of conflict and threat, but this does not at all lead me to believe in militarism and problem solving through the tools of the devil. Can we ever speak with one voice and in one direction? In support of moral values? Can we become the force of peace? This is the big question.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: in writing. - The EU leadership has been working since the 1960s to build an independent military alliance. However, the project of the Western European Union has always ended with declarations. The idea was also related to the idea of ​​joint production of selected types of weapons. One of the few such successes was the Gripen fighters. In the civilian field, the project of a number of Airbus aircraft, the development of Arianne rocket launchers and the promising Galileo project are still relatively successful. However, the ministers of defense and foreign affairs of the EU countries are under pressure from reality trying to renew the idea of ​​an independent armaments agency and coordination of military actions. EU stabilization action in the Malian regions of Mopti and Segou is relatively successful. On the contrary, the attempt to stabilize the situation in Libya after the overthrow of Colonel Gaddafi can be considered completely unsuccessful, as can the attempt to liquidate the regime of Bashar Assad in Syria. As aid from the Russian Federation has played a stabilizing role in Syria, this report is imbued with severe Russophobia in various parts. EU countries are currently heavily involved in the Eufor Althea mission in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Eulex mission in Kosovo. These parts of the Balkans are facing a large number of returning Islamic State fighters. The European Defense Fund is intended to strengthen defense research and, within the EEC, the European defense industry, independently of the United States

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing. - The European Union is supposed to be founded on the value of solidarity between its Member States. The Common Foreign and Security Policy was supposedly adopted to protect all the countries of the Union. Lately, Greece has been facing obvious challenges from both Turkey and Albania. In particular, Mr. Erdogan now openly disputes the Treaty of Lausanne, disputes the sovereign rights of Greece in the Aegean islands, the Turkish fighters violate Greek airspace every day and in all this the Greek people do not see any satisfactory response from the European side. Union. The European Union remains inactive. He does not really grit his teeth at the Sultan. She does not tell him that he must unite and that his challenges towards Greece do not pass. Turkey must therefore understand that it cannot continue in this direction, but in this we also need the determination of the European Union. It is a given that Greece has the ability to face Turkey, but it also needs the support of the European Union. To prove in practice that there is so-called community solidarity!

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – I am very pleased that paragraph 35 of this report encourages the creation of a permanent ‘European Integrated Force’; I have been calling for the creation of a real European Armed Forces for years now. I also warmly welcome the renewed call for Member States to ensure that their defence budgets are at least 2% of their respective GDPs. At the moment, too few Member States meet this requirement. Whereas paragraph 16 of the report calls for this goal to be achieved within a decade, I would personally very much prefer a faster and more ambitious approach to reach this important target.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the Iranian nuclear deal.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, it is good to be back in my place. If we look around us – and we are doing this quite consistently today – we see a dangerous world, indeed. There is a risk that tensions will rise around the holy places of Jerusalem – we will discuss this in the next debate – Daesh has been defeated in Iraq, but the war in Syria is not over yet, Egypt has just suffered one of the worst terrorist attacks in its history, and the war in Yemen is getting worse by the day. To look a little bit further, in the Korean Peninsula there is a security challenge that potentially affects all of us: nuclear proliferation is a reality. Against this background, preserving and implementing the nuclear deal with Iran is an absolute must. We simply cannot afford more tension in the Middle East and another nuclear proliferation crisis. We cannot afford to undermine the credibility of a multilateral agreement endorsed by the UN Security Council resolution, and we cannot afford to dismantle a deal that works and delivers on its promises. The deal with Iran is ensuring the peaceful nature of Iran’s nuclear programme. This is vital for our collective security in the European Union, in the region and beyond, and it is even more important as we face a nuclear crisis with North Korea. With a nuclear deal with Iran, we have established the strongest monitoring system ever set up. The International Atomic Energy Agency has reported nine times that Iran is implementing all its nuclear-related commitments. It took us 12 years of extremely difficult negotiations, led by the European Union, to achieve these results. Renegotiating the deal, or parts of it, is simply not an option. No one can possibly believe, in good faith, that this is a credible path to follow. After President Trump’s announcement of a new US strategy towards Iran, we Europeans have made our position very clear. Preserving the deal is our shared security interest, and the best way for the United States to address their security concerns – which are also ours – is in close cooperation with we Europeans. We Europeans share many of our American friends’ preoccupations regarding the regional situation and Iran’s ballistic missile programme, which is inconsistent with UN Security Council Resolution 2231. This is why we still have some targeted sanctions and an arms embargo in place. But these issues should not be mixed up with the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action with the nuclear deal and must be addressed in the appropriate formats and fora. Dismantling a nuclear agreement that is working would not put us in a better position to discuss all the rest. The opposite would happen. In fact, this is what we always do in our contacts with Iran. We discuss all the issues we have on the table, from cooperation to the difficult ones, including regional issues. On 20 November, we held the latest EU—Iran high-level dialogue and, as you know, I meet regularly with Foreign Minister Zarif. For more than two years now, we have built a very frank relationship with Iran. We are always open about our disagreements – and there are many – and we always try to find the best way to address them. This approach has also driven our conversations on human rights. We still have substantive disagreements but, together with Iran, we have agreed to focus on tangible results. For example, we welcome the recent adoption by Tehran of the revised anti—narcotics law. If properly implemented, it could lead to a significant drop in the number of executions of drug offenders in Iran. At the last high-level dialogue I mentioned a few weeks ago, there was also agreement to continue our engagement on women’s empowerment and on the treatment of prisoners. We have also agreed to look into possibilities for cooperation on the fight against drugs and on migration. Let me remind us all that Iran has played – and continues to play – an important role in hosting millions of Afghan refugees and we are ready to increase our common work and support in this field. Since we reached the nuclear deal, our engagement with Iran has entered a new phase. As I mentioned, it is not always easy. There are many issues where we disagree, but it is definitely a new phase. Trade between Iran and Europe increased by 94% in the first half of 2017 compared to the first half of 2016. Oil exports have reached the pre—sanctions level and billions of outstanding oil debts have been paid back. Foreign direct investment is increasing and the Iranian Government reported growth of 55% compared to the previous year. Progress in the financial and banking sector has been slower due to a number of factors, but important work is being carried out to improve the situation, also including on the Iranian side. Civil nuclear cooperation is also an integral part of the deal, and let me stress that, as the debate refers to the Iran nuclear deal, I am focusing here on the implementation of the deal and all the nuclear-related parts of it. I would obviously be very pleased to have a ninth debate today to address all the issues that are not covered under the nuclear deal and that are issues that we are addressing and we believe need to be addressed in our relations and talks with Iran. I am thinking of the war in Syria and the conflict in Yemen, even if I touched upon some of the bilateral issues we are working on. As I was saying, civil nuclear cooperation is an integral part of the deal. Our civil nuclear cooperation makes the nuclear deal more solid through increased transparency. The second High—Level Seminar on Civilian Nuclear Cooperation has just taken place in Isfahan and concrete cooperation activities are being rolled out. This cooperation is important for we Europeans and is even more important for the people of Iran. I would like us all to remember the images of young Iranians – girls, boys, but also not just young people – celebrating the deal in the streets of Tehran. I believe we have the responsibility to show these people and the Iranian leadership that they have an interest in making Iran more open and more cooperative, and that this brings benefits to the leadership and the people – especially to the people. It is in their interest and in our own interest. The deal with Iran prevented a nuclear escalation in the Middle East. It showed that diplomacy is the best way to overcome longstanding problems that sometimes seem impossible to solve. This is something we have not forgotten and this is why we believe that a diplomatic, but critical, engagement with Iran can benefit the entire Middle East and prevent a regional escalation that would destabilise the whole world. At this complicated moment for the region and for the world, let me say that the European Parliament has taken part of the responsibility for our collective security and I am grateful for that.  I would like to thank you for your contacts with the US Congress and I would also mention the visit of the delegation for relations with Iran to that country. As always there was excellent cooperation and coordination with me and with all our teams that are working on these files. I think we showed teamwork and that the European institutions across the board – including the European Parliament that to me plays an essential role in European foreign policy – managed to, as we always say, speak with one voice or pass the same message. Then, when the message is passed by different players across the EU institutions, it becomes louder and clearer. So let me thank you once again for your cooperation over the last weeks and months. Let me also say that I believe we will need this kind of cooperation even more in the weeks and months ahead, which will probably also be difficult. The work is not over, but I think that we are doing what needs to be done, again thanks also to your determined work. (Applause)

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, we are examining today the situation following the change in US policy towards Iran in October. The European position, as was recalled by the High Representative, is unchanged: we continue to support the Iran nuclear deal. But my belief is that instead of dismissing all criticism out of hand, we had better face our weaknesses and try to fix them. The development of Iranian ballistic missiles continues, and the "sunset clause" paves the way for Iran to a nuclear arsenal in ten years, obviously with important consequences for the security of Europe, including my country. Just because we are committed to the implementation of the nuclear deal, we should not put on blinders and refuse to admit the rest of the problematic aspects in Iran. We cannot remain silent on the dire human rights situation. For two years, the only European voices alerting to the growing number of executions, the oppression of critical voices and the persecution of minorities have come from our Parliament. For the rest, there is a polite silence. Second, one cannot forget Iran's destabilizing role in the region, whether it is Syria, Iraq, Lebanon or Gaza. One cannot pretend not to see the Iranian regime's support for Hezbollah and other terrorist movements, Holocaust denial and calls for the destruction of Israel. Let us have the courage of our convictions and raise these questions by working with our partners across the Atlantic.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, let’s set things right. Since the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) entered into force, the International Atomic Energy Agency has – as you rightly mentioned, Madam High Representative – certified nine times that Iran is in compliance with the commitments set out in the agreement. Following this, the international community has lifted the nuclear-related sanctions, whereas sanctions imposed by the EU and the US relating to human rights abuses and terrorist activities remain in place. The US non-nuclear-related sanctions are, nevertheless, much more comprehensive and have an extraterritorial effect that causes legal uncertainty and poses problems to the EU forums dealing with Iran.  The EU position is unequivocal. The US President’s decision to decertify the deal is damaging US credibility and interests, especially now, considering the worsening of the North Korean crisis. This decision remains purely an internal matter for the US, as the agreement remains a multilateral agreement and cannot be scrapped by a single party. In parallel, there are a number of other issues that are not part of the agreement but should be included in our EU high-level dialogue with Iran. I am referring to the following: human rights, firing of ballistic missiles, and Iran’s destabilising action in the region, notably in Syria, Lebanon and Yemen.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the Iran nuclear deal was concluded in 2015 as the joint comprehensive plan of action (JCPOA) by the P5+1 and the European Union, and I wish to extend thanks for the excellent work of your predecessor, Ms Ashton, and yourself, Ms Mogherini. Many so-called hardliners labelled it as a capitulation. These people not only failed to appreciate that the deal was concerned with one particular aspect, i.e. Iran’s nuclear weapons programme, but also they viewed the sanctions as an end in themselves rather than as a route to the negotiating table. Iran’s human rights record is atrocious. I am the first to admit to that, and we should not fail to speak out against, and I have done on many occasions. Its support for terrorist groups in the Middle East is well documented and must be thoroughly condemned. Its continued engagement in a regional, sectarian battle for supremacy with Saudi Arabia creates instability and should be strongly discouraged.
