These issues are, however, irrelevant when it comes to discussing this deal. That the JCPOA be enforced and measured solely against its specific aims is integral to its negotiation. Halting and hopefully ultimately preventing Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon is what we must remain focused on, not stoking the narrative of Iran as a pariah state deserving of sanctions. The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) has confirmed that Iran has kept within all of the technical parameters of the deal, even if at times, these parameters have been pushed to their limits. I am pleased, therefore, that the EU Member States and the High Representative have spoken strongly in favour of the deal, following President Trump’s continued threats to withdraw from it, which I regard as unacceptable. At a time when tensions with North Korea are at a breaking point, the ability to highlight a successful nuclear non-proliferation deal is of more value than ever.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, one of the reasons why I consistently defended the diplomatic solution to the nuclear question with Iran is that I believe there are so many other key areas where we need to engage the Islamic Republic of Iran. A deal on the new looming nuclear arms challenge was a hurdle that needed to be overcome.  Firstly, the systematic human rights violations remain the priority, and should be part of every dialogue, visit and communiqué involving the EU. There can be no watering down of what we mean when we talk about human rights. They are universal, even if people pray to a different god or are born in a different culture. Executions, torture, censorship and gender discrimination without due process are unacceptable.  Secondly, Iran’s role in its region is a disaster. In Iraq, Syria, Lebanon and Yemen, it is clear that Iran, through the Revolutionary Guards, as well as Hezbollah, seeks to ruthlessly push its interests and influence, and I am glad that the High Representative mentioned the problematic ballistic missile firings as a key point of concern as well. We should not be naive, and we should not be distracted either. We were warned about the potential unrest in the region as a consequence of the nuclear deal, but instead of tearing up the deal like President Trump suggests, let us do what we can to stop Iran’s toxic influence. We stand by our words and will honour EU commitments, but we must never blindly defend the indefensible. Through the new challenges to the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action by President Trump, I actually fear that we are again ending up in a place where all we will talk about is the nuclear deal. Instead of looking at yesterday’s agreement, let us tackle today’s problems and avoid more disasters tomorrow.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. Madam President, the 2015 agreement and the lifting of sanctions on the nuclear program have lifted Iran out of the isolation imposed on it by the West. Iran, in turn, must seize this opportunity constructively by contributing to its role in world peace and stability. In this context, his participation in the resolution of various conflicts and political crises, especially in the Middle East, is necessary and is constantly judged. In the two years since the implementation of the Joint Cohesion Action Plan for Iran's nuclear program, the International Atomic Energy Agency has certified nine times that it has complied with all its commitments. This is exactly the perfect implementation of the Agreement that President Trump ostentatiously despises and with his decision he puts another wick in the Middle East and the rest of the world. Ladies and gentlemen, History has shown that the United States does not hesitate to jeopardize the peace and security of an entire region, as long as it serves specific political and economic interests. The US President now seems to be a constant threat to world security but also to peace. Mrs Mogherini, the EU has a duty to continue to support the agreement at all levels and by all possible means. It is clear that Europe must pursue an autonomous foreign policy if it is to be the counterweight to disastrous US foreign policy. Personally, I am not very optimistic but I hope, because it is a matter of world peace, that you deny me.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, as elected politicians, we should always set respect for human rights and democratic principles as top priorities, including when dealing with other countries. This is especially the case with a country like Iran, which happens to be the world champion in the number of executions that it carries out. One thing should be clear: Iran is a religious dictatorship where there are no free elections. Unfortunately, the EU seems to have put aside all its core values and principles just to make a deal with the Iranian regime.  Since the nuclear negotiations were started in 2013, coinciding with Rohani’s election as president, over 3 000 people have been hanged by the Islamic Republic of Iran. According to the United Nations, this is the highest number of executions in Iran in 25 years. To be honest, Ms Mogherini, we really missed some words in defence of human rights when you visited Tehran earlier this year for the inauguration of Rohani’s second term.  Many Iranians have the impression that the EU has forgotten its principles in exchange for getting more business and trade benefits from the Iranian market. What will the Iranian people think when they see that all the visiting politicians are there only to close business deals, while remaining silent on human rights violations, including repression of women’s rights and ethnic and religious minorities? Let’s think about that.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, kind High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, the die has been cast: last October the American administration refused to certify the agreement on the Iranian nuclear program. A move, in my opinion, without a rational logic of its own and rather dictated by internal electoral reasons. The image of Iran as the enemy par excellence and the only source of regional instability certainly does not help the future of the Middle East. Honestly, I struggle to identify him as solely responsible for regional problems: on the contrary, he is certainly in good company. The defense of human rights is necessary and mandatory, but as has been recalled, in addition to Tehran's role in welcoming Afghan refugees, the nuclear deal is working globally. Defeating it would once again pave the way for the most radical factions in the country, exponentially increasing the risk of an escalation in the region, with unpredictable, not to say apocalyptic, consequences. As a Union we have a duty to keep the point and to be balanced in our approach. Only in this way can we be bearers of peace and not of further tension in the Middle East.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.- Mister President!After twelve years of negotiations, numerous visits and inspections by international nuclear energy authorities, President Trump has now announced with a shot in the hip that he will block and ignore this agreement.I can only advise the Union not to join in and to stand by the agreement.Otherwise there is a risk that this vacuum that will arise will be filled primarily by Russia and China.In return, Iran must of course adhere to its obligations under the agreement.I also expect Iran to become active in foreign policy and make a significant contribution to the peaceful stabilization of the war-torn region of the Middle East.Breaking off talks, not keeping contracts is not good, especially if you want to find solutions.And solutions include, even if one or the other does not like it that Iran is taken to the table.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen!The United Nations have confirmed: Iran is fully adhering to the agreements.We have now negotiated an agreement for twelve years, and at the same time Donald Trump declares Iran an enemy of the USA, declares the Revolutionary Guards a terrorist organization, criticizes the ballistic missile program and the cooperation with North Korea.But none of this has anything to do with the nuclear deal.What Iran needs now, two years after the agreement was signed, is the lifting of the sanctions.Iran needs jobs, Iran needs prospects for young people.Iran adheres to the agreement.Iran helped fight and destroy ISIS in Iraq and Syria.Together with Russia, he has brought peace in Syria within reach, and the principle of non-interference in internal affairs should again become more and more the primacy of the EU's foreign policy.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. I believe that in this debate a fundamental question arises, which is to know whether the nuclear agreement with Iran, which is one of the great achievements of international diplomacy in recent years, in which, by the way, the European Union has played a very prominent role, it must be dealt with separately or it must be dealt with jointly with the situation in the region, in Iraq, in Yemen, in Syria or in Lebanon. The position of the President of the United States has been very clear. This matter has to be addressed jointly and that is why it has not wanted to certify the agreement and has forwarded it to Congress. However, I want to say that I agree with the position of Vice President and High Representative Mogherini that it is important to preserve the achievements of this agreement, to address it separately and, indeed, to try to prevent nuclear proliferation in the region. Therefore, I support and really share the opinion of the High Representative. However, that should not lead us to the situation of being unaware of the disturbing situation - to which other colleagues have referred - of human rights in Iran. The high representative has offered to have a critical dialogue and to address this situation in a future appearance. We are concerned about the rights of minorities, the application of the death penalty and the situation of the opposition. I hope that the High Representative's talks with the Vice President of the United States, Mike Pence, with Secretary Tillerson and with Congress can result in a more balanced position and closer to the position we maintain in the European Union.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: - Mister President! Less than a month ago, the International Atomic Energy Agency confirmed for the ninth time that Iran was fully complying with the so-called nuclear deal. The deadline for the US Congress to decide what to do after President Trump's decertification expired last week with no result. Now the president has to decide whether the lifting of the sanctions should continue. We appeal to our American friends to uphold the treaty and to work with us to find solutions to the other current challenges with Iran. Of course we also condemn Iran's missile program. We do not close our eyes to the human rights situation and Iranian interference in other conflicts in the region or the agitation against Israel. But there will be no renegotiations as we know. It is absurd to say: because we are not successful in other areas, we are destroying the only thing that has really been achieved positively so far. In this respect, it is the treaty that is currently the only way for us to build a new basis of trust step by step with Iran on an equal footing - Ms. Mogherini has already mentioned that. We can only find sustainable solutions through talks with Iran, and Europe in particular must remain a partner to be taken seriously.

name: Bas BELDER
text: - High Representative, you will certainly not be ignorant of the fact that the abject regime of North Korea has long been militarily in close cooperation with the Iranian regime of terror.This is happening in the nuclear field, including the development of ultramodern missile systems.That brings me to two crucial questions for you, Madam High Representative.First, how do you view the option, the danger that Tehran uses Pyongyang, North Korea, as its nuclear backdoor plan, that is, that Pyongyang will be used to continue Iran's nuclear program?Question 2: Are you also consulting with the US security authorities on this option, this danger, who are rightly monitoring North Korean-Iranian military cooperation closely and with growing concerns?High Representative, we know North Korea's illegal nuclear path.Is an Iranian version coming now?

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: - Mr President, Madam High Representative, for us this agreement is of enormous strategic importance. This agreement is the symbol that multilateralism is effective, that diplomacy can strengthen stability and peace in the world. This agreement is a sign that, through negotiations, we can contribute to nuclear disarmament. Well me, I would like to congratulate you on your work and I would like to encourage the European leaders to support you more firmly and publicly to save this agreement. But beyond this agreement is the problem of nuclear disarmament in the world. And as Beatrice Fihn, director of the International Campaign for the Abolition of Nuclear Weapons (ICAN), which just received the 2017 Nobel Peace Prize, said, “we have to choose between two results: the end of nuclear weapons or our end. to all of us ”. On Sunday in Oslo, she called on the United States to choose freedom over fear, and Russia to choose disarmament over destruction. I would add that Europe must choose and must show the way of nuclear disarmament, and I am counting on you, Mrs Mogherini.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, the Iran nuclear deal was lauded by some as giving peace in our time throughout the Middle East. However, we must now ask: have we traded nightmarish prophecy for possible calamity? Or, indeed, has anything really changed at all? The deal deliberately only covered nuclear material and other components of nuclear capability, thus the immediate aftermath saw breaches of the UN Resolution on intercontinental ballistic missile testing and a bolstered Iranian foreign policy, not least including the proxy war in Yemen and further turmoil in the Middle East. And all this without even considering what happens after the sunset clause is closed in the not too distant future. The Trump administration was correct to force a debate on this deal. Accordingly, it is time that this place looks seriously at this issue beyond its mirage as the gold standard of EU diplomacy by addressing the real effects that it is having in the Middle East.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Mr President, the position of the West, and in particular of the United States of America, on the issue of the nuclear deal with Iran is simply unacceptable. Two years ago, all parties signed an agreement after long negotiations. To this day, Iran continues to abide by this agreement to the letter, without violating any of its points. The United States, on the other hand, was the first to violate the agreement, recently imposing new sanctions on it. Even French President Macron has called for the agreement to be supplemented with two new articles. This shows how valuable the signature of Western governments is. If some were not satisfied with the agreement, they should not have signed it from the beginning. But from the moment they signed it, I take it for granted that they must respect it. Iran has not shown that it is trying to acquire nuclear weapons or that it poses a threat to Western countries. So I think every new restriction is just to serve the expansion plans of the United States and its allies. Let us not forget that the countries that react to this agreement already have nuclear weapons, while the USA is the only country that has used atomic bombs in time of war, destroying two cities together with their inhabitants.

name: David McALLISTER
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the High Representative and also her Secretary General, Helga Schmid, for their tireless commitment to preserving the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA).  Be assured that you have the full support of a broad majority of this House. As we have heard – and many speakers have pointed this out – the JCPOA is a multilateral agreement endorsed by the UN Security Council and it should be preserved by all means. In every future action, we should remember that the negotiation process took around 12 years. We should not tire of making clear to our US counterparts – and this is exactly what a Committee on Foreign Affairs mission to Washington did last month – that, firstly, Iran is in full compliance with the JCPOA, as reported repeatedly by the International Atomic Energy Agency, and, secondly, Iran’s ballistic missile tests are outside the scope of the JCPOA. However, Iran’s regional posture, its ballistic missile programmes and the human rights situation remain deeply worrying. I remain concerned by the tensions in the region and the deteriorating relations between Iran and its neighbours, notably the military build—up in the region and confrontational rhetoric by all sides. Nevertheless, the international community would not be in a better place to deal with any of these issues without the JCPOA in place.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Mister President! I made my first speech in the European Parliament on the Iran sanctions; that was six years ago. I have argued against the use of military means. Much has changed since then, thanks in large part to the efforts of the European Union, particularly from you, Mrs Mogherini. The nuclear deal was a great success and it must not be jeopardized. There were many expectations associated with him: that the sanctions will be ended and the population will benefit from them and that relaxation in the region will be associated with it. None of that happened. There is a risk of failure and thus renewed instability. Iran has done its part and is now in danger of being wiped out in geopolitical disputes. What we urgently need is de-escalation in the relations between the states in the region, but also internally - keyword human rights. A confrontation strategy only helps the hardliners.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: - Sir.Chairman!Iran is a terrorist state.A state that terrorizes its own people, a state that terrorizes its neighbors, and a state that sponsors terrorism in Europe and the rest of the world.Therefore, when we discuss the Iran agreement, we cannot ignore the fact that it has been used too much to avoid talking about the many other problems that are spreading from Iran.Problems such as human rights violations, the financing of terrorist organizations and the whole regime around the Revolutionary Guards and the ayatollah, which are deeply problematic by all the standards we normally use in the EU to assess our counterparts.That is why, as the European Parliament, we should remind the Commission that the Iran agreement cannot stand alone.The pressure must also be on all the other areas where Iran continues to violate very basic requirements of humane behavior and basic human rights.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! The less predictable President Trump's policy is, the greater the responsibility rests with the European Union. Today we are talking about the most inflammatory region in the world, where various threats to our security are born. I am pleased as head of the Delegation for relations with Iran that the European Union speaks with one voice on a matter as fundamental as the nuclear deal. So there is no problem with finding a phone number to Europe. I believe that this deal is a victory for patient, consummate diplomacy and a real pillar of the international nuclear non-proliferation strategy, as well as a victory for those forces in Iran which are in favor of the gradual opening up of this great country and its modernization. And it is in this spirit - engagement, and not disengagement - that we spoke during our recent visit to Tehran with the parliamentary authorities and government representatives. The talks concerned not only matters that could bring them closer, but also disputed issues were definitely raised, i.e. first of all Iran's ambiguous role in such an inflammatory region, secondly, the abuse of the death penalty, and thirdly, broadly understood human rights. Mr. Ahmadreza Djalali was also on my list of topics for talking to various officials in this country. Tomorrow, there will also be an opportunity to raise this issue during a videoconference with the Iranian ambassador to the European Union. However, dialogue wins. I hope so.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: - Mr President, Madam High Representative, the nuclear agreement established with Iran in 2015 had the effect of generating a multilateral commitment where before there was nothing but antagonism, mutual distrust and a worrying rhetorical escalation. The Iranian nuclear program went from being highly opaque to allowing monitoring and even applying restrictions, and remember that it was signed at a time when it was believed that this country was on the verge of secretly obtaining the bomb nuclear. Having seen the failure of the embargo, which lasted for a long time, and which mainly punished the Iranian people, this agreement, supported by the European Union from the first moment, was a notable diplomatic success and, as such, was welcomed by the wider international community. In his incendiary vertigo, President Trump proposed to the United States Congress the approval of new sanctions against Iran on the grounds that this agreement does not meet American interests. In view of this, the European Union must make it clear that it will not waver in support of this agreement. Its eventual failure would imply a setback of decades, return the nuclear program to its opaque situation and bring back the fear that Iran could develop nuclear weapons, thus contributing to create even more instability across the Middle East. East.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, it seems that Ms Mogherini is overdosing on some unjustifiable optimism vis-à-vis Iran. This Treaty does not work. It was set to help to improve the situation, particularly in the sphere of human rights and to make Iran more peaceful. What we have seen instead was the number of executions rising, doubling in just three years, and we have seen Iran continuing its anti-Western policy. Iran never gave up its nuclear ambitions and was launching ballistic missiles instead, it supported terrorists – like Hezbollah – and it tried to achieve the status of a regional power, penetrating Iraq, Syria and Yemen, which could shake the very fragile regional balance of power.  It seems, therefore, that Iran is rather encouraged by this deal, not curbed by it, and therefore I do not see any reason why we should be worried about preserving the deal. It is a failure. We should in fact change it, or scrap it.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: question "blue card".- I have a very simple and very specific question for our colleague.In which article of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action did he read that the nuclear deal placed constraints on other areas of contention with Iran, such as the one he named, for example, thehuman rights?I have no sympathy for the Iranian regime, but I like to be specific, so I wonder in which part of the joint comprehensive plan of action is the provisions that Mr. Zahradil just referred to.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: blue-card answer. – I can only tell you that this deal was supposed to create a certain atmosphere, and it has been said that while it deals with a particular issue, the nuclear ambition of Iran, it could help to change the atmosphere in Iran and pave the way for improvement in the sphere of human rights, for instance. So, regardless of whether there is an article or not, it seems that the overall atmosphere and those implications that were expected to happen, simply did not. That is the whole thing.

name: Elmar BROK
text: - Mr President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen! Yes, Iran is a dictatorship. Iran is responsible for the proxy wars, along with Saudi Arabia, particularly in the region. Iran is conducting missile tests, which UN resolutions should not allow, and it is dramatically violating human rights. It is all true. But still this nuclear deal has to be there. In order to avoid the spread of nuclear weapons, this nuclear deal is also a signal to North Korea. If this is terminated, how can you come to an agreement with someone else not to build atomic bombs? And if Iran builds atomic bombs, Saudi Arabia and all countries in the region will also make atomic bombs. So far this has been avoided. The agreement says that the moment you violate the rules, the sanctions can be reintroduced at any time - so that we either gain time here or perhaps avoid nuclear weapons in Iran completely in the long run, in order not to become one in this way dramatic change in the region - and far beyond - to come. President Trump now has the ball back in his garden. Mrs Mogherini, I hope that the talks will succeed in persuading him not to take the steps that he can now take again after there were no constructive decisions in Congress. Like so many others, I note that Iran is sticking to the agreement. We should stick to the agreement, this agreement is part of international law. Only the Americans want to get out, no one else. For this reason we should press ahead with our policy to secure this agreement in order to prevent further development of nuclear weapons in this world.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you High Representative Mogherini for the beautiful report with which you have introduced this debate. The Iran nuclear deal was a diplomatic success of the European Union. With recent developments related to the statements by the President of the United States, who expressed the willingness to withdraw the US from the agreement, the diplomatic effort of the European Union must be even stronger. I agree with the High Representative in reiterating that the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action is a multilateral agreement adopted by a resolution of the United Nations Security Council, and that therefore it does not belong to any state and cannot be modified unilaterally. We need to confirm our support for the agreement: in addition to being the basis for a renewed economic relationship with Iran, the implementation of the JCPOA, with the consequent easing of sanctions, is having a positive political impact on Iranian citizens. Furthermore, I believe that Iran's opening to an international dimension can be a stimulus to improve the internal situation and a unique opportunity to initiate a process of full integration of Iran in an international and global context. The European Union, of course, must pursue the establishment of a strategic and structured dialogue, which must also go beyond the superficial aspects, and which must therefore also address issues related to the violation of human rights. The alarming use of the death penalty, the persecution of minorities, the arrests of activists and discrimination against women cannot be ignored. But for this I believe it is essential that efforts continue for a relationship with Iran established as in the agreements.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - 247 executions in the first half of this year, of which 3 women, 3 children and 12 public executions. The UN report on Iran reads like a thriller. The last name to be added to the list of people awaiting execution is Ahmadreza Djalali. Doctor, European Citizen, Father, Husband. Also known in my country for his medical guest lectures at the Free University of Brussels. Sentenced to death on dubious evidence. His lawyer failed to file an appeal, making his execution enforceable. I quote the rector of the VUB today in the Flemish press: "As an enthusiastic doctor and passionate expert in disaster medicine, he had only one motive: to save human lives. Today his own life is hanging by a thread. And there is no doctor. who can save him ”. Therefore, Mrs. Mogherini, this urgent appeal, an emotional appeal: use all your influence, use the levers you have to save this man's life! The nuclear deal with Iran should not close your eyes to the horrific human rights violations, as that would amount to culpable negligence and complicity.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: - Mr President, as I said earlier, there is no sympathy to be had towards the Iranian theocracy, and firmness is undoubtedly the best attitude to have towards- vis-à-vis Tehran. I come from a country that has been - and I am proud of it - the toughest in negotiating the Iran nuclear deal. But if we only speak with countries with which we share values, security interests and sympathy and if we only engage diplomatically with them, we are not going to speak to many people. We will end up well alone in this real world as it is. Today it is not about being naive about Iran, nor about being confused. We must approach this subject in a very rigorous way and deal with the problems and disputes in order to speak about them openly and - as I said - firmly. On the Common Comprehensive Plan of Action, it is a compromise agreement that there is nothing to say today that it is being violated or that it will have bad consequences. We must therefore apply the common global action plan today, period! The European attitude from this point of view is exemplary. On ballistics, there is - you said so, Madam High Representative - a violation of Security Council resolution 2231. So, on that, you have to be firm and react. On regional recomposition, yes, of course, Iran is progressing from Yemen to Lebanon, but Iran is also progressing on our mistakes, on our indecision and on our inclinations. Iran is therefore an actor, neither better nor worse in absolute terms than many other actors in the region. Here too, we must be realistic. We have red lines that we have to be totally uncompromising on, including the security of Israel. For the rest, I think we have an interest in engaging Iran - as I said - with the utmost firmness, but also with the utmost realism.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, I give full support for High Representative Mogherini’s efforts in implementing the nuclear agreement with Iran, which is strategic for the EU and global security. The EU should encourage Iran to play a responsible role in its region and beyond, in contrast with the Wahhabism fuelling terrorism and escalation by Saudi Arabian proxies. But the EU should also demand that Iran stops supporting the military butcher Assad in Syria. The EU cannot also be silent about human rights concerns in Iran, but to be credible and effective it must not turn a blind eye to the provocative activities of sects such as the MEK (Mojahedin-e Khalq), which act within this Parliament, and last week even physically assaulted an opponent just outside the Parliament. This criminal act happened when the MEK leader Maryam Rajavi was in the Parliament. I demand from President Tajani the expulsion of MEK agents who work on EP premises. This is also a security matter for all of us.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, today, more than ever, the EU needs a comprehensive, value—based and principled approach to the Iranian dictatorship. The nuclear deal has to be kept – it should not be abandoned, let us be clear – but it is not a substitute for such a principled approach. We should not be hypercritical, clinging formally to the letter of the Treaty and taking it as an excuse to look away from the real situation. The two belong together. Regarding the Iranian Dictatorship, the Treaty has also provided a breathing space for the dictatorship to strengthen its hold on the population, and Iran continues to be the biggest exporter of terrorism and conflict in the Middle East. It has continued with its ballistic missile programme, and our biggest worry is a dramatic worsening of the human rights situation. The EU cannot continue to keep a moderate and low—profile protest. We should take a very principled approach to this: the hundreds of people hanged find no relief whether their butchers have been called moderates in the West or not.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - Mr. President, the agreement with Iran, unanimously supported by the Security Council in its Resolution 2231, represented an important diplomatic success. It cleared the serious threat of a nuclear Iran and prevented the arms escalation in one of the most unstable regions of the world. Furthermore, it served to underline the role of the European Union as a global player, given the important role played during the negotiation. It has already been said in this debate that, according to the International Atomic Energy Agency, - as it has repeatedly stated - Iran is complying with the terms of the agreement. For all these reasons, we must support the maintenance of the agreement. However, this cannot hide the concerns raised today by Iran's ballistics program and its negative performance at the regional level, despite the hopes created by the agreement for a more constructive attitude by Iran on the regional stage. Its important influence on various actors in the region is known. We need a much more constructive Iran in the Middle East. An Iran that does not contribute to polarization and confrontation in a region ravaged by violence and in which national, religious and ethnic divisions intersect.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I have listened very carefully to the whole debate and allow me, Madam High Representative, a few sentences. I found your performance extremely optimistic. On the one hand, I support that this agreement be maintained, but on the other hand, we cannot relativize Iran's today is a theocratic dictatorship, where human rights are not respected, where there are huge executions, destabilization of the region and many, many negatives of this criminal regime. Do not be angry, in the face of this, to be happy that our trade with this country is growing, that our investment is growing, it seems to me that we are basically relativizing how criminal the regime exists in Iran today. So let's make this agreement exist, I consider it a great success for your diplomacy as well, but on the other hand, still be careful, because an agreement with such a regime can exist at one point, but such a regime can terminate it at any time.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Since the nuclear deal, it has actually remained deafeningly silent about the numerous human rights violations in Iran.I want to talk about the numbers here today.Executions have doubled in the last 4 years.In 2016 we are talking about 567 executions.Today I want to talk about one name, that of a doctor and guest lecturer of the VUB in Brussels, Ahmadreza Djalali.He is one of the people currently sentenced to death.His lawyer has not appealed and his death sentence is enforceable from now on.Today all universities in Flanders have called for his release.Mrs. Mogherini, I am taking advantage of this momentum to ask for your help.Help our professor and doctor get out.Help us!Thank you.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Mr President, we have to admit that the agreement limiting Iran to civilian nuclear activity was a major achievement of European and international multilateral diplomacy and will guarantee peace and stability. The deal works and delivers on its promises, fully or partially, and this agreement should be preserved. Despite this milestone in practical cooperation between the European Union and Iran, the scope of our bilateral relations is well below potential, and we have to ask ourselves, is it not high time to focus more on the situation of ordinary Iranians? To speak about the deteriorating human rights situation and the grievous condition of activists, about poverty, about corruption, the crackdown on the opposition, repression of women and religious minorities, as well as the role Iran plays in Syria and some other countries of the region.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, the agreement with Iran must be upheld and implemented. There is no possibility of renegotiation. Such a prospect will carry far greater risks than those it seeks to avoid. Especially the position of President Trump, unfortunately, together with a few more of his positions, brings us all to new unsolvable problems. That said, we must not forget that basic human rights are being violated in Iran and that the fight against drugs needs Iranian support. I conclude by emphasizing, ladies and gentlemen, that the danger of a nuclear Holocaust is real today and is exacerbated by North Korea's action, and that the European Union must immediately take an international initiative on nuclear disarmament.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, Madam High Representative, the nuclear agreement with Iran was certainly one of the greatest diplomatic achievements of the past decade. However, President Trump's decision not to validate this agreement will entail a serious setback in the fight against nuclear proliferation and will certainly make the world more insecure. It is up to us, therefore, us Europeans, to continue to lead the fight against nuclear proliferation. However, the implementation of the general joint action plan and its impact on institutional and commercial relations must be strictly conditioned to the uncompromising defense of human rights and go much further than the flash visits of European leaders with agendas focused on investment opportunities or promotion of energy alliances. But, Madam High Representative, let us not forget that Iran is not a democracy and that Europe cannot turn a blind eye to the constant human rights violations of the ayatollah dictatorial regime, maintaining this unacceptable posture of business as usual, vis-à-vis a regime oppressor who holds a sad record of human rights violations and world leadership in the application of capital punishment. Dear colleagues, I conclude by repeating what I said more than a year ago: human rights are not negotiable, they are part of our collective responsibility as human beings and Europeans.

name: Milan ZVER
text: - I understand your position, Madam High Representative, that an agreement with Iran, a nuclear agreement, is necessary.I also understand that you estimate that it even works in some segments, but I do not understand why we should not have a slightly more comprehensive, holistic approach to Iran when assessing its role in the region as well as in Iran itself.You know that this theocracy practically systematically and systematically violates human rights, we have heard dozens of people executed every month and so on, and you in silence.At the same time, the Iranian regime also acts as a destabilizer in the region, developing ballistic missiles, funding Hezbollah and other terrorist organizations, laundering money for terrorism, supporting Assad with bloody hands, and so on.In short, Iran is not a country that would be a factor of stability, democracy and peace, but on the contrary, something will have to change.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr. President, although the intention of the Iranian Nuclear Agreement was good in terms of stopping the spread of nuclear weapons and achieving peace, that agreement has not yielded the desired results so far. It is an agreement with an undemocratic regime, a regime that has more than doubled the number of executions in recent years and reached its highest level in 25 years. Violations of human rights, violations of women's rights, as well as minority rights, have been sidelined in reaching an agreement on the nuclear program and are still in the background today, while the Iranian authorities pass even stricter laws against women's rights, and Iran remains the leading executor of minors. who committed offenses. According to the State Department's annual report, Iran remains the world's leading financier of terrorist organizations and their activities and acts as a destabilizing factor in the Middle East. Iran has made almost no progress, and the parties to the agreement are keeping quiet about it for fear that Iran will not activate its nuclear program, which we can by no means call a partnership.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me clarify a couple of things that most of the speakers here have underlined, but which I think might be usefully remembered for others. First of all, the purpose of the nuclear deal with Iran – the name says it very clearly – is nuclear, and only nuclear. Was this a right or wise choice or not? It was taken 14 years ago at the beginning of the negotiations, and I don’t believe I disclose a secret if I say that it was the decision of the Gulf countries and the American administration at the time to limit the negotiations to purely nuclear issues. It was Iran at that time insisting on having a negotiation that would have included other aspects.  Was it a wise choice or not? Not for me or for you to judge it today, but the decision back then – not by Iran, by the way – was of a different kind. Since it was purely nuclear, we have facts certified by an agency that has proven to be crucial and will continue to prove to be crucial in other nuclear proliferation issues like the IAEA, certifying that nuclear commitments of the nuclear deal have been met constantly. It would not be wise to weaken the credibility of the agency, of the IAEA, when a few months or years from now we will hopefully need to push for the IAEA to enter and monitor other nuclear programmes. So if the agency testifies and certifies nine times after inspections, after technical work – and that needs to be happening in fully independent, non-political arguments for that on all sides – that the nuclear commitments under the nuclear agreements are met, then the deal is working. Full stop. That is a fact.  Then, second, does this mean that we are positive about Iran, that we trust Iran, that there is an optimism about the atmosphere? It is exactly because it is a country like Iran that you need to have a nuclear deal, because you do not want a country like Iran in that region to develop a nuclear weapon. If it was Switzerland, maybe we would be in a different position. It is not about being naive; it is the contrary. It is the lack of trust that makes the deal indispensable. And this was the reasoning of all the years of negotiations. This was the reason why the US administration engaged in this at that time, not having diplomatic relations with Iran, which is something that on the contrary most of the European Union Member States have. And there is one fundamental argument that some of you have raised: if we start saying that, with any change of administration, agreements and international commitments are put into question, we are not doing ourselves a favour, because nobody would accept negotiating any agreement, any international agreement with any administration of the future or of the present. In Latin we say: Pacta sunt servanda. That is the basis of any legal system of the world.  So it is exactly because there is and was no trust that an agreement was needed. Then it is true, not in an article of the JCPOA – I know it almost by heart by now – but in the preamble of the 104 pages of agreement, that there is a reference, half a sentence, that suggests that this agreement could open the way, could form the basis for a different kind of engagement, a more constructive engagement in the region. That sentence – here maybe I disclose a secret – was introduced at Iran’s request, because the Iranian leadership at the time, which is the same that has been reconfirmed today, intended to use the agreement as a way to ask their own population, their own public opinion, for a mandate to engage with the rest of the world in a political battle which we know very well has happened inside Iran and is continuing to happen. Some of you referred to the fact that undermining the full implementation of the nuclear deal also weakens those in Iran’s political scene who are trying to commit in their own way – which is not ours – towards an opening and an engagement with the rest of the world.  Weakening or putting into question the JCPOA is a way to strengthen the hardliners in the political scene in Iran. Is it convenient for us? Not for us, for sure. Having said that, what would happen if the deal was not there? Imagine that tomorrow the deal was no longer there. Would the human rights situation in Iran improve? Probably not; on the contrary, hardliners would be stronger. Would the regional behaviour of Iran improve? For sure it would not. Would the Iranian nuclear programme continue to be monitored? No. Would the IAEA have the means to be in the country? No. Would we be sure that Iran would not develop a nuclear programme that is purely peaceful? Definitely not, and enrichment would go up again tomorrow.  So is it convenient to keep the nuclear deal in place? Yes. This is the very simple argument that is keeping the entire world committed to the full implementation of the JCPOA, and I am confident that the United States of America will also remain committed to the full implementation of the JCPOA. This is what we discussed with Secretary of State Tillerson last week in Brussels, and this is the message we got from him. We are continuing to implement the agreement, and just today in Vienna the Secretary-General of the EEAS, Schmid, who has played a crucial role in these negotiations together with an excellent team from the European Union side, is chairing at deputy level the Joint Commission of the JCPOA once again. We do it regularly, sometimes at ministerial level. We did it last time in September with all the parties around the table. So I believe it is a matter of convenience; it is not a matter of being naive or ‘liking’ a system or a country. On the contrary. Two points I would like to clarify: one is related to the agreement. There is no sunset clause in the agreement – I know that this is often referred to. Read all the 104 pages of the agreement; there is no sunset clause to the agreement. The agreement has many different provisions with many different durations. Most of them last for a long, long time. Most of them last forever. And in the very beginning of the agreement there is the most important commitment taken by Iran: of never developing a nuclear weapon. This is a commitment that is there for ever as an NPT part.  So let’s stick to the facts. The nuclear deal, the nuclear commitment, fulfils more safety in the region and for us. That is why I said to our American friends that this is a matter of strategic relevance for European security. It is not about business, and it is not about the region; it is about security, because we do not want to see a region that is already troubled enough in a nuclear arms race. We miss just that. And then, good luck with North Korea: if we dismantle the only working deal on non-proliferation in the nuclear field, I want to see how we manage to peacefully solve the nuclear proliferation crisis that is currently ongoing. We have one deal that is preventing a nuclear proliferation, and we want to dismantle it? We must be crazy.  So I think, and I am confident, that we can continue to work to ensure that Iran continues to fulfil its commitments under the deal in full. That is the key point. The last point I would like to mention is on human rights, because it hurts me enormously when I hear voices saying that we stay silent on human rights. Actually, we are the ones that are more vocal on human rights when it comes to Iran. Look at President Trump’s speech. Look at the American discourse on the death penalty and compare it with the credibility on the death penalty that Europe has. Sorry to be blunt, but we have entered into a time where diplomacy has a different language. We are the ones raising individual cases, and we do it even today; in Vienna, issues were raised on individual cases. We are the ones who have started a human rights dialogue with Iran that regularly takes place. We are the ones, not others. And we are the ones raising this issue constantly. I don’t see others doing this. We never, ever avoid raising issues on human rights because of other reasons. We always do that, constantly and consistently, and sometimes – most of the time – we are the only ones. So let’s at least support and recognise the work we do. That is going to continue to be a very important aspect of our engagement with the country.  But again, I would say the most important thing for me are the social and the political dynamics inside the country. The Iranian population was celebrating the Iran deal, not because of nuclear issues, but because it was representing the opportunity to open up the country to international engagement. That is the investment that is smart to do as Europeans, and that is why I would like to thank this Hemicycle in its vast majority and the parliamentary delegations that travelled both to Iran and to Washington to support what is a fully united European Union position, when the entire world is looking at us to guarantee that the full implementation of the agreement is maintained by all sides.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thanks Vice President Mogherini.His marathon is not over and you will also stay with us for the next discussions.The discussion on this point is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: in writing. – Apparently, the Iran Nuclear Deal follows its course, and its implementation is flawless. I always viewed the Nuclear Deal as a pressure valve that would pave the way to a more cooperative and less belligerent Iran, more stability in the region, better life for its people, fewer human rights abuses, and more democracy.  These things are not happening! On the contrary; a much more well off Iran acts aggressively at regional level, from Yemen to Lebanon, and from Syria to Iraq. The EU is failing to raise any questions on matters like human rights or democratic principles in its relation with Iran. Our leniency towards Iran’s actions, before providing the alleged benefits, offers Teheran’s dictatorship regime the means to wreak havoc over a wide area. I believe it is in the EU’s interest to be more adamant in its relations with Iran. We must be clearer in stating the reasons for which we are backing the Nuclear Deal. We must also state the reasons for which we might back out from this deal. Iran’s answer to France’s request of dialogue, threatening Europe with an enlarged missile range is completely unacceptable. This is not a wise reaction and will not help in any way.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the discussion on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the announcement by US President Trump of recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel (2017/3012 (RSP)).

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the voice of the European Union has been heard loud and clear in all corners of the word after President Trump’s announcement on Jerusalem. We believe that Jerusalem shall be the capital of two states: West Jerusalem for the state of Israel and East Jerusalem for the state of Palestine. We believe that the only way to achieve this goal is through direct negotiations between the parties based on the 1967 borders and that there is no alternative solution that would be both viable and sustainable, meet the aspirations of the two sides and address the legitimate concerns. This is the position of the entire European Union and this is what all 28 Foreign Ministers said yesterday morning to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, one by one, in full unity. Our position is built on the most solid foundations. It is based on the Oslo Accords between Israeli and Palestinian leaders and on the international consensus embodied in UN Security Council Resolution 478. Our partners know very well where we stand and we have made it very clear – always, and during these last very difficult days. As a partner and as a friend, we have always been clear in our contacts with the United States, before and after the decision was taken. Exactly one week ago, I met with Rex Tillerson, the US Secretary of State, together with the 28 Foreign Ministers of the European Union Member States, and we invited the United States to carefully consider the repercussions that such a decision may have had on public opinion in the region and all around the world, because what happens in Jerusalem has global repercussions for good and for bad. This move risks strengthening radical forces in the region and weakening forces of wisdom and moderation, being completely counterproductive. We discussed these arguments with our American interlocutors, including a couple of days ago with Jared Kushner, President Trump’s Middle East adviser, and our contacts with our American friends will continue in the coming days and weeks.  The Israelis and the Palestinians also know where we stand and this makes us a credible, predictable and indispensable partner for them to restart a meaningful peace process. It therefore comes as no surprise that our meeting yesterday with Prime Minister Netanyahu was very open and frank. We did not hide our disagreements because this is what good friends and partners, as we are, should always do. We have made it clear that we will continue to respect the international consensus on Jerusalem as Europeans, including on the location of our embassies, until the final status of Jerusalem is resolved through direct negotiations between the parties.  At the same time, we understand Israel’s security concerns and we want to see them properly addressed. I took the opportunity of the visit of Prime Minister Netanyahu – the first one for more than 20 years – to condemn in the strongest possible terms all attacks against Jews everywhere in the world, including in Europe, and all attacks against Israeli citizens. At the same time, we believe that Israel’s security interests are best served by having a stable, viable, independent Palestinian state living in peace and security at the side of the Israeli state. This is what many great Israeli leaders have rightly believed throughout the years and this is what led Yitzhak Rabin to sign the Oslo Accords. I presented the very same position, very openly and very clearly, to our Palestinian and Arab friends. Last week, I spoke with President Abbas and guaranteed that the European Union will continue to work for Jerusalem to be the capital of both the state of Israel and the state of Palestine. We agreed with President Abbas that he will join us in Brussels on the occasion of the January Foreign Affairs Council, and we will have a similar discussion with him on the perspectives of the relaunch of the Middle East peace process that we had yesterday with Prime Minister Netanyahu. I also asked President Abbas to do all he can to make sure that all demonstrations remain peaceful. On Friday, in Brussels, I met with my Jordanian counterpart, and also my friend, Foreign Minister Ayman Al Safadi, and with him contacts have continued on a daily basis, actually several times a day. We are in contact with what we consider to be a key player at this moment because Jordan plays a very special role when it comes to Jerusalem. His Majesty the King of Jordan is the custodian of the holy sites, as agreed in the peace treaty between Israel and Jordan. He is also a very wise man and I believe all of us remember the very wise words he addressed to this very Chamber a couple of years ago. I thank the Minister for the restraint and the wisdom shown by Jordan in this difficult situation, including the work done by Jordan and others during the League of Arab States Ministerial Meeting in Cairo last Saturday, where the Arab Peace Initiative was recalled as a useful framework to re—advance the possibility to start negotiations. The steps taken by the Arab states in these days and in the coming days, in the near future, will be particularly important: to show leadership, wisdom, restraint and moderation, keeping the clearly defined position that we are backing in full consistency with our consolidated position and role.  I can say that I believe that, in these hours and days, the European Union is an important point of reference for the Arab world. Regardless of all the narratives and the rhetoric about the Arab world and the West, Europe constitutes an important point of reference to uphold the principle and the consensus developed on Jerusalem. For us Europeans this situation is a call to mobilise with even greater conviction for peace between Israel and Palestine. We are determined to play an even more active role in trying to provide, first, a political horizon for the two-state solution – there is no realistic alternative to two states – and, second, to work to create the appropriate international and regional framework to relaunch direct negotiations. So we will keep working. We are continuing to work at this time with both parties and with the Middle East Quartet, which means together with the United States, Russia and the United Nations. This format, as I have said in recent days, could possibly be enlarged to include key regional players such as Jordan and Egypt, but we could also involve other important partners, such as Norway, who could play an important part in supporting this process. The United States should – and could – continue to play an important role in that framework.  It is in the darkest hours, such as these, that the work of peacemakers becomes more difficult – yes – but more important. We must first of all engage to prevent any escalation around Jerusalem, which could have terrible consequences for the region and beyond, and we must engage to preserve the objective of two states and recreate the conditions for the peace process to restart – the key to restart the engine.  Let me conclude by saying that Jerusalem is not just a city. Jerusalem is the cradle of three faiths. Our ancestors believed that it was the centre of the entire world and the whole world still looks at Jerusalem. It can be a reason for division and even war or it can be the most powerful symbol of peace and reconciliation. The region and the world count on Europe – count on the European Union – to stay engaged with a clear, united message and clear, determined work and this is exactly what we are doing in the clearest and most united manner.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thanks Vice President Mogherini.Now let us listen to the opinion of the political groups.At this stage we will not accept "blue cards" because we are very late.Mrs Preda on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr. President, in 1995 the US Congress declared that Jerusalem should be recognized as the capital of Israel and that the US Embassy should be moved. The Clinton, Bush and Obama administrations have constantly used the notwithstanding clause of the Jerusalem Embassy Act to delay the implementation of the decision, without however contesting it. President Trump’s statement should come as no surprise, especially since he announced it during his election campaign. In the words of the statement, "the United States has not taken a position on the final status issues, including the precise limits of Israel's sovereignty over Jerusalem." This therefore does not contradict our position on the two-state solution, with Jerusalem as the capital. But I believe that one should look realistically at the role of the European Union in resolving the conflict. The reality is that our position is unfortunately weak. We felt it on the ground at the start of the year with the AFET mission in Israel and the Palestinian territories. In Jerusalem, we were told that we were too pro-Palestinian, and in Ramallah, we were told that nothing had been done for Palestine. Repeating that we are for the two-state solution will not magically make it happen. More must therefore be done for a lasting peace agreement and the resumption of direct negotiations. Finally, we must unequivocally condemn the violence and anti-Semitic acts that followed President Trump's announcement: Hamas rocket fire in Israel, burnt stars of David and Hamas flags waved in Berlin, Molotov cocktails against a synagogue in Gothenburg. and calls to “shoot the Jews” in Malmö; this is really unacceptable!

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, a complaint: this is the fifth debate in which blue cards have been denied to people like myself in the last three parliaments that I have been here. On an issue such as this, when there are so few people here who are able to speak, when there is going to be very few people supporting the idea of Jerusalem being the capital of Israel, I am absolutely appalled that once again a Member of this House is denied the access to have a speech on this. The fifth occasion I have had to face no blue cards. Thank you very much.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Excuse me, first of all no one has prevented you from speaking, at the moment the political groups are talking, they are presenting their evaluations, soon after it will be possible to use the "blue card".No one has forbidden or will forbid you to use it.So we pay attention when we receive some communications.Mrs Valenciano, on behalf of the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats, please.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, the truth is that the president of the United States of America, probably by electoral calculation, has come to set fire to the very fragile status quo that governs between Palestine and Israel. This statement is clearly a violation of international law, it is an illegality upon another illegality from the beginning. Israel has long been breaking international norms and, unfortunately, not just in relation to Jerusalem. The United States, which has so far been guarantors and intermediaries of the Middle East peace process, has preferred to renounce that role. It is very difficult for us to continue to trust the United States as guarantor of anything after we have thrown the balance in this way. President Trump does a disservice to the cause of peace and, of course, to his international commitments. I think it is time for the European Union to take the lead. We have said it many times, but this must be the most timely at this time and I believe that the response to Donald Trump's action is precisely the recognition of Palestine as a State. That is the response that deserves the provocation of Donald Trump and above all it is what we owe to the Palestinian people. This is a serious and irresponsible decision and it is time for the European Union to make a show of force: of political force and of moral force. I understand very well the prudence of the High Representative, but, really, it is a great occasion to give a political and moral lesson to both Israel and the United States. I don't know what else we have to wait for. It is time to recognize the Palestinian state.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Anyone who knows the history knows the bond of the Jewish people with Jerusalem. The EU and its member states refuse to pour clear wine on the Jewish state of Israel and its capital Jerusalem. So different the word of Israel's god and that really weighs the most for me and many Christians in Europe and not the word of Mrs. Mogherini. High Representative, you have invited the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, to Brussels for January 2018. In this context, I would like to bring to your attention a recent report on radicalization in Palestinian education. I've got it here with me, I'll give you a copy. It is very serious that Palestinian schoolchildren are taught by textbooks that incite hatred and violence. I therefore urge you to discuss this serious report with Mahmoud Abbas. High Representative, the blatant Palestinian denial of the age-old Jewish connection to the Holy Land and its holy capital, Jerusalem, utterly blocks any peaceful resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. How do you even see this connection of people, country and state and city?

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - It seemed yesterday that President Trump promised us to resolve the conflict in the Middle East. He hinted it would be "a breeze." He said, "I will be a great solution", he would provide a great solution. What he is doing now is of course completely the opposite. With his statement, he goes wildly against international law. He has sown fear, division and hatred. Actually, as we say, he played with a match next to the powder keg and I am a little afraid that with his statements and with his decision he has put the death knell on the peace process. This should encourage us more than ever to take up our role. I agree, we need a strong and united Europe. Our role is more important than ever to get back to the two-state solution, to advocate for respect for human rights, to find a negotiated solution. But Mrs Mogherini, we have been having this debate here for months and you yourself say, "yes, I have to find the key to start that car". Well, I have some very specific questions for you. But you should know that the ALDE group really wants to support you and encourage you to let Europe play its part in this. We must ensure that this conflict is resolved once and for all, that there is a negotiated solution. You say very clearly, "See, we want to play our part. We want to play a bigger part." What does that mean in concrete terms? What will we do if the US continues that course? How are we going to raise that with our "friends in the United States," as you put it? What are we going to do with the human rights violations, the settlements, the reclaiming of the destroyed property? I've talked about that before. How will we deal with that? Mrs Mogherini, I wish you a lot of courage, a lot of strength, a lot of strength. Let's hope we can make peace in the Middle East in 2018 to achieve.It may be a distant dream, but you can count on us.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, we unequivocally condemn the US decision to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. This decision only serves to perpetuate the occupation of Palestine and the political instability in the wider Middle East region and causes a new cycle of bloodshed with dead and thousands injured, mainly civilians and children. The Jerusalem regime is a central issue for a comprehensive Palestinian solution. The position of the international community is that East Jerusalem should be the capital of the independent Palestinian state. The US decision to relocate its embassy to Jerusalem shows its blatant imperialist aggression against the Palestinian people and their complete entanglement with the occupying state of Israel. It ignores the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people and the need for an independent, sovereign, viable Palestinian state on the 1967 border with East Jerusalem as its capital. Resolution 181 of 1947, of the UN General Assembly, established the special international regime for Jerusalem. UN Security Council Resolution 478 also stipulates that all legislative and administrative measures and actions taken by Israel as an occupying power that have changed or attempted to change the character and status of Jerusalem are invalid, never take place and must be lifted immediately. . But occupied Israel continues today with the systematic expansion of illegal settlements, the illegal demolition of buildings, schools and houses and the expulsion of Palestinians from East Jerusalem. At the same time, it continues to commit criminally undisturbed blatant violations of Palestinian human rights, international law and all UN resolutions, which provide for the withdrawal of the occupying forces from all territories. With the policy of equal distances, Mrs Mogherini, the European Union has heavy responsibilities for Israel's continuing crimes against the Palestinian people.We welcome the positive attitude of the European Union and its Member States, but the European Union must take drastic action, demand the compliance of Israel and recognize the Palestinian state.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Sir. Chairman! Thank you, and thank you to Mrs Mogherini! We hope we can stick together on this issue. International law is the only common language we have in the world, which is why Donald Trump's declaration of Jerusalem is dramatic. According to a series of UN resolutions, no later than 2334 from last year, there is no doubt: East Jerusalem is occupied by Israel, and the solution is two states with Jerusalem as the shared capital. The US strategy is dangerous and destabilizing the region, and it must finally be clear to everyone that the US can neither will nor will be an honest mediator in the conflict. Now it is up to the EU to take real diplomatic steps, so that we can finally start a peace process. I would like to repeat what you said before, Mrs Mogherini: there is no acceptable alternative to the two-state solution! We have several legal remedies available that should be used. The EU is Israel's most important trading partner. Therefore, the Association Agreement should be suspended for the time being. Israel is clearly breaking its share. Then there is the separation strategy - "differentiation" - where all contact with the illegal settlements stops. This strategy is mentioned in UN Resolution 2334 by the Council of Ministers and also by Parliament. And then I would also like to remind you of the recognition. Finally, it is high time to put an end to Netanyahu's 'impunity' and demand that Israel pay us back for its destruction of EU-funded emergency aid facilities in the West Bank, as demanded by dozens of MEPs in European and Israeli newspapers. in recent days.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, someone in the end launched a bomb, and it was not Kim Jong-un. The decision by President Trump to recognise Jerusalem as Israel’s capital is the diplomatic equivalent of using a nuclear weapon. It is a choice that is reckless, irresponsible and indeed damaging for both the Israeli and the Palestinian people and is detrimental to the prospects for an already difficult peace process. The consequences are in front of all of us: six consecutive days of clashes, four Palestinians dead so far, and more than 1 200 wounded, one Israeli stabbed. Tens of thousands are demonstrating in a range of Middle Eastern and Muslim nations. Daesh is probably rejoicing for the free propaganda.  What saddens me the most is that these casualties happened just for Trump’s electoral purposes: they were totally avoidable. That is why they are even more unjustifiable. Jerusalem cannot just be the capital of Israel, or even less just the capital of Palestine. It must be the capital of both states, and we must recognise Palestine as a state, as provided for in the Oslo agreements. I dare to say, given its unique status as a holy city for the three great monotheistic religions, that Jerusalem should be the heritage and capital of all mankind.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mrs Mogherini, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! The GDR was not recognized as a state by the Federal Republic of Germany. Therefore, no embassy was opened there, but a permanent representation. East Berlin was not a fully fledged part of the GDR. As a city as a whole, Berlin was subject to four-power status. But it never occurred to anyone not to set up the permanent representation in East Berlin. All EU countries naturally had their embassies in East Berlin and not in Dresden or Leipzig or anywhere else. It is therefore quite remarkable that a state like Germany and other EU states that recognize Israel as a state - with a Chancellor who says: Israel's security is the German reason of state - that such a country does not get its message across Capital, in the self-chosen, sovereignly chosen capital of a state. It is also noteworthy that the High Representative advocates the one-state solution for all of Europe and her supporters the two-state solution for Israel. That is wrong, and there will only be security in this region if the Palestinians also recognize that Jerusalem is the capital of Israel.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: - Mr President, the decision of the United States to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel has ignited another fire in the flaming Middle East, with Palestinians dead, wounded and the mass condemnation of the peoples of the region. The United States seeks to legitimize the Israeli occupation, the ongoing crime against the Palestinian people through killings, imprisonment, walls, settlements. This is a development linked to more general imperialist plans in the region to change borders, with the aim of controlling energy sources and their transportation routes. These competitions also dictate the differences between Germany, Britain and France. It is a great responsibility of the European Union, Mrs Mogherini, to upgrade its relations with Israel, identifying the perpetrator with the victim and declaring terrorism the just struggle of the Palestinian people. The Greek government, which adorns the aggressive policy of the United States as devilishly good, is upgrading its relations with Israel, without proceeding with the recognition of the Palestinian state. Solidarity, then, with the Palestinian people, in their struggle for the immediate recognition of the independent Palestinian state, with East Jerusalem as its capital on the 1967 border!

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Requests for "blue cards" will now also be accepted in the debate.Mrs Petir, one minute and thirty.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr. President, achieving peace in the Middle East is one of the very high priorities, the realization of which we have not contributed to so far, neither the European Union nor the United States. Achieving peace in the Middle East does not depend on the status of Jerusalem, but on the deradicalization of societies there and the establishment of democracy and respect for human rights. We must note that a number of states today that oppose the recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel are essentially opposed to the existence of the state of Israel as a Jewish state. This also takes on an additional dimension in light of the recent terrorist attacks on the Jewish community in Jerusalem, but also in Sweden where an anti-Semitic protest and a bomb attack on a synagogue took place. These are real problems that we must tackle with due seriousness, because the European Union has been indifferent for too long to the situation in the Middle East, as well as to the radicalization that is taking place on its soil. I believe that President Trump, in opting for a proactive US policy in the Middle East, has considered all aspects of his decision and that in cooperation with Saudi Arabia and other Sunni states he has reached a certain level of agreement by recognizing Jerusalem as Israel’s capital. Such a decision should not be seen as opposed to the position of the European Union and the solution of two states for two peoples. On the contrary, I want to hope that this will encourage all parties to act faster and more efficiently, and that Jerusalem will continue to be, and above all, a holy city of Christians, Jews and Muslims. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleague, I would kindly to ask you to name one Member State of the European Union which is opposing the existence of the State of Israel.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: the answer to the question posed by raising the blue card.- Thank you very much for the question you asked.All these debates that we have witnessed in recent days that followed as a reaction to the recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel, I think are hasty, to prejudge possible future situations, and some of them, I did not talk about European but spoke in principle about countries that react very violently,they certainly have both an anti-Semitic attitude and a background at the root of their reaction.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the response that the European Union has given to Trump's provocative choice to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel has been clear and clear, and it is right and right for this Parliament to recognize it. Moreover, the move of the American administration not only infringes international law, but risks undermining the very principle of "two states two peoples", which is at the basis of any peace process. The price of this move can be high, as both Palestinian and Arab reactions show, and it can upset the already fragile balance in the region. So, the answer you gave to the Israeli Prime Minister yesterday in Brussels is clear and clear, but I don't think it is enough. The time has come to make Netanyahu and his government feel even more the pressure of the European Union, and I think that in order to prevent ours from turning only into a cry for the moon, it is essential to tell the Council to make this ours consistent. position with the same policies towards Israel. Use the association agreement and trade policies themselves to introduce strict conditionalities. And I think it's time now to do it.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: - Sir.Chairman!It is fitting today to wish Jews around the world a happy Hanukkah.And precisely Hanukkah and a lot of other historical facts bind the Jews to Jerusalem and the state of Israel.The modern state of Israel's struggle for survival against the aggression that has been shown from all neighboring countries, and in spite of, now makes the Americans, after more than 10 years, after 10 years after it has been adopted democratically in the US Parliament, now finally movethe embassy of Jerusalem.It is unfortunate that no EU country has dared to acknowledge the same.It is unfortunate to hear all the hypocrisy that is taking place here in the Chamber.It is the same hall that - we believe - must completely unconditionally recognize a Palestinian state.And therefore there is only to say to the Jewish people: There is someone still standing with you, and Jerusalem is unconditionally the real capital of the state of Israel!

name: Frédérique RIES
text: - Mr. President, what else to say that has not been said since the announcement of the American president last Wednesday? To reiterate, first, even though it has been said and repeated this evening, that we condemn in the strongest terms all acts and calls for violence against the Jews of these last days. For the rest, I have two convictions as deep as the other. Yes, Jerusalem has been the capital of Israel for over 60 years, the alpha and omega, the horizon of the Jews for 150 generations.
