We can't say anything else except rewrite history. In this then, President Trump is only recalling, even re-establishing the truth. In this, and in substance, he is right. Now, in form and in time, unlike many here, I don't have a crystal ball and I don't know if, past the emotional moment, this American decision will be the bearer of long-term violence or if it maybe has a chance to shake things up. It is clear that American diplomacy risks losing its mediator status for the next few years, and this is undoubtedly the luck and the duty of Europeans: now invent new ways to relaunch the peace process. . Better balance, Madame Mogherini. European equidistance is far from being accepted as such in Israel. A new tempo around tracks that are known, always the same in essence, from the Clinton settings to Camp David. It’s Hanukkah tonight, Mr. President. An excellent Hanukkah feast for the millions of Jews around the world, who light the first candle to celebrate - I conclude - the light and the victory of the spirit over violence, a nice punctuation for our debate.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: - Mister President!With his Jerusalem plans, Mr Trump acted as an arsonist, willfully incited hatred and deliberately and seriously endangered the peace process in the Middle East.New violence is the result.But I also say: Burning Israeli flags and anti-Semitic attacks should not be the answer.Now more than ever, the EU needs a common voice of reason and prudence for a two-state solution, for the power of negotiation against the power of war.Europe must play an even more active role in the mediation process.Because Mr Trump has just left this process as a mediator.The EU must act now.Ms Mogherini, what do you think if you on the one hand announce greater efforts for a peace process, but at the same time stress that there will be no specific EU initiative?But that is exactly what the world needs now.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: - Mr President, Madam High Representative, it is an MEP who has just been banned from entering Israel who is addressing you. I salute the efforts you are making and the balance that the European Union has always tried to achieve in this conflict, and I fully share the elements that you have brought forward as well as what has been said by many of my colleagues. Simply, the difficulty we have at this point is that your calls for reason, your calls for peace, your calls for negotiation are not being heard, whether by Mr. Trump - it is obvious. now - but also by Mr. Netanyahu. I asked you, a year ago, ex officio of course, whether we intended to enter with Israel on the issue of negotiations on war damages, on the destruction of what the European Union finances. I know you are concerned about this issue, so I will come back to you a year later. You know that Haaretz has just published the invoice that 57 MEPs sent, on behalf of the European Union, for this destruction. So I would like us to also be able to enter into a dialogue on this issue, which touches the lives of thousands of civilians who have nothing to do with violence, but simply with their dignity that they want to regain.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after the 1967 war, Israel occupied East Jerusalem and the West Bank territories in open violation of international law. There are 320,000 Palestinians in Jerusalem alone, whose civil rights are being squeezed by the Israeli authorities. The recognition by the United States of occupied Jerusalem as the capital of Israel is a dangerous unilateral act that undermines several principles of international law. It ignores both the UN resolutions, which emphasize Jerusalem's special status, and the 2004 International Court of Justice ruling, which defines Israel as an occupying power in some territories that include East Jerusalem. Above all, it dramatically undermines any hope of a solution. to two states, triggers further tensions and violence, with dramatic consequences in terms of clashes, injuries and human lives. The position of my delegation, the 5 Star Movement, on the Israeli-Palestinian question has always been consistent and in line with the provisions of international law: "two peoples, two states", removal of illegal Israeli settlements in the occupied territories and respect by Israel's infrastructure financed with European money in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. I conclude with a quote from an Israeli writer, Grossman: "Israelis and Palestinians do not need to erect a wall to separate them, they need to tear down the wall that divides them."

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: – Mr President, let me start with some facts. Except in some periods under the Crusaders, Jerusalem has never been the capital of any country other than Israel, and never for any other people except the Jewish people. The US demands to move its embassy to West Jerusalem, which has been part of the State of Israel since its foundation. Having said this, it would have been preferable if this US decision had been taken as a result of direct negotiations between the parties, so it is therefore a correct decision in principle but with adverse timing. According to the High Representative, the EU as a whole stands behind the position of not recognising Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. Ms Mogherini calls the unilateral decision of the US very worrying. Fair enough. However, why is it that the High Representative did not denounce another unilateral decision, about recognising the Palestinian State, taken by the Swedish Socialist Government in 2014? Why is it that the High Representative is expressing deep worries regarding one unilateral move, but not another? Where is the consistent and balanced approach towards Israel, Ms Mogherini?

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: - Mr President! The question is: Who owns the status of Jerusalem? Yes, Donald Trump he apparently thought he was the one. He only fulfills an election promise, he says, and then he decides in one fell swoop that Jerusalem is the capital of Israel. The decision is not compatible with international law, not with UN Security Council resolutions, and it has led to strong reactions, increased instability, violence and unrest. But none of this Trump needs to worry about. Instead, it is synagogues that are burning. Israelis and Palestinians who are injured, stoned, killed, and in my country, in Gothenburg and Malmö, synagogues have also been attacked, which is terrible. Jerusalem belongs to Jews, Muslims, Christians, Palestinians and Israelis. A two-state solution with Jerusalem as the capital of both Palestine and Israel is the core of such a solution. Now the EU must take the lead. Now we must get this in order and find out before it has even worse consequences than those we have already seen in recent days.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, I wish a happy Hanukkah to all those who celebrate this feast of lights. The statement by President Trump recognising Jerusalem as Israel’s capital is basically repeating what the US Congress and Senate already said with an overwhelming majority in 1995. It does not threaten the peace process and does not change anything about the accessibility of the holy sites, but simply recognises the fact that it has been a most important place for Jews for 3 000 years and the capital of the state of Israel since 1949. For Israel it is a confirmation of what in fact already exists and nothing more.  However, we have notoriously seen an aggressive reaction from the Palestinian Government and Hamas. They call for a third intifada, they shout anti—Semitic slogans, fire rockets on Israel and so on. They attack innocent civilians. So, Madam High Representative, President Trump’s announcement might be seen as politically insensitive, but the response is outrageous. I therefore call on you to condemn this response in strong words and to call on these undemocratic Palestinian leaders to react to this US statement by addressing President Trump, not Israel, to refrain from calling for violence and to restore democracy in Palestinian areas. I think this would be a solution.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: - President Trump has announced an intention that goes far beyond the competencies he was given as president of his country and one of the leading leaders in world politics. For now, by announcing the recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of the state of Israel, it has sparked criticism and outrage from the international public. Not only that, he further irresponsibly and without regard to the long history of attempts to solve this problem burdened relations between Israel and its Arab neighbors, challenged Muslims, humiliated Palestinians. If he sincerely believed that during his term he could contribute to the solution of the Palestinian-Israeli problem and to the lasting reconciliation of the peoples, who must find a way to peaceful coexistence and mutual recognition, then the move he announced will certainly not contribute to that goal. . It is right, colleagues, to support the position expressed by High Representative Mogherini, and previously also by President Macron and many other European leaders, to Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu. It would be time for Europe to support its commitment to Middle East peace and a just solution to the conflict by recognizing the State of Palestine and resolutely opposing unilateral moves that prevent the only possible international law solution to the two countries, Israel and Palestine. We know that an alternative to a peaceful solution in this area is bloodshed, and this is already happening today. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8))

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: blue-card question. – You have just said that Mr Trump went beyond his competencies as the President of the United States in recognising Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. Were you one of those who voted in this Chamber to recognise Palestine as a country, which went beyond the competencies of this Parliament when it did not have the powers under any treaty to recognise that country, or is it simply that you are pro—Abbas and Palestine and anti-Israel? One rule for one and one rule for another.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: The answer to the question posed by raising a blue card.- Dear colleague, I am much less one-sided and emotional than you are when you defend your case.I think it would be absurd to suggest that the capital of the United States should be, for example, Dallas in Texas or Anchorage in North America.In short, I think this has nothing to do with the competencies of the president of one or any of the countries.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: - Mr President, Madam High Representative, thank you for your opening statement, but since Mr Trump takes the risk of sidelining the United States from international law, I believe it is up to you , it is up to the European Union, because of our geographical, historical and cultural ties with the Israeli and Palestinian peoples, to take up the torch of diplomatic, political and even economic initiatives if necessary. First, beyond the Quartet, should we not seek to convene an international conference on the basis of international law, justice and peace? Secondly, should we not produce an important political act in accordance with international law, that is to say that of recognizing the State of Palestine within the borders defined in 1967, with East Jerusalem as its capital, and not a Rump state as we are being offered? Thirdly, you have an asset to promote: Article 2 of the Association Agreement and all the texts which are partnership agreements between the European Union and Israel. Has not the time come, in the name of the law, to brandish and activate them? (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: “blue card” question.- Mr. President, Mr. Deputy, why has France not recognized Palestine?I'm not talking about the France of President Macron, but the France of Mr. Mitterrand, whom you supported at the time.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: answer "blue card".- François Mitterrand made a lot of speeches with regard to Palestine and for the recognition of Palestine, but I inform you that the two chambers of the French Parliament voted for the recognition of the State of Palestine, as is in conformityin four United Nations resolutions and the opposite of what you said earlier.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: - Mr President, Mrs Mogherini!President Trump's decision was a mistake.It also has nothing to do with the peace process.It is supposed to calm down his coalition of ultra-conservative Jews and radical Christians alone.I am not against Jerusalem being the capital of Israel.But we're not playing Monopoly here, where the one who has money buys a town.If Jerusalem is recognized as the capital, it is also recognized as such for the Palestinians.But not out of whim, but as part of a comprehensive peace process.Speaking of which: the US has gambled away its role as an impartial mediator.The EU must now find its way into this void.It has the economic and political power and the reputation to be involved in resolving this conflict.As we have seen, we are feeling the effects of the conflicts in the Middle East more and more often and more intensely.That too should be a drive.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Madam President, High Representative! Jerusalem is the capital of Israel. Millions of Europeans are concerned here with respect for 3,000 years of Jewish history, with respect for 70 years of Israel's state history. It's not about the inventions of modern times. Let's name another problem: In Berlin, in Paris, across Europe, Palestinians and their allies are currently demonstrating against Israel. They burn Israeli flags, set fire to banners with the Star of David, and the police let them. I am feeling ashamed for that. Those who burn flags presumably burn all decency and tolerance and spread hatred that is devastating to humans. Hate must never be our partner! Let us stand up against all the new anti-Semitic, anti-Zionist violence! We have courage! Let's set an example as Europeans! Let's stand by the only democracy in the Middle East - Israel's right to exist, Jewish culture! As Europeans we have to send a clear message: Jerusalem is the capital of Israel.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, the dangerous decision taken by the Trump administration illustrates that no matter what the cost, they will do whatever it takes to deflect attention from trouble at home. It is shameful and wrong that they are playing fast and loose with a region already unstable. Palestinians have suffered at the hands of Israel for decades, and now the Trump administration is rubbing salt into their wounds.  The US can no longer claim to act as a neutral player in the region, but the UN and the EU must show leadership, and the EU must apply sanctions and end business as usual. This means an arms embargo on Israel and an immediate suspension of the EU-Israel Association Agreement until Israel upholds human rights and international law. The Irish Government must also take on a role of leadership. Criticising the decision will make little impact on the long-suffering people of Palestine. The Irish Government needs to recognise the State of Palestine immediately, especially as a response to the unacceptable action of the Trump administration.

name: Maria ARENA
text: - Madam President, Madam High Representative, although I am one of those who believe that yesterday's meeting with Benjamin Netanyahu should never have taken place in this context, I thank you especially for your firm attitude towards him. I will still have three questions in relation to this meeting and in relation to Mr. Trump's statement. After Mr. Trump's unilateral and irrational announcement, which is more than regrettable - it is reprehensible because it flouts international laws - are you ready, Madam High Representative, to play the role of mediator to relaunch the talks peace on the basis of United Nations resolutions? I think the European Union has the tools - we have talked about the Association Agreement - it has the strength, but above all it has the political responsibility for peace in the Middle East, but also for the live together in Europe. Second question: In addition to the settlement ideology of the Netanyahu government, supported by Mr. Trump, the policy of destroying Palestinian infrastructure funded by the European Union and member states demonstrates the arrogance of the current Israeli government. Are you ready, Madam High Representative, to demand compensation? Finally, the third question: Do you share the idea that the Association Council cannot meet until we have some progress on Israel's side?

name: Arne LIETZ
text: - Madam President, dear Federica Mogherini! Trump's current unilateral recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel runs counter to a two-state solution and a peace process in the Middle East. I expressly support the clear stance of the EU foreign representative, who repeatedly criticized the decision of the US president with clear words. Federica Mogherini is thus strengthening the message of the EU member states, who already publicly spoke out against the unilateral decision of the USA on Jerusalem last Friday at the United Nations. A strong performance that didn’t miss its impact. Especially in such important issues as the Middle East conflict, we Europeans can and must together - without going it alone nationally - form a counterweight to states that disregard international law and violate UN resolutions. I am also including the honorable Members here today in this Chamber, who have also spoken out against it. Thank you very much, Mrs Mogherini, for your tireless diplomatic activities. In this region in particular - as in Jordan, for example - it is important not to give up now, but to act with vigor because the USA has left a gap.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: – Madam President, I think the two-state model is actually the reason why the so-called peace process has made so little progress over the past 23 years. Firstly, Israel will not withdraw their military from the West Bank. One only needs to look at the map to understand why. Secondly, Israel will not evacuate half a million Jews from the West Bank and East Jerusalem, as that would result in a civil war. With the Israeli military presence and the settlements, a viable Palestinian State is hardly possible. Any serious plan should be based on what is possible and realistic. I think the recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel by Mr Trump could be the first step out of this deadlock.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: - Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, I have Greek citizenship but I also have Palestinian citizenship. Yesterday, you welcomed Mr. Netanyahu as a friend and collaborator in the perspective of a two-state solution. This friend of yours is known worldwide for being responsible for the situation depicted on this map, which shows Palestine - it started from here - here in dots with enclosed and destroyed villages. This really depicts the occupation of a state, who is the conqueror and who is the conquered. This map is an insult to the world community. Do you really think, Mrs Mogherini, that there can be a two-state solution? Did you say all this to Mr. Netanyahu yesterday when you met him, to your friend Mr. Netanyahu? Did you really tell him that he must be persona non grata for Europe, precisely for the crimes he has committed? These, Mrs Mogherini!

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: - Madam president. Lady Mogherini. I think it is quite evident that Trump's decision is a flagrant violation of international law, a unilateral action, breaking all the consensus of the international community, a disregard for the agreements made in the past and a decision, furthermore, that is generating , as we are already seeing, more instability in the region. A decision, moreover, that contradicts what was agreed by Israel in 1993 in the Oslo Accords to find a negotiated status for Jerusalem. I am one of those who believe that Netanyahu's visit this week, High Representative, was a mistake, but I want to acknowledge the firmness with which she has responded to Trump's decision. And I also want to thank her for his initiative for President Abás to come to Brussels in January as well. In any case, it is time to think about what we can do as Europeans. And from this point of view, I believe that betting on a two-state solution —as you have said—, betting on the instruments that we have —as mentioned, for example using the articles of the Association Agreement—, also finally betting on a policy of differentiation, something that we have been demanding for some time. Now is the time to take action and go on the diplomatic offensive.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Madam President, President Trump has recognised Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. This announcement, and the decision to move the US embassy, is a counterproductive measure that will damage the chances of peace. He has completely disregarded East Jerusalem and any reference to Palestinian aspirations for a capital of their own in the city. He is putting the US in violation of UN resolutions 476 and 478 by recognising part, or all, of East Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. This poorly judged announcement has triggered words of concern and condemnation from around the globe. The entire Middle East has braced itself for the prospect of social unrest. How on earth can this decision be a constructive step towards peace? The sheer incompetence coming from the President of the US is unprecedented in my lifetime.  On our side, I thank the High Representative for her statement. We are here to reaffirm that the two-state solution is the only scenario we will ever accept for Israel and Palestine. Let us seize the moment to re-launch negotiations between Israel and Palestine for a lasting solution that works for all of the people. Finally, to our Jewish brothers and sisters, Happy Hanukkah.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I will try to address most of the questions and the comments with two or three observations.  One: our role and the US role. Is this move from the United States a possibility for the European Union to play the mediator role alone? Is the US discredited as an honest broker, as many think in the Arab world? Can we go forward alone? I want to be very clear: I believe that it is not in anyone’s interests to see the United States’ role discredited. It is in everybody’s interest to make sure that we create the appropriate regional international framework that can accompany the restart of talks.  This is not the situation today, but I believe it is the responsible role of the European Union to try to help moving in that direction. Peace will not happen with the United States working alone on a plan, but peace will not happen without the United States being credibly engaged. I believe it is first of all an interest that our Palestinian and Arab friends share that we get to a point where together – and this is why we are engaging in the Quartet and with others in the region – we join forces. It is not either/or. It is not either a European Union initiative or a US initiative or anybody else’s initiative. We have to join forces. This is why I said there is not going to be a European Union-specific initiative or a specific mediating role that I am going to take or that we are going to suggest. No, we need to unite and join forces because this is not an easy conflict to solve, and we need all the relevant players to be engaged, but on a clear political horizon: two states, Jerusalem the capital of both, and steps that can be accompanied by this regional international framework to help the parties get there.  This is also why I did not say to Prime Minister Netanyahu that he is persona non grata – definitely not. He is the Prime Minister of Israel. I made it very clear – very clear – that we disagree on many different things, and I was probably clear even beyond what is normally done in diplomatic terms, because this is the way in which things should be. The European Union has a clear position. It states very clearly, it is consistent, and all its Member States are consistent with it: we are not going to move embassies, we are not going to recognise Jerusalem as the capital of the State of Israel until the final status of Jerusalem is determined through direct negotiations, and we want to see two states where Jerusalem is the capital of both.  We are very clear on that but we talk to everybody, starting with the parties. The European Union is well positioned, and is credible. I know that sometimes it is not perceived like this, but it is a credible interlocutor and partner for the two parties, the regional relevant players and the international community. Otherwise Prime Minister Netanyahu would not have been in Brussels yesterday morning, meeting the European Union and discussing the perspective with us. Even if I disagree with him on many things, I appreciate the fact that he visited and I think it is useful that we engage first of all with the parties on the way forward. And, by the way, it would be a little bit strange to play the mediator role and not talk to one of the parties. This is not even in nature, I have to tell you.  The second point: what is the priority now? First, to keep the situation on the ground calm, and this is why I am insisting on this report, which we need to give it to Jordan and to His Majesty the King of Jordan. Keep the situation calm in and around Jerusalem, and not to allow violence or escalation to take root. Second – and this goes together with it – to support the forces of wisdom in the region and to avoid a vacuum on the political scene, which would open the way for radical forces to benefit from this development. This is a specific role that the European Union can play because of our position; that is very clear and loud. The risk that I see is that the discourse gets polarised and that the forces that have always worked for peace, including in the Arab world, get isolated and marginalised, and that radicals take the leading role. This is a risk that Israel cannot afford, and that the Palestinians cannot afford either. The Palestinian leadership has always been ready to engage in dialogue for peace, in direct negotiations, and it would be damaging to both the Palestinians and the Israelis, but it is a risk that we are running. Third, as I said, keeping the political horizon, the political objective, very clear: two states with Jerusalem as the capital of both. Fourth, building an international and regional framework that can accompany the restart of direct negotiations. And last but not least – this is our own homework – I was pleased to see full unity in the Foreign Affairs Council yesterday (we always underline whenever we have a little comma that is different one from the other); 28 Member States fully in line, singing with different voices exactly the same song, consistent with the united position we have and have constantly had. This is what makes us powerful in passing the message, and I believe that this is going to be key for the continuation of our work. Last but not least, I took the opportunity of Prime Minister Netanyahu’s visit yesterday in Brussels to wish him a Happy Hanukkah already, but please do not turn a religious celebration into a political argument. This is very dangerous, and it is not respectful to religions. Maybe it is because I was born a few hundred metres away from the Vatican that I think this. This should not be done, and especially this should not be done when we are discussing the situation in Jerusalem. It is dangerous; religion should never ever be used for political purposes on either side.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The conversation is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - The president of the United States of America, by electoral calculation, has set fire to the very fragile status quo that governs between Palestine and Israel. This statement is a clear violation of international law. An illegality upon another illegality, on the appropriation that Israel made of its Basic Law in 1980, declared void by the Security Council. The State of Israel from its birth has violated international standards and, unfortunately, not only in relation to Jerusalem. The United States, until now guarantor and intermediary of the peace process in the Middle East, prefers to lose that condition and now passes with Israel to the side of those who break the rules. The European Union must take moral leadership in the peace process and definitively ensure the recognition of Palestine as a state. That is the answer to the statement. Member States must react by supporting the new State. The European Union can make a show of political and moral force, accompanying the recognition of the new state with intensive economic support, to make the reconciliation agreement between the Palestinians viable and to lift Gaza from desolation.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- President Trump's announcement on the capital of Jerusalem is not only a bomb against peace in the Middle East, but is an affront against international law and against the entire world community.According to the United Nations, East Jerusalem is the capital of Palestine and Israel's claim to appropriate all of it is only understood from a racist perspective and of ethnic cleansing of the Palestinians.It is the denial of the other through contempt for legality and force.The European Union must firmly reinforce international resolutions, recognize the Palestinian State with its capital in East Jerusalem and, at least, show before those who violate the world the same firmness that they show with small countries.The EU should be present diplomatically in East Jerusalem to show support for a Palestinian state against those who seek the imposition of an apartheid state as racist South Africa was in the past.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - Donald Trump’s decision to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel is a real obstacle to building peace. This unilateral decision could have dramatic consequences on the ground in the Middle East. I would like to reiterate, once again, that the two-state solution based on the 1967 borders is the only way to achieve lasting peace between the Israelis and the Palestinians. There is no alternative! This coexistence must be thought of with Jerusalem as the common capital of Israel and Palestine. I am happy that the foreign ministers of the Member States, together with the High Representative, showed their unity last Monday by unanimously recalling their commitment to the two-State solution. The Union must be fully engaged within the Quartet and in cooperation with regional actors in order to take initiatives and promote the resumption of dialogue between the Palestinian and Israeli authorities. The European Union must redouble its efforts to obtain concrete results for the resolution of the conflict by recalling that it remains a priority for international diplomacy.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation of migrants in Libya.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, as you can see, for this debate I am pleased to be joined by Commissioner Avramopoulos as we were asked to cover both the external side of this situation and the internal work of the European Union. As Commissioner Avramopoulos is responsible for our internal work on migration, he will complement my introduction and will stay for the conclusions as well. We have all seen the images on CNN of the detention centres in Libya. Unfortunately, what the media has reported is not new. We have discussed this in this Chamber several times and this is not the first time that I am telling you about it personally.  I first heard the stories about the detention centres and the unthinkable violations of human rights a few years ago in Lampedusa; I was surprised that the rest of the world was not strongly reacting to stories that had been well known, not just for a couple of weeks, but for years. I heard them from people who had been tortured or had lost their loved ones. I heard them from the NGOs, from doctors and humanitarian workers who had been in those centres. If any of you have seen the film ‘Fuocoammare’, which I believe was also shown in the European Parliament in Brussels, I have heard those stories because they are told and are shown just in a film. So unfortunately there is nothing new.  But let me tell what we did after we first heard those stories, which does not mean two weeks ago, but a few years ago. Personally, I would say that it was still too late because Europe and the European Union should have acted even earlier, but it is now two or three years since we decided to act in a situation that was not easy.  Well before the media started to report on the situation in Libya, the European Union started to act. How? We engaged with the United Nations and in particular with international organisations for migrants to provide an alternative to migrants stranded in the country. I have said many times that our goal is to close the detention centres and I remember very well saying this in this Chamber a couple of months ago. We have worked to do precisely this, but it cannot be done overnight. We have now been working with the IOM and the UNHCR for a year, supporting their work inside Libya, which is the only way to address the situation. We need to give these people the opportunity to leave Libya safely, towards a better life, or I would rather say towards a life because in the detention centres you cannot call it life. Thanks to our work—the work of the European Union—just this year we have assisted over 15 000 migrants who were trapped in Libya and who now have been able, not only to go home with assisted voluntary returns supported by us and practically and operationally done by the IOM, but to start a new life.  I will give you one example. I was told the story of a group of ten young men from the Gambia who went home from Libya, thanks to our support, and with our funds bought a small refrigerated truck and are using it to deliver fish around the country. This is just one little story and is one example out of thousands of good stories about voluntary and sustainable returns. It is with stories like this that we also show local communities that embarking on a dangerous journey is not only a risk but is extremely dangerous and you might end up in a worse place than the one you left. These are the kind of stories that I think we need to share and we need to tell. We believe this is the right way to do things. It is humane, sustainable and with the right international standards in cooperation with the UNHCR and the IOM. Today new partners are finally joining our work.  The summit between the European Union and the African Union ten days ago in Abidjan was a turning point. It was a turning point not only on this, but was a key political summit for the EU—African Union partnership. This is not the issue we are discussing tonight—that is the tenth debate that we can have at about one o’clock tomorrow morning. On this issue our African partners have realised that it was time to seriously engage.  I believe our African partners had had enough of seeing their brothers and sisters dying in detention centres or along the route in the desert. They want to stop it and to stop the criminal networks that are making money out of death and slavery. We have set up a joint task force with the African Union, the European Union and the United Nations precisely to address the situation of migrants inside Libya and, already in the first ten days, the results are quite impressive. Right after we did that, in just nine days, we have assisted almost 2000 migrants in going back home from Libya voluntarily with the assistance of the IOM and there is a new awareness and a new common determination to act.  So thanks to this we now aim to transfer a further 15 000 people who are currently in detention centres. This would allow us to empty—to empty—the current population in the detention centres in the next few months. This is feasible. We have already assisted 15 000, 2000 of them in the last nine days, and we are aiming to transfer another 15 000 in the next couple of months with the practical work of the IOM and the cooperation of the African Union on the ground. But this is not enough. For some people going back home is not an option because of war or persecution. So for those who have the right to international protection we need to open new avenues to come to Europe or other safe places. The Commission has proposed welcoming 50 000 people in need of international protection and we have just launched a new programme with the UNHCR called the Emergency Transit Mechanism. The first transfers have already taken place so that those who have the right to receive asylum can come safely to Europe instead of risking their lives.  Is this enough? Clearly it is not and we are frustrated by every single person we do not manage to reach and every single place we do not manage to go.  You know the situation on the ground in Libya. It is not easy for the IOM and the UNHCR or for the NGOs simply to get around or to get access. Clearly it is not sufficient. It is not enough yet and we need to continue working together, including with the Libyan authorities. We need to overcome once and for all the system of systematic detention. We must allow the complete and proper registration of migrants and prosecute the criminal groups who are smugglers and enslavers.  I discussed this with President Sarraj this morning in order to prepare together the first meeting of this task force between the European Union, the African Union and the United Nations, which I called for at a political level for Thursday morning in Brussels. We will have this first operational meeting at a political level to accelerate our common work in Libya, but also beyond Libya because the situation further south along the route is also not at all rosy. We, first of all the European Union, are working to put an end to death and exploitation, to reduce risky journeys, to save lives at sea and in the desert and to provide international protection to those who need it. We are also working hand in hand with the United Nations to make progress in the political process in Libya.  Let me conclude with a word on this before I give the floor to Commissioner Avramopoulos to complete my remarks. The political process in Libya is, first and foremost, for the benefit of Libyans. We sometimes tend, with our European lenses, to forget that Libya is not just a place where migrants are passing through or detained. Libya is a country that has gone through very difficult times and is still in a very difficult situation. The Libyans themselves need to see our political support to overcome the current situation, but obviously improved governance will also help address the migration challenge inside Libya.  So the European Union is actively supporting the UN action plan at every stage. I met with President Sarraj ten days ago in Abidjan and, with Special Representative Salameh in Rome ten days ago. While there is not much progress to report yet, there is some movement in the right direction, but it is fragile and we need to stay resolute, particularly to support the Libyan Political Agreement through and beyond the deadline of 17 December. So it is clear that this job will not be done in a day. There will be bumps on the road and we will need long-term engagement, but we are on the right path. We are the only possible path to manage migration in a more humane and sustainable way and, finally, we are not alone. We will continue to work with all our determination, together with the African Union and the UN and in particular, the IOM and the UNHCR.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you very much for the invitation to discuss this very, very sensitive issue here tonight. I am more than happy to be here and wish to complement what my colleague, Ms Federica Mogherini, said some minutes ago.  The situation is as described, but I think on the ground it is even worse, and the images we saw on CNN recently do not reflect the reality. We are conscious of what is happening there, but let me start by making one thing crystal clear: it is not the European Union’s action that has created an inhumane system in Libya. Quite the opposite. For far too long these unacceptable, appalling, conditions have existed there and it is the European Union which, together with its international partners, is coordinating the efforts to address and improve the situation on the ground. Our collective efforts cannot ensure from one day to another a result which equals our expectations, but with our joint and international cooperation we hope to achieve results in the short to medium term.  We are working in a very difficult context, as you are all aware. An inclusive political transition, along with the stabilisation and economic consolidation of Libya, remains a key prerequisite for addressing migration—related challenges in Libya in a sustainable way. Within this complex framework, we are managing to work in Libya on all possible fronts. Cooperating with third countries, especially in North Africa, is a cornerstone of the comprehensive migration policy that we propose to step up in our contribution to the Leaders Meeting this Thursday evening on the way forward in migration.  Together with the International Organisation for Migration (IOM), the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and other humanitarian organisations, we are focusing first on improving the conditions of the migrants stranded in the country, secondly, on supporting their voluntarily return and reintegration back home and, thirdly, on creating legal pathways to Europe for people in need of international protection.  I am not going to repeat what Ms Mogherini has already said about registration, humanitarian assistance on the ground, and the voluntary reintegration of migrants to their own countries. I will focus on the legal pathways which should become the preferred way for people in need of protection to safely reach Europe.  In mid-November, the first group of 25 of the most vulnerable persons needing protection was evacuated from Libya to Niger for further resettlement in France, thanks to the support of the UNHCR, to EU funding and the consent of the governments of both Libya and Niger. With EU support, more evacuations from Libya to Niger will be carried out by UNHCR in the coming weeks. As announced in our roadmap presented last week, our target is to reach 1 000 by the end of February.  The continuous evacuation of people trapped in Libya depends on several factors. It is, of course, linked to the capacity of our Member States, together with other destination countries, to rapidly resettle from Niger the asylum—seekers evacuated. As you know, in September, the Commission called on the Member States to make available at least 50 000 resettlement places in the next two years for asylum-seekers located in some priority countries. This, of course, includes the countries of the central Mediterranean route. Member States replied in a very encouraging manner, offering until now almost 40 000 new resettlement pledges, and we are confident that additional pledges, from Member States which have not yet replied to our call, will be offered. Meanwhile, the moment to start fulfilling these pledges has already arrived, and I count on the support of the European Parliament in reminding them of the urgency of this. I also count on your support for the target we proposed to the Leaders – that 25 000 resettlements take place before October 2018.  In parallel, we continue to help the Sahel countries to better manage their borders and reinforce their capacities in relation to the fight against migrant smuggling and human trafficking. I understand that there are still concerns about the efficiency of our collective action on the ground, as Amnesty International today reported. Instead I would call for more, and stronger, joint cooperation between all actors and partners, since we all have the same objectives: stability in the region, unity in Libya, solidarity and practical support for the people in need. I look forward to the exchange of views with you tonight.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Madam High Representative, Commissioner, the images disseminated by different media, in which sub-Saharan immigrants are victims of a kind of slave auction at the gates of Europe are scandalous. The European Union and its Member States have strongly condemned the inhumane situation to which smugglers subject migrants as they pass through Libya. It is estimated that today there are between four hundred and seven hundred thousand people living in these degrading conditions. I also welcome the reaction of the Union, the African Union and the United Nations in the framework of the recent summit in Abidjan, to seek an immediate solution to this intolerable situation, as well as the commitment to help the Libyan authorities to do facing this very serious problem. It is necessary to develop a comprehensive migration policy with the situation of the countries of origin and transit which, together with the management of migration flows, includes an effective development cooperation policy with our African partners: with investment projects, institutional consolidation, security and protection of human rights. A policy that creates opportunities so that it is not necessary to emigrate to have a decent future and that ends the business of the mafias that traffic in human beings. In the case of Libya, no solution can be implemented without an inclusive political transition and the stabilization of the country. The Union must be fully involved and support the efforts of the United Nations representative to achieve a political solution for a united and peaceful Libya.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam president. Hell in life, that's Libya. And those who manage to escape tell it. Torture, sexual violence, kidnapping, slavery: the daily horror. Mrs Mogherini explained it perfectly, and not for the first time today. The video published by CNN has not actually discovered anything new, but, like that cruel photo of Aylán - remember? -, it has managed to stir consciences and accumulate reactions. Let us use this momentum to move in the right direction and also so that you can explain what the European Union is really doing. But it is very important that we put the protection of people above the protection of borders. That is the big difference between those of us who think this way and those who are just obsessed with security and border control without thinking about people. The question is how to act in Libya. If there is no State, there are no structures, there are no interlocutors, how to find a solution? There is huge concern about what we are doing in Libya and with whom we are doing things in Libya. And this can only be remedied with more transparency, and this debate is an opportunity for that. The situation in the country certainly does not allow us to face the humanitarian drama and, therefore, the idea of ​​returns is a good idea, a very good idea. But they return to their countries, with what possibilities? To what extent are we willing to share responsibility for this side of the Mediterranean? Or are we going to systematically try to move the problem away from our borders? How are we going to deal with economic migration, which, in human terms, is an euphemism? Economic migration, people are looking for life, a bearable life. So, once again, we insist that Europe needs to clearly define, for its own survival, a sustainable migration policy. For that we need to open more legal and safe channels for immigration.I say it louder, because we have said it many times.The only way, and the high representative knows it well, is to build a true association with the countries of origin and transit, reconciling interests, sharing projects and assuming responsibilities.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: On behalf of the ECR Group.- (FI) Mr President, the situation of illegal immigrants in Europe in Libya is tragic.However, the solution is not to create more legal routes to Europe for these people.This has recently been put forward by Commission President Juncker, among others.Migrants will come to Libya as long as Europe attracts them with poor border controls, generous asylum policies and inefficient return practices.These pull factors need to be addressed.People on the move from sub-Saharan Africa are driven by poverty.Above all, poverty is perpetuated by a huge birth rate.Africa’s population is projected to grow to as much as four billion this century.This root cause must also be addressed.Migration to Europe is not the answer.The integration of Third World migrants has so far failed miserably and the situation will only get worse as numbers increase.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I wish to thank Ms Mogherini – who has left in the meantime – and Mr Avramopoulos for his introduction. I insisted particularly on his presence here because we have to make it very clear that what we are talking about is not external policies, it is migration policies. It is politically relevant that we show that this is a migration debate and that we are not outsourcing the problem, although that is exactly what Member States want to do. We have all been shocked by the images of Amnesty International, but as Ms Mogherini rightly said, this is not the first time. Every time, like you said, we express our horror, we are shocked and then we basically move on. I know, Mr Avramopoulos, that you are personally very committed to a proper EU migration policy, but there is one thing that you said that I disagree with, which is that you basically said we are not to blame for this. It is true that the atrocities are committed in Libya by Libyan people and not by Europeans. However, it is also a consequence of our policy choices. We also know that a lot of funding from the EU, but also from Italy, is going into Libya and ending up in the pockets of God knows who: militia, terrorists, corrupt politicians. We have seen the images of a boat used by the Libyan Coast Guard that has been funded by Italy. It is our money going into that misery. Let us stop funding the misery. I also would like to hear a little bit more about the rescue operation. Where are these people going if they are not being repatriated?  Finally, Mr Avramopoulos, I would like to know something else, as remarks have been made and we are talking about human rights here. You have said a lot about legal pathways for labour migration, and I would like to know about these, because that is what we urgently need. Stop the fiction of Fortress Europe: we need legal avenues for labour migration.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to ask the Commissioner three questions. First: the 2012 European Court ruling on the Hirsi case. I reread the verdict that condemned Italy for collective push-backs to Libya, and the context is identical. The European Convention is violated and Libya remains unreliable, having not ratified the Geneva Convention. Where is the difference between 2009 and today? Second: the decision taken in Abidjan to evacuate the camps where violence takes place, to activate voluntary repatriation of migrants, to resettle some. I would like to know the procedures that will be adopted to prevent the returnee from having to choose between plague and cholera, and I would like to know the number of evacuations. Cochetel, a UNHCR envoy, said that most of the torture sites are unknown, that Sarraj controls minimal territory. He said again: Abidjan's decisions are illusory. Whenever we released someone from the detention camps, someone else immediately took his place. Last question: at what point is the redefinition of the concept of non-refoulement, which the Union proposed in February in Valletta? The resolution was cautiously deleted from the communiqué. I ask if it is still on the agenda.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - I remember that Commissioner Malmström then visited Libya in 2010 to relieve Eritrean refugees who were in dire conditions in Libyan prisons. Gaddafi threatened to return them to Eritrea. Agreements were made between Gaddafi and Berlusconi to stop migrants at sea and the Eritreans found themselves in the thick of it and were in danger of their lives. Tribute to Commissioner Malmström who then moved heaven and earth to save people. Now it's 2017 and there are again unclear deals between Italy and Libya. But there are also agreements in which the European Commission and other member states are involved. Libya's coastguard has never been better equipped than it is now, paid for by us, paid for by Europe. When they carry out a rescue, even more people drown. We know what things are like in Libyan detention camps. It's worse than 2010. And this time we're helping to fill those camps ourselves. Admittedly, we are also rescuing people from Libya. During the summit in Abidjan, I spoke to people who had just returned from Libya and they had the worst stories. One man had been rescued at sea by the Libyan coast guard, taken back to a detention camp, sold there, and worked on land as a slave. And when he had his mother on the phone to ransom him, he was being worked with machetes because he would scream loudly and the money would come earlier. Europe has paid for its so-called "sea rescue". Indeed, he did not drown. Europe has also paid for its return flight to Ivory Coast through the European Emergency Fund for Africa and will pay for its integration. Isn't that a bit cynical?

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the High Representative told us only part of the truth in her description of the journey of these economic migrants that Europe had pledged to save from the sad experience of the often dying travels across the Mediterranean . True, they are handed over to the states of origin, which among other things welcome them because they have temporary passports. So they are received and taken back from Ghana, Nigeria, and that's fine, this part of the narrative would be great. However, the High Representative does not tell us thanks to whom: thanks to the activity that was favored by the Italian agreements that allow the Libyan Coast Guard to take back all these irregular boats of traffickers who would like to hand over the poor migrants to other exploiters. But there is the other part of the coin that is not told to us, that is, those who cross the line - excuse me and I conclude - of Libyan competence arrive in Italy, on the ships of Italy, the EU or NGOs, and come dispersed in the Italian territory and arrive in Europe. So let's start again: you have partially solved only half of the problem. The other half of the landings continue, this is the truth you do not tell!

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: - Madam President! As a first important step, we welcome the promise of the Libyan Prime Minister to grant the UNHCR and the international organization for migration full access to the camps in his sphere of influence. But the promise from Tripoli will definitely not be enough, because the government there has hardly any access to the regions in which there are, for example, these slave markets. Other militias have this access. At the last EU-Africa summit at the end of November, planned emergency operations were discussed and these urgently need to be carried out. According to the plan, the IOM is supposed to officially help non-vulnerable migrants to return to their countries of origin. For this, the EU is also providing financial aid for - as it is said - a face-saving return. That alone cannot be enough, because we must also promote more development programs in the countries of origin and expand the framework for legal immigration to Europe. On the other hand, people in need of protection, i.e. people who have fled political persecution and civil war, are initially to be brought to Chad and Niger under the leadership of the UNHCR, and from there are to be resettled to willing states in Africa or the EU. I'll cut it short: In the medium term, the reasons for protection must be checked in Libya itself and resettlement must be made possible from there to Europe. It cannot be that a lack of solidarity within Europe prevents a common migration policy.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President! Vice-President Mogherini said that it was known for a long time what was happening in Libya, it was not necessary to watch CNN. So the question: What have we been doing all this time? I remember that more than two and a half years ago, the European Council said that we would start the fight against illegal human smuggling. And was it not tolerance to this practice, and was it not the activities of the Soros flotilla that were encouraging these people somewhere deep in Africa to embark on the way to this Libyan trap? Today, practical help steps are really needed, and it's good that we are talking about them. But if we do not really restore accountability - including political responsibility - in the activities of the European Union, such tragedies will change place, but will multiply. Therefore, I will repeat it once again: time for responsibility, time to think about the effects of the beautiful words that are sometimes spoken.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: - Madam President, last weekend, the Aquarius, a boat chartered by SOS Méditerranée, again rescued 450 people. The testimonies collected on board are damning: "on the beach, people were afraid, but the uniformed guards pointed their weapons to force us to get into the boats". Guards, in uniform, a few days ago ... For months, we have been told that we are training coast guards, 100 to 150 we were told in Tunis in September, and the same number has was repeated last week in Brussels. So in three months nothing new, despite CNN, dare I say. Yes, this is nothing new! Human trafficking and torture have been going on for years, including already under Gaddafi, and the European Union was already trying to negotiate a deal. There is no miracle solution. Enough beautiful speeches, enough beautiful stories, ridiculous figures compared to realities! The so-called official government only controls a tiny part of the territory. So there is no full investigation, there is no judicial system. The detention centers are out of control. How do you plan to evacuate these centers? And we are going to open a call center in Tripoli to better drive back to Libya these men, women and children who are ransomed, martyred, sold like merchandise, murdered. How many more deaths? By the funding provided, by your policies which worsen the situation, including in Niger, you are complicit in what is happening in this country. One day, you will be accountable for it and, in particular, for these thousands of human lives lost at sea as in the desert.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: - Madam President! To prevent irregular migration, the EU is working with countries like Libya, which lack basic guarantees of the rule of law and human rights. Today's Amnesty report clearly shows that the EU is complicit in violations of the human rights of refugees in Libya, and these are denounced. Not only Amnesty says that, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights also publicly stated and criticized this a few weeks ago. So if we look to cooperation with Libya, then the absolute priority must be that we focus on protecting refugees. The EU must use its influence here and immediately demand and support the release of all refugees and migrants, all those who are arbitrarily detained in Libya. And the EU member states must also accept refugees directly from Libya in their resettlement programs, and they must not only be in favor of them being transferred back to Niger, where we do not even know under what conditions they will then continue in their countries of origin are sent back. We have now repeatedly had reports about what and where the Libyan coast guard is involved. I think we have to fundamentally realign our cooperation with Libyan actors, including the coast guard. One should not develop methods and carry out collaborations that are not independently accompanied and monitored by international bodies and bodies trained in human rights.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: - I would suggest that we dare to draw conclusions from this absolute Libyan disaster, two.One, we must recognize our own responsibility and two, we must put our own interests first in foreign policy.Sorry, colleague in 't Veld, but it is certainly not the case to separate migration and foreign policy.The European Union and European coalition itself has caused the Libyan mess as a result of misunderstanding alliances and by using wrong principles.Putting self-interest at the center of foreign policy should be introduced as an important principle.When engaging in foreign policy, we must, especially in Mediterranean affairs, take into account the immigration effect of the measures and actions we take.If we could learn that lesson, then we would have benefited at least one more from the whole Libyan crisis.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner you say that the problems did not arise today, but were already present in Libya from the point of view of human rights violations, and this is true. But we must ask ourselves whether current containment policies solve or substantially aggravate the problems that exist. What we see, in fact, is that these containment policies produce two effects: they keep people in Libya in unbearable conditions and have led to a real conversion of smugglers from managers of migrant routes to managers of oil sold on the market. black, which entails enormous economic losses for the Libyan public coffers, with the consequences of the case, precisely in the management of the migration problem. I wonder, and I ask you, if the time and time has not come to reflect on the real consequences of these containment policies and to approach a different migration policy towards Libya by the European Union.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: - Madam President, I believe that we are not focusing this debate well: today it is not necessary to debate here on how they enslave, torture and rape migrants in Libya, because this is already more than documented. The debate is why all this is being done, promoted and paid for by the European Union. It is the European Union that finances a Libyan coast guard made up of militias that has sunk ships full of migrants in the sea, uses violence systematically and persecutes NGOs. It is the European Union that finances these detention centers where there is physical and sexual violence, where migrants are malnourished and tortured. And, instead of opening legal and safe ways for these people to reach Europe - which they say a lot but do not do - instead, what they do is deport them so that they return to war and poverty. who fled. The question is: Who will accompany Libyan torturers when they sit on the bench of the International Criminal Court for crimes against humanity? Will Mr. Tusk, Mr. Juncker, or will Mrs. Mogherini accompany you?

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - Ms. President! Here, those who have spoken before me have all told me about the dramatic conditions in which refugees live in Libya. They also said that this life is simply unbearable, they also said that we are not doing anything, that the situation is not improving, but that it is getting worse, and I think that is not very surprising, as Libya is a country that does not really have a government with real political power. That is why refugees are fully exposed to the conditions. Local authorities are colluding with human traffickers, trampling on the rights and human rights of refugees. The question is, what can the European Parliament, the European Union, do in this case? And I think we need to come up with very clear and very clear demands. We do not have time for further time, talks, conciliations, we must demand that the Libyan authorities, the Libyan government, put an end to the arbitrary imprisonment of refugees, guarantee the human rights of these people, put an end to violence and domination, do everything for these people to live in humane conditions. If we do not follow this path, nothing will happen except that Europe will lose its own conscience, betray its own values, insult its own values, and nothing else will happen but the far-right forces will be strengthened.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: - Madam president. Yes, Mr Avramopoulos, the European Union does something, but I get the impression that we are doing something wrong. Or something, or how something, or since when, or for what or with whom. Because while we support the United Nations and its envoy, Mr. Salamé, in his roadmap to try to stabilize a country that has exploded into a thousand pieces - which we treat in this room as if it were a country with a Government and a country that he may be required to do this or that, when we don't even really have an interlocutor who governs the rest of the country - we find that the other United Nations envoy for human rights, or Amnesty International, or Doctors Without Borders , or other organizations that are there on the ground criticize us fiercely, because our policy remains, unfortunately, reactive. I don't blame you alone. Member States also bear a lot of guilt and a lot of responsibility. And, in fact, we are just implementing either an Italian agenda or a German or a French agenda or who knows. 2017 was the year this Parliament wanted to have been with the Libyans. I wanted to have come to signify that the European Union, more than just financial programs, had the capacity to give a message for the future, a political message in the face of normalization, the stabilization of the country. I am afraid that we are not going to achieve it, because precisely in these days we are witnessing a situation of misrule - because of the images and the real situations of immigrants - in a country that, I repeat, we treat from the European Union as if it were a country with a government. And the problem in Libya is that it is a country exploded into a thousand pieces and that must be treated differently, not as if it were just another country where terrible things are happening, but where also the Libyan citizens are going through terrible things. From the European Union I think we should be a little more ambitious to the time to make a comprehensive program for Libya and not only to reactivate if there are immigrants, if now there are slaves, if now ... No. Libya is a complete country with all its citizens, with all its participations and it needs a comprehensive policyand a comprehensive budget and not by parts, that all we do is blow it up into more pieces.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Libya is a country that has not known peace for too many years, it is a country in total chaos and with an unknown future, hostage to violence and a trap for thousands of people in search of international protection. A country that sums up an unprecedented humanitarian, security and political crisis and that needs immediate action by the European Union and the entire international community. We must act with urgent measures to respond to the atrocities suffered by migrants, but also Libyan citizens themselves, and put in place long-term policies to guarantee security and stability. The challenge today is to ensure that the Union speaks with one voice in Libya, fully assuming its leading role in the peace process. Solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities: no Member State should be forced to act alone. Peace, reconciliation and reconstruction, the inescapable conditions for identifying credible interlocutors in the country and allowing the disposal of smuggling and trafficking networks of human beings. Urgent measures to put an end to the atrocities we have all been witnessed and which very good NGOs have denounced. But also long-term goals, peace and reconciliation at the center of our strategies to work towards an inclusive political dialogue and full respect for human rights, for the reconstruction of the country and the stabilization of the entire Mediterranean area and the region of the Sahel. I close by saying that we must put in place an instrument for safe, orderly and regular migration.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: - Fil-fatt, f’din l-Awla llejla smajna kif fil-Libja hemm eluf ta ‘persuni li ta’ kuljum qed ikun torturati u abbużati. M'hemmx għalfejn noqgħod nirrepeti. Imma forsi min joqgħod fin-naħa ta 'fuq tal-Ewropa, jew min ġej minn pajjiż kbir, ftit li xejn jirrealizza. Jiena li ġejja minn Malta, pajjiż ġar tal-Libja, nifhem li din hija sitwazzjoni kritika għall-aħħar, problema li għandha u li se jkompli jkollha effett enorm fuq ir-reġjun kollu tal-Mediterran u l-Unjoni Ewropea kollha kemm hi. L-Afrika huwa kontinent enormi, fejn mijiet ta ‘eluf ta’ persuni qegħdin jiċċaqalqu ta ’kuljum minn post għall-ieħor. In this context, the Libyan people were confronted with problems. I did not know how much food was used. If this is the case, if there is a European Union policy, it will be a matter of government policy, it will be a climate change, it will be an investment in the private sector, all of which will be implemented. -problema. U le, ma nistgħux nibqgħu nagħlqu għajnejna għall-immigrazzjoni illegali, għat-traffikar tal-persuni u għan-netwerks ta ’criminalità. Fl-istess ħin, għandna d-dover li ngħinu liż-żgħażagħ f’dan ir-reġjun. Huma l-catalyst tal-bidla. In the present case, the first series of bovine animals may be used as a whole.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Madam President, according to an Amnesty International report: Libya is full of cruelty. However, this cruelty is specifically targeted at religious minorities, especially Christian migrants and refugees who have been subjected to kidnappings, torture, theft and physical attacks by Daesh, criminal gangs and human smugglers, but also government officials. The whole world witnessed this intolerance when religiously motivated mass murders caused by hatred of Christians were committed on the way to the Italian coast. Even in the moments of mortal danger that everyone shared equally on these dinghies in the middle of the Mediterranean, hatred and intolerance prevailed and resulted in the death of dozens of innocent people who prayed for the help and salvation of all present "wrong God". Killing Christians on the road to Christian Europe is more than symbolic. Knowing that billions of euros are constantly flowing into Libya, the question arises with what goal? Which groups? With what consequences? Europe should be more careful and pay more attention to which groups it supports financially.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Madam President, just a few days ago I had the opportunity to hear in Abidjan, on the occasion of the European Union-Africa Summit, the moving testimony of the survivors of the route to Libya from all parts of Africa. Slavery, torture and mistreatment of human beings are nothing new in that region of the globe, but the magnitude, scale and, above all, the exposure to the public through the media, clearly tells the European Union which is not the time for analysis, but for action. The European Union has to launch an international investigation into what constitutes a crime against humanity. The European Union has to promote with the United Nations an international action that converts current detention centers, where massive human rights violations take place, into reception centers where human rights are respected. It has to ensure that funding meets its objectives and it has to open legal avenues with humanitarian corridors and humanitarian visas that give an opportunity to those who risk their lives and lose everything in the effort. The upcoming visit of a delegation from the European Parliament to Libya may be a good occasion to change course, look and take action.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, the disintegration of Libya is the result of foreign intervention in this country, a situation that is exacerbated by the support of Turkey and Qatar to the Libyan jihadists. The chaos in Libya has led to a mass exodus of huge waves of refugees to the European Union. The European Union must set up a system to repatriate illegal immigrants, but at the same time ensure humane conditions for all migrants in Libya, where they are literally treated as slaves. At the same time, the relocations from Italy and Greece, Mr. Avramopoulos, to the other countries of the European Union must continue. We are particularly concerned about the policy of Mr Tusk, who has more or less stated that he wants to abolish the system of compulsory refugee allocation quotas in the other Member States of the European Union. It is something that the Greek people will not tolerate.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Madam President, today's report from Amnesty International unfortunately demonstrates what we have known for some time.Libya is reeling from chaos, the consequences of the war, the incredibly poor post-war reconstruction and the complicated social stratification of the country make the stabilization of the country seem in sight.Thus, torture and even something as incredibly barbaric as human trafficking is taking place in Libya.Members of the Libyan Coast Guard cooperate with smugglers, and the state in chaos parasitizes on human disaster.I believe that the NATO countries that have contributed to the incredible devastation of this country should now take responsibility and help get this country back on its feet.A political and diplomatic consensus needs to be found as soon as possible on how to ensure as soon as possible that the Libyan institutions are able to enforce law and order in the country.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, stop the fiction that there is a Libyan coastguard for the EU to train in Libya. What EU Member States, such as Italy, have been paying is militia who fight each other to exploit the trafficking of human beings, arms and drugs. They operate horrendous detention camps and some migrants and refugees are slaves, or ‘abeed’ as they were called in Gaddafi days. Infighting between militia competing to take care of migrants for the EU recently destroyed the city of Sabratha. By not opening safe and controlled ways for migrants and asylum seekers, the sad story is that Europe feeds the human traffickers business, and it is big business! Al-Qaeda and Daesh are taking the profits and bring the security threat closer to us in Europe. It is time to try to stop the fiction that there is migration management in Libya and governance, be it from President Fayez al-Sarraj or the criminal General Haftar. It is time for the EU Member States to wake up and demand action at the UN, together with the African Union, to dispatch a robust international force well inside Libya to expel terrorist groups and to bring about a society for Libyans with Libyans. Without that there will be no governance in Libya. It will have to be with European boots on the ground, many boots on the ground. But after all, it is also about our own security that is at stake in Libya. The more we delay it, the more it will cost in African lives and possibly in European lives.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Madam President, Libya is in a state of turmoil. In five day’s time, on 17 December, the two-year mandate of the UN—appointed government will end. Without an official government, we can expect further destabilisation and a rise in illegal immigration, as well as terrorism-related and criminal activity. Instability in Libya will also affect Europe. It is imperative that the EU put more effort into understanding the actual situation on the ground and more resources into the pursuit of peace and stability. One positive development, as was mentioned, is the group of different actors in Libya that has come together to form an EU—Libya friendship association that will be established in Malta in the coming months. It is important for the EU to back this effort, and I make a plea for this.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, indeed I was listening to our colleagues very carefully and I would like to express my thanks for their contribution to this debate. What I would like to say at the beginning is that finally we are all on the same side. We share the same concerns and we are trying to find solutions. Some of these solutions are not common, but I think we have reached a level where we all understand that more action has to be undertaken, more responsibility shown, and more initiatives undertaken, in order first of all to bring back stability in Libya.  Ms Valenciano, we are still in the early stages but yes, I agree with you that we have to work, we need to work in a balanced way with our partners and also to face reality. Europe is in need of economic migrants, but for this purpose we need to enhance and open legal pathways, legal channels, while in parallel reducing irregular migration. As long as irregular migration is there, pictures like the ones we saw some days ago will be replicated.  As you know, Member States keep the right to determine the volume of admission of third country nationals coming to work in their countries. It is their national competence and responsibility. As far as the Commission is concerned, we stand ready to coordinate and propose pilot projects with selected third countries and of course provide related financial support. This would be in cases where Member States commit themselves to hosting certain numbers of migrants coming through legal channels, in particular for economic purposes. We are not discussing with the Member States, and as you very rightly said, Ms in 't Veld, my goal, the Commission’s goal, is the implementation of a comprehensive migration policy. The same goes for the particular case of Libya. As Ms Ayala Sender said, we need a global solution addressing all problems and challenges. Dear colleagues, it is clear that we are all equally aware and shocked at the terrible, appalling and inhumane conditions in Libya. Yes, this has to stop and has to stop now. The situation in those detention centres is unacceptable. The European Union is pursuing efforts to support the establishment of a standardised process by the Libyan authorities through concrete projects.  Another question you would ask me: who are these Libyan authorities?
