The legitimate government of Tripoli is there, recognised by the United Nations, by the European Union, but does this government have the power? Does this government have full control of the situation in Libya? The answer is clear: no.  When migrants are rescued by the Libyan Coast Guard they are disembarked and taken to reception centres that meet international humanitarian standards, and once again we have to praise and commend IOM and UNHCR for the work they are doing on the ground, even putting the lives of their people there in danger. The European Union is actually supporting the development in Libya of alternatives to detention.  Recently the Libyan Government agreed to allow UNHCR to open a transit and departures facility to Tripoli for people in need of international protection. IOM is also working with partner non-governmental organisations on pilot projects to promote safe spaces which would have the capacity to host a small group of vulnerable women and children. As regards the use of funds, we are monitoring, as in every case, how they are used. We are not aware so far of misuses but are ready to listen to concrete evidence.  Dear colleagues, fanciful statements about complicity and blame might grab headlines but they are not helping anyone, least of all the migrants themselves. The situation in Libya is not bad because of the European Union. This discourse has to stop. On the contrary, the situation is slightly better compared to the recent past thanks to the European Union, and we shall continue working on the ground in order to support these people. You described the situation in Libya before. I will pick out some of your words because ultimately Libya is lacking all elements to be qualified as a state. The situation is chaotic. There is no strong interlocutor on the other side. The country is divided. There are approximately 20 independent militias operating uncontrolled on the ground. The country is a paradise for smugglers and an open corridor for irregular migration. We here all share the same objectives.  First and most important is to save lives and provide these desperate people with support. The European Union, its institutions and the Member States are working to achieve it, pure and simple. We do so by first stopping people drowning in the Mediterranean – and you see that the numbers have gone down drastically – evacuating them from disastrous conditions in Libya and offering them safe and legal pathways to come to Europe. I will not repeat what I said at the beginning, but it is clear that we have a lot more work to be getting on with to make it better still.  I count also on the Members of this House to help us advance, because what we have achieved in general in migration, from the very beginning of our term as the European Parliament and as this Commission, has been achieved thanks to our cooperation, and once again I would like to express my gratitude to all of you for your support. Today the European Union can be proud of its policy and of the adoption of the principles upon which this policy and this strategy is based.  The MEPs who were here in the previous Parliament know very well that there was no migration policy, there was no migration strategy, just an embryo somewhere in Brussels, but not something clear and concrete. So we can all share this effort to achieve what we have done. But yes, we have to do more, but we will do it together. This is not a national, regional or a European problem. As we said before it is a global one, and I was more than happy one year ago when I proposed to the former Secretary-General of the United Nations to hold this extraordinary General Assembly and he did it in New York. So in this way, we made this issue a global one. It has become a global responsibility and we are all responsible globally for what is happening in the Mediterranean and in Libya. The European Union has taken its part. All others should do the same.  So before I sign off, I would like to call for more and strong joint cooperation by all of us, all actors and partners, since we all aim, as I said, for the same objectives: to bring back stability to the region; to bring back stability to Libya; to be the ones that will contribute to bringing unity in Libya, because the country is divided and fragmented; to work on the principle of solidarity towards these desperate people, but also among ourselves; and finally, to produce practical results by giving practical support to the people in need.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. - In Libya it is difficult to understand whether the European Union is waging war on smugglers or migrants. The Al-Sarraj government receives our money but does not control its territory, which is contracted directly or indirectly to militias fighting with other militias, groups that also manage the smuggling of migrants and on which the increase or decrease in landings depends Italy. Mass, arbitrary, rights-free and indefinite detention is the main means of controlling migration flows in that country. As there is no single recognized authority in Libya, when we say we are training the Libyan Coast Guard and providing support for the management of migratory flows we do not really know who we are paying or supporting, nor which Libyan territory, which sea area is controlled and from who. A situation that Amnesty International describes as "a dark web of collusion" through which European governments, to prevent departures from Libya, end up actively supporting a system of violence, exploitation and violation of human rights.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – Undoubtedly, the reports on the Libyan slave trade shocked the world. Last year, I raised the question with the High Representative / Vice President about the situation in migrant detention centres in Libya and the issue that Libya has not ratified the 1951 Refugee Convention and has no domestic refugee law or asylum procedure. Unfortunately, working long term solutions have not been found and we are seeing the results. Not only as a member of the European Parliament but as a human before all, I strongly believe that to watch a human being been sold as a commodity in the 21st century just few hundred kilometres from European shores is a despicable and shameful act. Therefore we need, together with the African Union, to demand from the Libyan authorities a full investigation of the slave trade in that country, but we also have to work on an emergency plan to dismantle human trafficking networks. Appropriate international protection of migrants in Libya is the first step to ending modern day slavery and slavery markets in Libya.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: in writing. - According to the United Nations, 390,000 migrants are stranded in Libya today, 9,000 of whom are said to be deprived of their liberty. The current EU cooperation programs with Libya have an impact on the latter, who are in need of international protection and whose living conditions in detention centers do not respect fundamental rights. Following the EU-Africa summit on November 30, a joint declaration on the situation of migrants in Libya was adopted. It obviously condemns the inhumane treatment of migrants and refugees by criminal groups, but does not provide any response to the crisis. However, journalists recently witnessed an auction of enslaved migrants. The images illustrate the dramatic situation experienced by thousands of people. It is true that the Libyan authorities have decided to create a transit and departure center in Tripoli for people in need of international protection. Nonetheless, it would be good if the ongoing investigation verified the press allegations and concluded quickly. The Union, for its part, must review the modalities of its policy vis-à-vis Libya and put in place legal and secure channels for these migrants.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- The difficult political and security situation in Libya has also created a growing problem for refugees.Every year, tens of thousands of refugees come to Libya to enter Europe.At the same time, tighter controls on the coast and at sea make it increasingly difficult to leave Libya, which is trapping refugees in Libya.Traffickers have started selling people as slaves there, holding auctions in the marketplaces during the day.People sold into slavery are used for hard work, starved and blackmailed from their families.If it is not received, the person is simply killed and a new one is bought on the market.The problem of slave markets has also been acknowledged by High Representative Mogherini.It is time for the EU to address this issue in substance and to help find solutions to help the refugees trapped in Libya.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: in writing. - We had already firmly denounced here the declaration between the European Union and Turkey because it should not become a model to be followed, but now another agreement, once again without the control of the European Parliament, has seen the light of day in Libya. With these arrangements, Member States only worsen the situation of migrants there and become complicit in these atrocities. Amnesty International has revealed that stranded migrants are exposed to arbitrary detention, torture, killings, rape, extortion and exploitation. The Union cannot shirk its international obligations on asylum. Migrants cannot be blamed for wanting to flee war and in this sense they have the right to international protection. I regret that the sole aim of the Libyan coastguard, financed by European funds, is to push migrants ever further from our doors. This is a big mistake; All the more so as other avenues exist for a human and voluntary migration policy! If there was real political will, we could build safe and legal routes to Europe through resettlement, family reunification or obtaining humanitarian visas.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the 2016 annual report by Ms Godelieve Quisthoudt-Rowohl, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on human rights and democracy in the world and the European Union's policy on the matter (2017/2122 (INI)) (A8-0365 / 2017)

name: Godelieve QUISTHOUDT-ROWOHL
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President! I would like to start by thanking the shadow rapporteurs for their commitment and the good spirit of compromise. I have to say that it was a pleasure, but also a lot of work, to work with you on the 2016 annual report on human rights and democracy in the world. Despite disagreements in a number of areas, this report is the product of shared beliefs among the various political groups. We share the fact that we care about human rights and that we are increasingly concerned about human rights violations in many regions of the world. As it is in the nature of such a report, we have endeavored to reflect this basic concern accordingly and to pay special attention to the groups in need of protection - unfortunately they are always the same: women, children, people with disabilities, migrants and refugees. However, there is also a second part. The report also expresses great concern that democracy, human rights and the rule of law are increasingly being pushed back and threatened around the world. I tried to make this clear and precise and to avoid repetition. First point: especially for religious minorities, life in more and more regions has become extremely difficult. States are increasingly suppressing these minorities through blasphemy laws. Non-state actors, such as the Islamic State, suppress them through violence and terror. I am pleased that the report consequently calls on the Commission to work in particular for respect for religious freedom and to support it worldwide. Second: The human rights challenges in connection with the refugee and migration crisis of last year are by no means over - something we have long heard in relation to Libya. you still require significantly greater efforts to combat the causes. The report is clear and calls for sustainable solutions to be found, including through a strengthened neighborhood policy. Third, civil society is also suffering from a growing number of repressive laws. Here, the freedom of expression both online and offline is increasingly narrowed and curtailed. And it is also endangered, and thus actually one of the basic requirements of our democratic society, which sometimes goes swimming, is endangered. The so-called Human Rights Dialogue remains a particularly important foreign policy instrument of the EU, since human rights can seldom be better defended than through direct talks and negotiations. As the EPP coordinator for trade policy too, I am pleased that the report continues to reaffirm the practice of human rights clauses in international agreements and to highlight the generalized system of preferential tariffs as a model and effective tool for promoting the effective implementation of key international human rights conventions. And I can say from experience: It was a very, very long work over the years before we could implement it. Two final remarks. First, we believe we need to find a different timeline. To talk about a situation from 2016 at the end of 2017 - that is actually too far removed from the events. As MEPs, we repeat it year after year: it really has to change. Second: Human rights have taken on a different quality in the digital age. When it comes to human rights, we are no longer just dependent on dictatorships, we are also dependent on technical possibilities. I believe that this second point is not yet sufficiently anchored in consciousness. We should work on that. Thank you again for the good cooperation.

name: Godelieve QUISTHOUDT-ROWOHL
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, honourable Members of Parliament, I would like to speak on behalf of Vice-President Mogherini. We are living in extremely difficult times for human rights all around the world. We are facing a global problem. One could even call it a political or cultural problem. When we Europeans raise human rights issues with our interlocutors, sometimes they tell us: ‘You Europeans are the only ones who still care about human rights. Why do you keep doing this?’ Some countries are questioning the Council of Europe and the very idea of a continental system to watch over human rights. Some have withdrawn from the International Criminal Court, although many others have redeclared their commitment to it. Human rights may be a difficult undertaking, but by no means a desperate one. For every bad story there are also many good stories, often less reported. Let me assure you, we may sometimes feel alone as a force for human rights, but we do not intend to change course.  If you look at the European Union Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy, and the European Parliament’s report, it is clear that we all agree on the analysis of the situation. The timing of the European Union Report was not ideal this year, as Antonio Panzeri pointed out in his recent letter. This year, as you know, the European Union Report was postponed because of the mid-term review of the Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy. To improve our report and its impact, we will deliver a streamlined and much shorter report next year. We will focus on thematic issues and use country-specific examples rather than going through each country one by one. Our next report will be tabled in the spring of 2018.  Today, we would like to focus on three issues in particular. The first is civil society and the role of human rights defenders. In your report, you highlighted that the space for civil society is shrinking in many parts of the world and you called for the EU to use all means to protect human rights defenders and NGOs. Even on the occasion of our forum with NGOs last week, there were friends and colleagues who were not allowed to travel and to join us in Brussels. What we keep hearing is that old narrative of a clash between interests and values, but whenever one person’s rights are abused we are less safe and secure. Our society, when human rights are not guaranteed, is more fragile, less resilient and an easier target for radicalisation. Investing in human rights, in civil society and in open societies is the best possible investment for the security of our countries. It is what we call sustainable security, security with deep roots in societies and communities.  Looking at the mid-term review of the Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy, which was published in June 2017, it is evident that we have taken a number of measures to address this issue. All our European delegations today have at least one human rights defenders liaison officer. They have worked together to support human rights defenders who were put on trial. In many cases we have helped them leave a country when their life was at risk. The protection of human rights defenders in civil society is also frequently the topic of our human rights dialogue with third countries. We would like to thank, once again, our Special Representative for Human Rights, Stavros Lambrinidis, who has helped us keep a constant focus on human rights issues all around the world.  The second issue is violence against women and girls. No continent is spared. Every culture, including our European culture, still harbours some forms of discrimination and violence. One in three women in Europe has experienced either physical, sexual, or emotional violence. The European Union is already, and by far, the first investor in gender equality and change around the world.  Let me just mention two recent initiatives. First, we are extremely proud of our decision to sign the Council of Europe’s Istanbul Convention. Second, the Spotlight initiative launched by the European Union last September with the United Nations is a truly unprecedented action, for the size of our investment, which stands at half a billion euros, and for its innovative way of working. Spotlight will be run together by several European Union agencies and European Union services, and with our delegations around the world. We will engage beyond governments, with civil society organisations and local communities. This is not a traditional, top-down development assistance, because a change in attitudes cannot be imposed from above. It can only grow from the heart of each society and each community.  Our third point is about democracy support and election observation. We would like to thank all of you who have spent energy and time as heads or observers of our election observation missions. As rightly pointed out in your report, a special focus is now given to the follow-up of our missions’ recommendations. These recommendations are now always raised in our political dialogues with partner countries. We are also working with local associations and institutions. Our engagement with local authorities goes well beyond the moment when ballots are counted. Too often, part of our societies feel that the ‘system’ is not working for them. Many people have the impression that they are not listened to and they are losing trust in their institutions. This feeling of exclusion is one of the great enemies of our democracies. If we want to save our democracies we must also improve our democracies. When we work for better institutions, or to open up the space for civil society or for free and independent media, we are also contributing to resilience and to sustainable security. This is the European way to security. It is about our values and it is about our interest. In these difficult times, we have become an even more indispensable partner for all those who believe in human rights and work for them. The Commission is sure that with your support we will continue to be the credible force for human rights that the world so urgently needs.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. – Madam President, as rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM), I want to recall that more than 50% of the world’s population is composed of women and that women’s rights are basic human rights. It is therefore essential that this dimension is well covered in this report. In particular, I am worried to see that sexual and reproductive health and rights were quite overlooked. It is unacceptable that women and girls’ bodies remain an ideological battleground. The integrity of women and girls’ bodies is an inalienable human right that should be protected. A few months ago, we witnessed how the Trump administration reinstated and expanded the global gag rule. This is a breach of human rights that will jeopardise efforts to fight diseases such as Aids, Zika or Malaria and to reduce high-risk births and child mortality. In that sense, it is fundamental that the EU and its Member States fill the financing gap left by the US in this field.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! I would like to thank the author of today's report on human rights observance in 2016. Admittedly, as the rapporteur said, it was submitted late, more than a year after these events. It is difficult to keep a good distance to these events. I would like to thank both the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for trying to find these key points in this annual report. In particular, I note that priority was given to freedom of religion and belief and to persecution against this background. Religion is not a direct cause of conflict, but is often used as a tool in conflict. I think we must oppose this, and religious freedom is a fundamental value of freedom, it is a human right that should be fully respected. I would also like to say that we should always remember that the death penalty is still being carried out, and that human trafficking is also a disgrace, and in particular, what we heard on the occasion of the report on the situation in Libya, in other parts of the world. The situation of the population in post-conflict areas such as Iraq or Syria, the difficulty of adapting, returning to their homeland. Moreover, a situation that affects minorities, such as the situation of the Muslim Rohingya population in Myanmar, which is also discussed here in this Parliament, and the phenomenon that concerns the relationship between big business, entrepreneurship and people in certain areas. The phenomenon of land grabbing - we are dealing with the embarrassing thing that here the indigenous people are deprived of the right to land. I think that the phenomena outlined here in the report, but also those that we remember here from the debate in this House, should be recalled each year, especially as tomorrow we are to present the Sakharov Prize for freedom of thought, including the Venezuelan opposition.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the rapporteur for the work she has done, and I must say that there is a contagious disease which is spreading more and more in the world, and it is that of contempt for human rights. The truth is that the cynicism produced by a political, economic and commercial hyperrealism now seeks to overcome and annihilate the wind of solidarity and rights. On the other hand, I believe that in the face of the large economic subjects that increasingly govern the world, the appeal to individual and collective rights is the way forward to prevent everything from being subjected to the natural law of the market. We need to accompany the revolution of equality, the revolution of dignity, which can increasingly place the self-determination of the person at the center. The challenges we face are manifold. We must know and see, and above all face. Human rights defenders face discrimination and intimidation and are often killed. The European Union must maintain a single position on the values ​​of human rights, but often different positions are met. Europe can have a credible voice if the message it sends is not only shared as a whole, but also if it is able to show a strong coherence in its internal and external policies. The annual report we will be voting on is clear on this point, and calls on all EU institutions and Member States to place human rights at the heart of the EU's relations with third countries, and we must always do so with regard to anyone.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! I appreciated the speech of the Commissioner, who demanded or called for a more sparse and concise report. In fact, we should defend what is fundamental. Europe should always come to the rescue when entire social groups are destroyed in religious wars and ethnic wars, it must stand up for religious freedom, which is violated in many parts of the world. Christians are the main victims of this persecution. We must be everywhere where human rights are violated in the great displacement processes associated with refugees. Finally, we should come to the aid of all those repressed, imprisoned for their political beliefs. At the same time, we should avoid bias, and by no means I can agree with Mr Solé, who attacks the Trump administration, promotes reproductive rights which, in fact, violate the right of a person to life. Let us fight for the fundamental, let us avoid the partial.

name: Renate WEBER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the report we are discussing today is a valuable paper as it tackles a wide range of horizontal topics of the utmost importance for the EU and its policy instrument for advancing human rights and democracy worldwide. I thank the rapporteur for her openness during the negotiations and I am happy to see that issues which were proposed by my group were extensively supported by the other groups and are now in the final report. However, I consider that in general the reports we are adopting should go beyond theoretical statements. We should not censor ourselves when speaking about violations of human rights and democracy in the world without referring to particular cases, countries and regimes. We should not be shy in naming and shaming abusive state and non-state actors. Such an approach would give more value to our work and to the work of civil society, whose representatives expose themselves to danger and abuse, yet continue to act as watchdogs and brought these events to our attention.  The aim of the report is also to be a supportive instrument for the work of the European External Action Service, as well as to the EU delegations in the third countries. I believe that speaking openly and stating the facts about undemocratic regimes will strengthen the significance of our work and its impact on the design of EU external policies. I hope that in the future we will surpass this limitation and will address without restraint events that damage human rights and democracy in the world.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam president. As this report says, we are at a time of setback for human rights around the world. I think that the Honduran people deserve a special mention these weeks, who have suffered more than twelve murders in the demonstrations against electoral fraud. The report raises interesting ideas, but the problem is that these ideas do not correspond to the practice of most member countries. Thus, while defending the role of the European Union as a promoter of human rights, it is forgotten that they are also violated within it, as occurs on the southern border of Ceuta and Melilla or in the immigration detention centers. On European territory, for example, the criminalization of the human rights defender, Helena Maleno, has been prepared. The violation of human rights by European multinationals, trade agreements, the military industry, the looting of natural resources and many other practices make us think that if this continues, the positive aspects of this report in practice will stay on wet paper. It must be rectified.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, this is quite a comprehensive and good annual human rights report, and I thank the rapporteur for her work. This annual report includes strong language on the shrinking space for civil society, including the call for an EU monitoring mechanism for cases of violations of freedom of assembly and association.  Given that I have only one-and-a-half minutes of speaking time, I would like to focus on the situation of environmental rights defenders, which the annual report explicitly mentions. Their important work often goes against the interests of influential companies, and they face severe human relations by state actors as well. According to the NGO ‘Global Witness’, on average three environmental human rights defenders were murdered each week in 2015. In 2016, there were around four murders per week and this murderous trend went on this year. Almost 40% of the environmental human rights defenders killed are indigenous people. We are glad that Lolita Chavez, a committed environmental and indigenous human rights defender from Guatemala, is one of the finalists for the Sakharov Prize this year. Environmental human rights defenders like her are under threat when they oppose the interests of corporations and governments. The sectors most affected are mining, extractive industries, agri—business, hydroelectric dams and water rights and logging. The EU and its Member States are clearly not doing enough to ensure corporate accountability and legal redress. It is time to hold accountable those European corporations who contribute to the excessive violence against those activists. I know that it is late, but still I have to say that I really regret that High Representative Mogherini is not here to contribute to this human rights debate.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate my colleague, Mrs Godelieve Quisthoudt-Rowohl, for the excellent report she prepared and negotiated on the state of human rights and democracy in the world in 2016. I was very pleased to see that the amendments I proposed were fully incorporated into the report. These amendments referred to the importance of placing the strengthening of human rights and democracy at the heart of our enlargement and neighborhood policies. I also proposed developing guidelines for supporting democracy, because it is an illusion to think that democracy and human rights could work without the other. On the contrary, they are two sides of the same coin. But nowadays, in many parts of the world, there are still policies that seek to convince us that communism and left-wing populism can work for the benefit of citizens. It's wrong! In China, the fate of Nobel Peace Prize winner Liu Xiaobo is a typical case of the authorities' brutal crackdown on dissidents. Also in China, Lee Ming-che, a staunch defender of human rights, has just been sentenced to five years in prison. In Venezuela, the cases of Alfredo Acosta and Leopoldo López, winner of the 2017 Sakharov Prize, testify to the bankruptcy of the Chavist system. That is why, in accordance with the commitment we have made in our treaties, we must promote human rights and democracy on the international stage.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, last year, I condemned the global clampdown on civil society and human rights defenders, but sadly the situation is only getting worse. In the Gulf, where many EU Member States – including the United Kingdom – have strategic and economic interests, the situation of human rights defenders remains catastrophic. In Bahrain, at least 169 peaceful critics have been targeted in the space of a year. Last week, Bahrain activist Nedal Al-Salman was banned from travelling to the EU NGO Forum on human rights, and as we speak, Nabeel Rajab is serving a two-year sentence solely for speaking to the media. He is facing 15 more years for tweets about the Saudi-led coalition air strikes in Yemen and the use of torture in Bahraini prisons. Nevertheless, neither the High Representative nor any EU Member States publicly condemned the confirmation of his sentence on 22 November. Nabeel Rajab is a prisoner of conscience; he deserves our full support and resolute action. In Turkey, the situation is truly appalling. The European Union’s ambiguous relationship with Mr Erdogan is unacceptable, and our policy must change. Many human rights defenders, lawyers, academics, civil society representatives, trade unionist activists, judges, journalists, civil servants and artists face trumped—up charges of terrorism. I would especially like to highlight some cases that are close to my heart, for example Zehra Doğan and the Istanbul 10. The EU must uphold its human rights commitments in assisting civil society actors worldwide as stated in the EU Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy 2015—2019 and the EU global strategy. Ms Mogherini, I urge you to call for the immediate release of Mr Rajab in Bahrain and all jailed human rights defenders in Turkey, and to concretely engage with defenders well before they are put on trial.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! I would also like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on this very good report. As she mentioned, 2016 was undoubtedly a difficult year from a human rights and democracy perspective, but as the previous debate on the situation of refugees in Libya has shown, it is a communal vessel system. I would like to focus on Africa, because I believe that what the Commissioner said is the visible shrinking of space for civil society and social organizations, this is a consequence of, inter alia, suppressing peace protests in countries such as Congo, Nigeria, Ethiopia and Sudan (these are just examples), but also the persecution of journalists and human rights defenders, of course. Armed conflicts in Africa include not only civilian casualties, but also cases of sexual violence against women or, for example, recruiting child soldiers. These and similar cases and phenomena, of course, contribute to mass emigration both within Africa itself and, of course, to Europe, which is why I believe that the promotion of human rights on the African continent is one of the main challenges also for us, in the European interest. I would like to thank the rapporteur for having clearly highlighted in her report the fact that the European Union is working with Africa also at this level. Although many civil society and human rights organizations on the African continent are still young organizations, I believe that supporting them can really provide an opportunity to act effectively and can solve and help solve the problems of these African countries in line with international standards, while ensuring respect, cultural conditioning and building a civil society.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: - Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on the quality of the report. Unfortunately, from year to year and from report to report, we find that human rights, instead of advancing, are, in some cases, suffering serious setbacks in different regions of the world. It would not be fair to ignore that some advances have been made and that many of them have been achieved with the direct or indirect involvement of the European Union. But they are still timid and insufficient progress. Wars and terrorism, the situation of migrants and refugees, trafficking in human beings, slavery, the criminalization of fundamental freedoms, the persecution of minorities, the repression of human rights defenders, the criminalization of abortion, contempt by indigenous peoples, disrespect for the rights of women and children, among others, constitute an extremely dangerous scenario, since they are phenomena that are often interconnected. This scenario therefore requires the European Union to live up to its values ​​and responsibilities. The truth is that all over the world there are millions of people whose human rights are the target of violations from different points of view and who look to the European Union as the last hope of achieving some protection, justice and reparation. And the European Union, for historical, philosophical and cultural reasons, must do everything in its power to avoid abandoning these same people.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur for preparing a good, comprehensive report. 2016 was a dramatic year with many consequences for human rights. It is therefore of utmost importance that the EU stays focused on the good and effective use of our instruments and diligently puts human rights at the core of our relations with the third countries. This should be echoed by the EU institutions and Member States alike. The report puts a lot of emphasis on democratisation and the essential role that the EU plays in this domain. With respect to enlargement and neighbourhood, these regions require that we focus our attention on the rule of law and fundamental freedoms. We must continue to engage with our partners in these countries and pay attention to their political developments. This comprises support to democratic institutions, enhancing parliamentary cooperation and empowering civil society. I especially welcome the mentioning of the essential role the EU plays in election observations and electoral assistance. As election day is the culmination of the life of any democracy, the EU’s support during the entire electoral cycle remains crucial in this respect. Following up on reports and recommendations has to be an integral part of our presence in third countries.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Ms. President! I, too, would like to begin by congratulating you on your comprehensive report, in which the author, on behalf of the European Union, reaffirms his commitment to the promotion of universal human rights, fundamental freedoms and values. The Union must be able to promote respect for human rights in third countries beyond its borders. Many cases of human rights violations appear in the report. I think we can agree that the right to education and the mother tongue is one of the fundamental rights. Thus, I would like to draw attention to the fact that, unfortunately, in Ukraine, the process of reducing the right to use the mother tongue of national minorities by the article on the language of instruction in the new Ukrainian Education Act began in 2016. While so far minorities have had access to all levels of education in their mother tongue, after 2018 it will be limited to primary school, meaning the new law will take back already acquired rights. However, last Friday's EU-Ukraine Association Council's final document states that the EU's official position is that the existing rights of minorities cannot be curtailed. And in a report released Monday, the Venice Commission said criticisms of the week's article were justified and suggested that it be amended. Primarily because the text adopted differs significantly from that on which minorities were consulted and agreed. The seven-week article of the law also contains significant ambiguities, although international and constitutional commitments must be taken into account in the case of comprehensive reforms, especially in the case of existing minority rights. I hope that Ukraine will fully implement the recommendations of the Venice Commission, consult with the minorities concerned and its neighbors, and incorporate the needs and suggestions of nationalities in the implementation of education reform.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Madam President!36 years ago, on December 13, 1981, the emerging democracy was killed in Poland and martial law was introduced.Years passed and in 1989 we returned to the path of building democracy and the rule of law.We lasted for 25 years.Also during this period, other countries in Europe began to build democracy, develop civil society, and respect human rights.Unfortunately, it seems that again in many places in the world we are turning away from these wonderful ideas.There is a growing number of repressive governments, repressive laws, disrespect of some to others, disrespect for human rights and civil society.Unfortunately, this process also applies to some Member States.So if we want to be an ambassador for democracy and human rights around the world in the future, we must deal with these problems at home too.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Ms. President!This afternoon, we raised our voice in defense of the Muslim Rohingya in Myanmar.In other cases, we protect the most persecuted Christian communities in the world.The European Union must act in unison, without distinction on the basis of ethnicity and religion, in order to respect individual human and minority collective rights and freedom of conscience, expression and religion.It is particularly important to take up the fight against disenfranchised and mass murderous religious and political ideologies such as Islamic fundamentalism and atheist communism.The European Union is the main custodian of this universal fight for human rights, as is clear from Parliament's 2016 human rights report.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Commissioner, next year will be 70 years since the adoption of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which has been signed and ratified by almost all the countries of the world.For the third term in this House, I am taking part in the discussion of the evaluation reports on human rights and democracy.These reports are very similar throughout the period.It is astonishing that, after seventy years, there are still so many countries where fundamental, universal, inalienable and non-negotiating rights are not respected.No wonder.What is EU policy like?Respect for human rights in third countries is not always a fundamental condition in trade negotiations with the European Union institutions.And secondly, for almost 10 years now, as in this report, we have been calling for the abolition of abortion, the end of the life of unborn children, despite the fact that, according to all international documents, the right to life is a fundamental and paramount right.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, Mr Andriukaitis, the European Union is really intervening in different parts of the world, claiming that it wants to protect human rights. However, he does not look at what is happening here, in our neighborhood, what is happening in Albania, how the rights of the Greek national minority of the Northern Epirus are being violated there. Where the Albanian authorities, in Chimarra, demolish the houses of the Greeks. Where, again in Northern Epirus, in the village of Drymades, the Albanian authorities demolish Greek churches, demolish the church of Agios Athanasios. Don't we see these issues? How will the European Union intervene in this case to unite the Albanian authorities, to respect the rights of the Greek national minority of the Northern Epirus, their property rights, their religious rights? The European Union must therefore not turn a blind eye to these violations of the rights of the Greek national minority in the Northern Epirus.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Madam President, I am pleased that the report reiterates its call for a common position of the European Union on the use of armed drones. The activities of these silent killers violate international humanitarian law. The machine does not know what the legal framework, proportionality, accountability, civil protection and transparency are. But it is our duty to use them in this spirit. I believe that the whole of the European Union, but above all the Commission, must once again be urged to ban the development, production and use of fully autonomous weapons that allow attacks to be conducted without human intervention. It is our duty to use new military technologies to help protect the lives of soldiers, but this must not be to the detriment of the safety of innocent civilians. We all know that machines have their limits and there is no such thing as 100% efficiency. And it is all the more that we must work to create strong international rules, but above all we must start with ourselves.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, on behalf of Vice-President Federica Mogherini, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and the honourable Members for this very fruitful debate. I could not agree more that maximising the efficiency of our tools in promoting and protecting human rights and democracy is of the utmost importance. To achieve our ambitious goals for improvements to democracy and human rights across the globe, we have to ensure a strategic and systematic approach. Furthermore, external coherence is key for the legitimacy of our external policies, and we count on Parliament’s attentive eye and useful recommendations to ensure such consistency. We remain committed to the improvement of democratic governance at home and will continue supporting democratic transitions in our neighbourhood and beyond. Finally, let me express deep appreciation for the very constructive and enhanced cooperation with this House. Coming back to the 70th anniversary of the Universal Declaration and the slogan of the celebration, ‘Stand up for Human Rights’, we certainly hope, and anticipate, that the European External Action Service, the Commission, the Member States and Parliament will stand together for human rights in the years to come.

name: Godelieve QUISTHOUDT-ROWOHL
text: Rapporteur.- Madam President!Thank you to everyone who spoke here tonight.We all share the same goals, even if we set different priorities.I would also like to thank the Commission for the good cooperation.And please tell Mrs. Mogherini: It's eleven thirty for all of us, not just for her.Thank-you.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place tomorrow, 13 December 2017, at 12 noon.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - Today we are witnessing an increasing violation of human rights and fundamental freedoms around the world, which often affects the most vulnerable groups such as ethnic, linguistic and religious minorities, people with disabilities, members of the LGBTI community, women, children, asylum seekers and migrants. The European Union is based on a strong commitment to the promotion and protection of human rights, democracy and the rule of law worldwide, and this Report is a valuable instrument for providing a comprehensive overview of EU priorities, efforts and challenges in combating violations in third countries. in identifying further effective ways to address them. Over the years, the Union has adopted a number of important documents through which it promotes and protects human rights, and a range of diplomatic and cooperative tools that support the advancement of human rights around the world. The Lisbon Treaty, the role of the Council and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, the Strategic Framework for Human Rights 2012-2021 and the Human Rights Guidelines are important instruments by which the Union promotes and protects human rights and fundamental freedoms. The EU should continue to actively support democratic human rights institutions and civil society in their promotion of democracy, and should continue to actively combat all forms of violations of human rights, democracy and the rule of law within and beyond its borders.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - I congratulate the rapporteur on the fact that it was no longer necessary this year to table an amendment for people with disabilities, because the report commends the ratification of the UN CRPD in a separate paragraph and states that disability does not diminish human dignity, so States have a duty to protect them. I agree that the principle of universal access and the rights of people with disabilities must be credibly integrated into all EU policies, emphasizing the prescriptive and horizontal nature of this issue. I support the EU integrating the fight against disability discrimination into its external action and development aid policies. I am pleased that the rights of people with disabilities are included in the new European Consensus on Development. However, it is still relevant, as was the provision in my text last year, that the effectiveness of projects for people with disabilities should be examined more closely and that local NGOs representing people with disabilities should be involved in their implementation. Support the social integration of people with disabilities in their own place of residence Local organizations need to be involved because they know exactly what is needed locally and they can also help to ensure that support really reaches the people for whom it is intended. We do not need to talk, we need to act, we do not need to export democracy, we need to strengthen local communities.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the report by Alyn Smith, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the recommendation on the situation in Hong Kong 20 years after the handover (2017/22014 (INI)) (A8-0382 / 2017).

name: Alyn SMITH
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I am very pleased to introduce this report –briefly, you’ll be glad to hear at this time of night – to the House. I believe it is an example of the EU adding real value, and of the Parliament working well. The EU external competences are still new, and at best we can use the footprint and historical connections of our Member States to use that insight to inform a values-based foreign policy in the wider world. We can use that insight to inform ourselves, but not be a prisoner of the baggage of history. On that point, on a slightly personal note, it’s a great tragedy for me, that as the EU begins to speak with one voice in the wider world, my own Member State, the United Kingdom, has decided to retreat into isolationism with Brexit, if not my country, Scotland. I assure you, there are plenty of  constructive partners in Scotland, and we’ll be in touch. On this report, it is right that we take stock of the situation in Hong Kong. We are 20 years after the handover from the British to the Chinese, and 20 years into a 50-year commitment to a ‘one country, two systems’ approach. Hong Kong is the 14th biggest trading partner of the European Union, it is an important partner to us, an important part of the EU-China dialogue. And it’s important to be frank: Hong Kong is a great place but all is not perfect. There remains a concern that the ‘one country, two systems’ is being undermined, and in paragraphs 1(b) and 1(l) we voice that concern – not criticism but concern. I believe we have struck a balance. Freedom of speech also must be defended, now and in the future, and in paragraph 1(p) I believe we have struck a balanced statement which takes due stock of where things are. In paragraph 1(t) we set out ways in which we could support and strengthen civil society within Hong Kong, a crucial set of groups that are doing increasingly difficult work; they look to us for support. I am very pleased that we have reached such a high degree of consensus across the house: only two amendments of substance from the GUE group in favour of greater partnership on tax work, tax avoidance, money laundering, and financial transparency.  For my part, I strongly support the amendments, I urge colleagues to support them, too. I think there is a key area where we could assist in the fight against organised crime and money laundering. And with that I would warmly thank the shadow rapporteurs, our most excellent secretariat, the Green/EFA Group staff, and I commend the text very warmly to the House.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, Hong Kong is the European Union’s fourteenth largest trading partner in goods and the fourth largest in services. More than 2000 European companies are present in Hong Kong, and the European Union is Hong Kong’s second largest trading partner in goods after mainland China. Vice President Dombrovskis was in Hong Kong just ten days ago, and we have invited the Chief Executive, Carrie Lam, to visit us in Brussels as soon as possible. We care about Hong Kong, and we know that its autonomy has been the foundation of its success. The people of Hong Kong are now asking to resume electoral reform, and to have a genuine choice for the election of the Chief Executive and Legislative Council in accordance with the basic law. But, as your rapporteur rightly notes, the principle of ‘one country, two systems’ has come under increasing pressure. The rule of law and the independence of the judiciary in Hong Kong have been questioned. The implementation of the electoral reform has been postponed. On top of this, we cannot forget the case of five book publishers who went missing in 2015. To us, that is the most serious challenge to the basic law since 1997, and, unfortunately, it is not an isolated event. In line with the report’s recommendations, we intend to reinforce our bilateral dialogue with Hong Kong. Our latest European Union-Hong Kong structured dialogue took place less than a month ago. What we always stress in our dialogues is that the principle of ‘one country, two systems’ is essential for Hong Kong’s prosperity, but it is also important for change; for its own growth and prosperity. Our relations with China are becoming more and more intense, not only economically, but also on foreign policy and security issues. Our dialogue is very open, and our message to our Chinese friends is very clear: preserving ‘one country, two systems’ is in their best interests, and we are ready to work with them to make this happen.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. - Madam President, I would first like to thank Mr. Alyn Smith for working together and supporting each other. As this is our recommendation to the Commission, the Council and the High Commissioner, I would like to emphasize once again that we have highlighted in our report Hong Kong as a major trading partner of the European Union. Of course, we strongly support the principle of one country - two systems, and the high degree of autonomy that Hong Kong has in relation to China, which stemmed from the Sino-British Declaration twenty years ago. I would also like to emphasize that we, as European institutions, need to support all trade and political partners. We know that Hong Kong has developed into a society where there is the rule of law, freedom and high standards of security, health and autonomy. With this report and this recommendation, we wanted to support the prosperity and rights of Hong Kong citizens in order to enable a model for democratic and political reforms in China, with the goal of liberalizing Chinese society as well. Respect for Hong Kong's autonomy is key to its further development and good relations with China, and the European Union should provide support in this regard. I would also like to emphasize the reform of universal suffrage so that future elections are fully democratic, fair, transparent, but to continue the bilateral dialogue with the European Union in various policy areas, which we confirmed by a large majority in the foreign policy committee. we will vote in Parliament tomorrow as well.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: on behalf of the S&D Club. - Madam President, I thank the rapporteur for his really good cooperation. This report is an important step in our further cooperation with Hong Kong. The approach of one state to two systems is the foundation of our relations. Twenty years have passed, thirty years are ahead of us. The European Union has a close relationship with Hong Kong as an important trading partner, but our relationship needs to be upgraded, for example through better cooperation in education and research programs. As for the situation in Hong Kong, Beijing's interventions in its regulation are noticeable. The right of journalists to write freely is being restricted. We also witnessed protest movements in Hong Kong. Some seek independence, however, the official policy of the European Union is the policy of one China and two systems, which determines our cooperation. I also point out the problem of tax evasion and tax fraud. I support the appeal to the Hong Kong government to take more effective measures against companies that facilitate tax evasion and tax fraud through their branches in the city. I hope that most colleagues will support this appeal in tomorrow's vote.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- In the run-up to this debate, I read in the New York Review of Books, December 21, 2017 edition, a compelling essay by Hong Kong-based journalist Gavin Jacobson entitled "Hong Kong protests".Through interviews with a variety of defenders of core democratic values, Jacobson sketches and analyzes the erosion of China's promise of two systems, that is, the steady undermining of social and political pluralism in Hong Kong.That is exactly what Mr Smith's excellent and valuable report rightly points to.I wish that this debate and this report will be of support to the defenders of democracy and fundamental human rights in Hong Kong.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! I believe that we can only approach the complex and contradictory situation in Hong Kong openly and with openness. In my opinion, this openness is based on the one hand on the recognition of the principle of “one country, two systems”, and on the other hand on the necessary criticism of the politics of regional and international elites, which have made Hong Kong a highly unequal society, on the one hand by extreme poverty and on the other hand is characterized by extreme wealth. The Hong Kong people are suffering from an incredible housing crisis: people are literally living in cages; German media have reported extensively and intensively over the past few weeks. This crisis is fueled to a large extent by money from tax swamp, which deliberately does not appear on the EU's black list of tax havens. Let's drain these swamps! Let's help the people in Hong Kong! Then the rapporteur can act as a credible broker on human rights issues. In any case, we will not be able to approve the report and its recommendations in its current form.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, this has been a very useful exchange and I, on behalf of Vice-President Mogherini, thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and the honourable Members for their interventions. From this debate, we conclude that we all share a strong commitment to Hong Kong’s autonomy in the context of the ‘one country, two systems principle’.  Relations between the EU and Hong Kong keep on growing. Now they cover not only trade and economics, but also customs cooperation, innovation and technology, competition, food safety, the environment and education. European Union companies play a key role in sectors like financial services, retail and distribution, transport and logistics, which are all vital for Hong Kong. They rely on Hong Kong’s efficient business environment. To that end, we hope that in Hong Kong the high standards of the rule of law, transparency, non-discrimination and economic freedom will be maintained in the future. May I close by signalling once again the Commission’s appreciation of Parliament’s role in keeping this important issue on the international agenda.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I really can be very brief, we have such a consensus on this report, the work has been done on it before we got to plenary, so I look forward to a solid majority tomorrow. I echo the points about the lack of progress on electoral reform, but we do cover that in point 1(h). I think we have struck a balanced text across the House. I would thank colleagues for the very good work and look forward to tomorrow’s vote.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place tomorrow, 13 December 2013, at 12 noon.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Christel Schaldemose and Bart Staes, on behalf of the ENVI Committee, on the use of phosphoric acid - phosphates - di-, tri- and polyphosphates (E 338-452) in frozen meat cooked on a vertical skewer (2017/2920 (RPS)) (B8-0666 / 2017).

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: poses. - Madam President! Dear colleagues! The issue we are now debating has received completely absurd treatment in many media in the EU. So let me start by stating it with seven-inch nails: we are not going to ban kebabs in the EU. In the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, on the other hand, we have objected to the Commission's proposal to allow the addition of phosphates in frozen meat to skewers, ie. kebab. We thus want to preserve what we have today, the status quo. If the Commission is to update the EU list of authorized food additives, three criteria must be met: 1. The additive must not be harmful to human health; 2. There must be a technological necessity; and 3. It must not mislead consumers. None of those parts meet the Commission's proposal, unfortunately! However, the core of our objection is first and foremost about health. Doubts have been raised scientifically about the health aspects of phosphates in meat. There is concern about whether the phosphates increase the risk of e.g. incidence of cardiovascular disease. This is also what has led EFSA to decide to give high priority to a reassessment of phosphates and their health effects when put into food. That reassessment will come during 2018. We therefore believe in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy that there is no reason to open up for the addition of phosphates in meat until we know that assessment from EFSA. So when we say no to allowing phosphates in frozen meat, it is primarily for health reasons, and because we want to wait a year while EFSA works. But having said that, there is also no technological necessity present, because there are actually plenty of good kebabs on the European market today that are completely free of phosphates. And if you want and absolutely want a binder in your kebab, then there are both E-number-free and chemical-free binders on the market. So it is possible to act without phosphates. And then I would like to address some of the things that have been raised in the media. In Germany in particular, there has been great concern on top of our vote in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, and there have been stories of job losses and all sorts of things. I would like to state that the current EU rules also apply in Germany, so Germany is not allowed under the EU today to add phosphates in frozen skewers with meat. If it takes place in Germany today, it is because the rules are not being obeyed. Others have also highlighted that there are some types of meat that are allowed to have phosphates in. That is correct! There are e.g. some traditional sausages where allowed. But we do not think there is any reason to allow a whole lot of new areas until we are sure that there is no health problem. Incidentally, this was also a matter that we in the Environment Committee raised with the European Commission back in 2014 with our then chairman of the Environment Committee, Matthias Groote. We raised the concern and we still share that concern. So instead of shouting that the EU will ban kebabs, which is not true, the media and businesses and citizens should instead ask the Commission why the Commission wants to make our food worse and more unhealthy, because that is what this story is about! In the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, we take our task of seriously protecting European citizens, and that is why we appeal to the precautionary principle. We await EFSA's assessment of the phosphates in 2018 before we think any changes need to be made. That's why we want the status quo, that's why we come up with this objection.

name: Bart STAES
text: Author. - I agree fully with what Christel Schaldemose has said. This debate is not about banning kebabs. This debate is about maintaining the current legislation, which clearly prohibits the addition of phosphates to meat preparations. That is why we oppose the Commission proposal to allow this. Yes, there are problems in the Member States. Yes, there are debates in some Member States whether kebab is a meat preparation or a meat product. But then it is up to the Commission to help Member States, to step up controls, to guide them there. I have tabled another amendment on this that clarifies the situation. Mrs Sommer, you led the resistance in Germany and I am very sorry for doing so in a populist, unfair way. This is not right. The addition of phosphates in kebabs is not allowed. That's what the regulations say. There are only three reasons why the Commission can deviate from this and still include phosphates in a positive list. Mrs. Schaldemose has listed them. It must be clear whether or not they are harmful to public health. There are plenty of studies that cast doubt on this. Even EFSA has not provided a conclusive answer to date and EFSA has decided to conduct an overview study, an overview study that will not be concluded until the end of December 2018. The precautionary principle then says that we have to wait a while until there is clarity. Second, there must be certainty that there is an alternative. The debate that has taken place in the press in recent days and weeks shows that there are alternatives, alternatives where no E-numbers are added to kebab preparations, which are safe, which are healthy. If that is possible - and I have tabled an amendment on that too - then it becomes clear that the opposition of Ms Schaldemose and myself is effectively not opposition to the kebab industry against workers in the German meat industry.Finally, it is indeed true that phosphates are also added to other products such as burgers, such as sausages, even soft drinks.If the EFSA study says that they are harmful to public health, then you should delete those products from the positive list.

name: Bart STAES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the application concerning the use of phosphates in frozen vertical meat spits received in 2015 has been discussed in detail several times by the Working Party of Governmental Experts on Additives as regards the fulfilment of the conditions for inclusion in the Union list and the use of food additives. These conditions are defined in the Regulation on Food Additives. They provide that a food additive may be included in the Union list only if: firstly, it does not pose safety concerns; secondly, there is a reasonable technological need; thirdly, the issue does not mislead consumers; and, fourthly, its use has advantages and benefits for the consumer. Let me briefly set out the evidence that all these conditions are fulfilled for this application. Regarding safety, the safety of phosphates was evaluated by the Scientific Committee for Food before 1991, and the maximum tolerable daily intake of 70 milligrams per kilogram of body weight expressed as phosphorous was established. Current authorisations are based on this evaluation. Phosphates are authorised for use in a wide variety – I would like to draw your attention to this – of foods, including meat products and certain meat preparations. The extension of their use to frozen vertical meat spits does have a significant impact on overall exposure to phosphates. I would like to draw your attention to this because it is very important. Following a request from the Commission, in 2013 the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) assessed a published review on health risks associated with phosphate additives. In the light of this assessment, EFSA did not question the conclusions of opinion of the Scientific Committee for Food. The Commission regulation setting up a programme for the re—evaluation of approved food additives requires EFSA to re—evaluate the safety of all food additives approved before 20 January 2009. The end of 2018 was set as a deadline for the re—evaluation of phosphates. All the relevant and most up—to—date scientific evidence will no doubt be collected and evaluated. The Commission closely follows the re—evaluation programme and considers appropriate risk management measures, when needed, on the basis of published opinions. Pending the publication of the new EFSA opinion on phosphates, the health—based guidance value established in the opinion of the Scientific Committee for Food remains valid.  Regarding technological needs, the technological need was recognised for certain meat spits, as specified in the draft regulation. Phosphates are needed, in particular, for the stabilisation of meat spits and for bonding meat pieces together to ensure homogenous freezing and to prevent the risk of unbalanced heat treatment or of raw or burnt spots. This is very important from a health point of view. Economically and technologically practical alternatives were not identified.  As regards not misleading the consumer, if added water makes up more than five percent of the weight of the finished product, according to the applicable European Union legislation, it has to be explicitly mentioned in business—to—business trade. As regards water in roasted meat spits, as consumed, the data provided by the applicant demonstrated that the use of phosphates does not lead to any additional water content. As a result of the heat treatment, additional water is not retained despite the addition of phosphates.  Finally, let me address the advantages and benefits for the consumer. Phosphates ensure homogenous freezing and prevent the risk of unbalanced heat treatment or of raw or burned spots. The avoidance of raw parts or burned spots results in a better quality and tastier product for the consumer. For the reasons I have set out, the Commission is of the opinion that the draft regulation fulfils all the relevant requirements of the Regulation on Food Additives.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues! The objection of the Social Democrats and the Greens is pure scare tactics, it is ignorant and it is irresponsible. Why? Phosphates are permitted in many foods, but they are also found naturally in many foods. If that were really that dangerous to health, we would all be terminally ill long ago. And why, dear Social Democrats, did you actually have no problem with phosphate in Kassler in 2014? What do you have against doner kebab? A doner kebab contains just 134 milligrams of phosphates. That is a fraction of the 4,200 milligrams of phosphate per day that the EFSA declares to be safe. In addition, phosphates have long been allowed in grilled kebab. And by the way: EFSA - the Commissioner said it - examines all food additives, not just phosphate, because it can be so dangerous under certain circumstances; that's not true. The claim that doner kebab does not need phosphate is ignorant. On the contrary: without phosphate there is no kebab, but a slumped heap of meat, burned on the outside, still raw on the inside, a hygiene risk. So there is a technical need, and there is no substitute, tapioca flour cannot be used for doner kebab either, and it also contains phosphate. There is also no misleading consumer because of the addition of water. The Commissioner has just explained. The added water mainly evaporates when the meat is cooked through. So all the arguments in the motion for a resolution are wrong and yet you are sticking to them? You are endangering tens of thousands of jobs for no reason; that is irresponsible. It's really just a technical clarification that phosphate is allowed in raw kebab skewers as well as in grilled ones. Without this clarification, phosphate will be banned in kebab. And that is exactly what some Member States are planning for this case. You will not have an eye squeeze more.But that is exactly what your motion for a resolution calls for: you want the end of the doner kebab in the EU.We do not want to allow that, we must not do that to our citizens.We want to save the doner kebab.

name: Susanne MELIOR
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Ms. Sommer, what you are doing here is scaremongering at a high level. You say: there will be no more kebab if we vote in favor of this objection tomorrow. I will try to react to this in a very factual manner and not encourage this scare tactic any further. Our objection is directed against a decision by the Commission on the exemption for the addition of phosphate-containing additives in frozen meat skewers for kebab and gyros. The addition of phosphates is not permitted for meat preparations, except for precisely defined exceptions. These exceptions include - you said that right - Kassler or meat roast, which is used in sausages. Strictly speaking, since the Food Additives Ordinance came into force in 2008, no phosphates should be used in the production of frozen meat skewers. If lobbying was required here, it would have been here. For once you are right. There is a legal loophole here. However, there are also very different interpretations of courts in Germany, for example in a judgment from Munich and one from Augsburg - both are not identical. The S&D Group is not generally against the fact that this exemption should also be granted for frozen meat skewers. The point in time alone cannot be understood by us at all. The European Food Authority - and the Commissioner has confirmed this again - is currently checking the effectiveness of additives containing phosphates. The results will be available by the end of 2018. So then we have a reassessment. Dear Commissioner, if the assessment was made in 1991, it was a very long time ago and we may have learned something new. So we should wait for this evaluation and then decide which food products remain on the exception list and which should be removed.So this scaremongering that there would be no more kebab is completely wrong.Doner kebab can also be produced without additives containing phosphates.You just said that wrongly, Ms. Sommer, and it has been described differently in the media several times, especially by the largest manufacturer in Germany.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, the way kebabs are made in street stalls today has little to do with how they are really to be made. For a few bucks, kebab sellers have frozen lumps of meat transported from Germany, which are stuffed with phosphate to save money, as the meat does not dry out on the grill and sells it to consumers at a reduced cost for a few euros. The current procedure has nothing to do with cooking, because traditionally this delicacy is made by interlacing different types of meat, differently fatty, and not from a fabric of unattractive shape and smell. Just to realize what we are talking about here, a colleague from S&D has already explained here how meaningless the PPE Group's argument is. If my colleague says that we want to save kebabs, I would very much like it to be primarily in the PPE Group's interest to protect European citizens. That is far more important to me. And if there is the slightest suspicion, then I must behave according to the precautionary principle, that is, behave in such a way that I do not put citizens at risk. And so, as has been said several times here, you put something in our mouths that is simply not true. All we want is for the Commission not to be in an unnecessary hurry, to wait for the European Agency to assess the whole matter in a year and for the results, how we will get to know them and according to them, and how the results will turn out, in order to survive. I do not know where you are in a hurry, but we are in no hurry to harm European citizens.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are past midnight, midnight and two minutes, and we are here to talk about an extremely important issue, which is the health of citizens. We are here to say stop to those European regulations that poison our citizens every day. No to those regulations that are against common sense and against the health of citizens. We want a Europe that works to safeguard the nutrition of our citizens, to safeguard the health of our citizens. Not a Europe that every day never misses an opportunity to make regulations to poison the tables of our citizens and the mouths of our citizens. Tonight there is even talk to save kebabs, but before saving kebabs, let's think about saving European citizens. We are fed up! Christmas 2017, which is upon us, sees what I have in this dish as a gift from this Europe. In this dish we have insects: this is the gift of the European Union for European citizens in 2017, insects for the tables of 2018, from January 2018. Now someone wants to give meat with phosphates instead for Christmas 2018. Here, we would like to give health, tranquility in nutrition to our citizens. I suggest that the Commissioners set a good example: you start eating roasted insects and eating meat with phosphates, so that the European people can see the side effects and reassure themselves, if those regulations that you propose every year are right or wrong. to the European people.

name: Esther HERRANZ GARCÍA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in this case, as in so many others, the important thing is to let EFSA work with complete autonomy. We have an excellent scientific authority that is in charge of issuing the opinions on which to base our political decisions. EFSA must carry out a new evaluation as required by Regulation (EU) No 257/2010. Until then, in my opinion, it is obvious to note that it is not appropriate to make any type of value judgment and even more so when the information published by this Authority up to this moment indicates that there is no clear indication of risk to health, which is the most important thing: the health of our citizens. Therefore, we must reject this objection that would directly or indirectly put the work of many people at risk and await their opinion, which, as the text of the objection itself indicates, must be presented within a year. If it is proven by EFSA in the future that there is some kind of risk to human health, I will be the first to support such a re-evaluation of this substance. Until then, it only remains to trust the scientific work of the European Authority, which is the one that truly cares about the health of all our citizens.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: - Years ago, the European Commission acknowledged that some Member States were in breach of European legislation, which did not allow the use of phosphates in meat preparations, except in individual cases. Today, the use of phosphates in the preparation of kebabs and gyros is therefore prohibited and I want it to remain so. After all, kebabs have spent most of their lives without phosphates.
