Experts warn us that there are signs of links between phosphate supplements to food and increased risks of cardiovascular disease, that phosphate supplements worsen bone and kidney health and even increase mortality. We are in no hurry to expand the set of exceptions until EFSA publishes a final report on the impact of phosphates on food. We are not in a hurry when it comes to human health. Let us act wisely and emphasize the importance of prevention in health. They say accepting the objection tomorrow would have negative consequences for the deal. I, on the other hand, believe that prevention is much cheaper than subsequent treatment. Ladies and gentlemen, none of us who support the objection to the Commission's proposal wants to ban kebabs. All of us who have children know well how popular it is among adolescents. The only thing we really want is for young people and adults to be able to eat kebabs and other similar meat preparations healthy, without unnecessary phosphate additions. Here, too, it is necessary to pave the way for healthy alternatives.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, I believe that this midnight debate is perhaps more harmful to health than the 100 mg of phosphate I have consumed in the sausage today. In any case, we are now talking about phosphate in frozen meat, because some Members simply want to ban them. The objection to the Commission's action is, in my view, unfounded. I believe that the Commission is responding correctly to current practice and is providing the regulation with greater transparency and certainty for both consumers and producers. Phosphates are already explicitly allowed in fresh meat today and it is quite consistent that this should also be the case in frozen meat. Should it prove to be defective in the future, it is of course possible to continue working with this limit. As we know, phosphates are used both for the more pronounced taste and smell of meat. The use of phosphate is certainly not ideal, it should be reduced, which is also the case, under pressure of regulation or also for the purpose of quality. Manufacturers strive to improve this quality and voluntarily reduce the content of these substances. Our role is to ensure, above all, health safety. So, of course, I agree that we should be very careful, and that is why the Commission also allows only a minimum amount of phosphate. Our role in this is therefore clear and the Commission's action is moving in this direction, which is why I support its regulatory proposal. I consider the total ban to be a purely populist gesture with which I do not agree.

name: Ivo BELET
text: - I just went here near Parliament to buy another delicious kebab. I will not eat him now, Commissioner, otherwise I will have to speak with my full mouth to you and my colleagues. So I'm going to eat it later, with a lot of enthusiasm. I don't think we are supposed to ban that kebab all of a sudden because some here in House have started an ideological and some patronizing crusade. We are also concerned with public health. Public health is one of our priorities, especially for this European Parliament and for the European Commission. But please, let's stop panicking. There is no reason at all. If you eat too many of those kebabs, if you eat two or three a day, yes, of course that is too much and it can affect your health, but that also applies to chips, that also applies to soft drinks, you name it . So, as Mr Peterle rightly put it, let the European Food Agency do its job. Once the research into the added ingredients such as phosphate in our diet has been completed, we can pass judgment. But in the meantime, please, let's not ban this kebab. Because if we are logical with ourselves, then today we must also ban all kinds of cheeses and soft drinks and all kinds of other meat products. That would be great. So tasty and have a good evening.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! As a new member of the House, this is my first full day of plenary. In fact, I am happy to be able to follow the principle of Montesquieu, who said: "If it is not necessary to make a law, then it is necessary not to make a law". In this case, regarding kebabs, one would have to say: if it is not necessary to make a ban, then it is necessary not to make a ban. After studying the documents and after the deliberations, it seems to me to be clear that it is not necessary to make a ban because the phosphate content in the kebab is much, much lower than in many dishes and, incidentally, also beverages that we constantly eat take us. If Mrs Sommer, who thankfully took up this issue so as not to contribute to overregulation at European level, is accused of populism, as has just been done, then that is self-directed, because the scare-mongering that is behind it if an attempt is made to intervene centrally on our part in something that affects the everyday life of the citizens, which is real populism. I am therefore pleased to be able to vote against the objection to the Commission proposal in the upcoming vote and to make it clear that the European Union is dealing with important issues, as has already happened in the nightly debate today - Israel, human rights, Libya, Hong Kong -, and it does not overregulate it, for example by banning the kebab.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened very carefully to the comments made and the views expressed. Let me assure the honourable Members that all the concerns have been considered by the Commission services and discussed with Member State experts on food additives. We had very thorough debates.  Of course, health is the main concern of the Commission, and personally I am very concerned about people’s health. The draft regulation received the strong support of the Standing Committee on Plants, Animals, Food and Feed on 25 September 2017, and not one Member State questioned the safety of the proposed use.  Some colleagues made some emotional expressions, and I would like to draw attention to a comment by Angelo Ciocca, in which he proposed that I taste insects. I would like to draw your attention to the fact that, in the New Testament, Saint John the Baptist ate grasshoppers with wild honey. It is an old story, and it was tasty and healthy. At this very important time, do not disseminate messages which are not reality.  I would like to repeat that the Commission is firmly of the view that the draft regulation fulfils all the relevant legislative requirements. Thank you very much indeed, and I wish you all a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: - I close the debate.The vote will take place tomorrow, 13 December 2013, at 12 noon.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: in writing. - Statistics show that every day EU citizens consume several hundred tons of meat in kebabs. We must remember that the market for the production of meat for kebabs includes companies operating in this market, and behind each company there are numerous jobs in gastronomy, which we must remember when considering the economic aspects of this issue. However, the results of the conducted research do not allow to conclusively state whether there is a cause and effect relationship between the risk of diseases and the consumption of phosphates. I believe that consumer decisions should be based on reliable information about the products offered for sale and the consumption of which may affect our health. Therefore, we must be careful in taking the final decisions regarding the prohibition or non-ban on phosphates, and instead of making that choice today, let EFSA reassess the safety of phosphate food additives, due by December 31, 2018. Remember, that one serving of kebab is about 134 mg of phosphate, so if we eat it regularly for a year, we would consume the amount that is in a 1.5 liter bottle of Coca-Cola. After all, every day we come across substances that are harmful when consumed in excess, but their responsible consumption and, for example, information campaigns allow us to make informed consumer decisions and at the same time take care of the health of EU residents.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: in writing.- The objection concerning the use of phosphates in frozen meat loaf for vertical grilling responds to the Commission's proposal to update one of the annexes to the current Regulation on food additives.The proposal is to legalize in practice the use of phosphates (and several other so-called eček) in this type of meat.Authorization of the use of additives in foodstuffs is based on three preconditions: additives must be safe, their use must be technologically justified and must not mislead the consumer.However, in the case of the use of phosphates, there are concerns that none of the above criteria are met, and in particular the health aspect needs to be carefully considered before the general ban on the use of phosphate additives in meat preparations should be revised in any way.
